B4OPINIONWhy U.S. CEOs turned against shareholdersTop executives are finding that in a world of concentrated ownership, they aren't as protected by a regime of share-price primacyKATHARINA PISTOR

Professor of comparative law at Columbia Law School and the author of The Code of Capital: How the Law Creates Wealth and Inequality

The Business Roundtable, an association of the most powerful chief executive officers in the United States, announced this month that the era of shareholder primacy is over.

Predictably, this lofty proclamation has met with both elation and skepticism. But the statement is notable not so much for its content as for what it reveals about how U.S. CEOs think. Apparently, the U.S.'s corporate leaders believe they can decide freely whom they serve. But as agents, rather than principals, that decision really isn't theirs to make.

The fact that American CEOs think they can choose their own masters attests not just to their own sense of entitlement, but also to the state of Corporate America, where power over globe-spanning business empires is concentrated in the hands of just a few men (and far fewer women). As a matter of corporate law, CEOs are appointed by a company's directors, who in turn are elected by that company's shareholders every year. In practical terms, though, most directors remain on the board for years on end, as do the officers they appoint.

For example, Jamie Dimon, the chairman of the Business Roundtable's own board of directors, has been at the helm of JPMorgan Chase for more than 15 years. During most of that time, he has served as both CEO and chairman of the board of directors, in contravention of corporate-governance principles that recommend separating these two positions.

By capturing the process to which they owe their own positions, American CEOs have made a mockery of shareholder control. The Business Roundtable itself has long favoured plurality over majority voting, which means that incumbent board members need only receive more votes than anybody else, rather than a majority. At the same time, the organization has fought the Securities and Exchange Commission tooth and nail to block a rule that would allow shareholders to write in their own candidates when votes are solicited. And it continues to try to weaken shareholders' ability to propose agenda items for shareholder meetings.

In short, for the Business Roundtable and the CEOs it represents, shareholder primacy has never meant shareholder democracy. Instead, the shareholdervalue model has given CEOs cover to avoid discussing corporate strategy, especially when it comes to considering alternatives to the share price as a metric for corporate performance.

For CEOs, the share price is everything, because it protects the company from takeovers (the greatest threat to incumbent managers), and it increases their own remuneration.

Why, then, would CEOs come out against a status quo that has allowed them to reign almost unchallenged, in favour of a stakeholder-governance model that puts employees and the environment on an equal footing with shareholders? The answer is that revolutions often devour their children. Share-price primacy has not only ceased to protect CEOs in the way it once did; it has become a threat.

After all, it is one thing to champion shareholders when they are too dispersed to organize themselves. It is quite a different matter when shareholders have assembled into blocs with effective veto power and the ability to co-ordinate in pursuit of common goals. Some 74 per cent of JPMorgan Chase's shares are held by institutional investors, five of which - including Vanguard, BlackRock and State Street - control one-third of total shares. And JPMorgan isn't alone.

Recent research in the U.S. shows that the same few global asset managers are top shareholders at almost all of the largest financial intermediaries, Big Tech firms and airline companies.

For CEOs, the emergence of powerful shareholder blocs has changed the corporate-governance game. With trillions of dollars of savings that need to be invested, institutional investors simply cannot be ignored. Even if asset managers do not actively involve themselves in corporate governance, they can still send a powerful signal to the market simply by dumping shares.

For years, the shareholder-primacy model led CEOs to eke out profits through outsourcing or labour-force downsizing, regulatory and tax arbitrage, and stock buybacks that shower cash on shareholders at the expense of investing in their companies' future. But now, they have finally realized that these strategies are better for institutional investors than they are for the sustainability of firms.

Confronted with the headwinds they themselves generated, American CEOs seem to have concluded that the best defence is a good offence. But if they are serious about abandoning the shareholder-primacy model, public statements will not suffice. They must also support legal reforms, particularly the measures needed to hold corporate directors and officers accountable to the principals they serve.

That could mean extending board representation to employees and other stakeholders, or it could take the form of special audits, along the lines of those to which public benefit corporations submit.

Either way, if the new stakeholder model is going to amount to more than the old charade of "shareholder democracy," the principals themselves must be involved in setting up the new regime. If we leave it for the agents to decide for themselves, we will end up right back where we started.

urn:contentItem:5YWC-WK11-JDKC-R2RB-00000-00Opinion | Will Facebook's oversight board sanitize the internet?2020-05-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:39ZLexisNexisOpinion | Will Facebook's oversight board sanitize the internet?New Delhi

New Delhi, May 11 -- Last week, Mint reported that Facebook had extended its announcements on an oversight board that it formed some months ago. The report spoke of what the board is aimed at, how it is structured, and provided an analysis of Facebook's record on free speech. Separately funded, the board is not supposed to be under Facebook's control. It will provide independent reviews of content and act as a "supreme court" for people appealing against its internal review processes for taking down objectionable content. It can override decisions taken by Facebook's own internal watchdogs and committees. This won't include sovereign government requests, for which it has a separate process.

The board will now have over 20 members from across the globe, including Sudhir Krishnaswamy, vice-chancellor of National Law School of India University in Bangalore, human rights advocates, a former US judge, a former prime minister of Denmark and a Yemeni Nobel laureate.

For now, the board will focus only on Facebook and its subsidiary Instagram. Its aegis may expand to include its other platforms, like WhatsApp, but the real story lies in the impact it is likely to have on the internet per se. For some time now, a debate has been raging on whether online social networks are just conduits for free speech or whether they are reporters of news, which would call for stricter governmental control and make them liable for acts of defamation and libel. Plus, such platforms have also been acting as conduits for actual news, often without acknowledging or paying news organizations for content. This has put Facebook, Google's YouTube, and others in the crosshairs of regulators in many countries. In Europe, they recently ruled that Google needs to pay news organizations for showing their content on its searches.

Facebook's move is smart. Firms with immense market power are better-off self-regulating, before official bodies impose fines or clamp down. At the extreme end, large companies may possibly be broken up, as happened in the past to firms such as AT&T and IBM. But it seems likely to me that other governments will see Facebook's model as a good way to introduce legislation that requires internet companies to form similar oversight devices. The danger of it lies in the creation of yet another layer of red tape and reporting requirements before the internet has a chance to truly discover how such mechanisms could self-correct.

If internet platforms with contentious content, such as YouTube, Snapchat and TikTok, see that governmental regulation could take a course that their lobbying cannot stop, they will look for another way to head off regulation. Investing in Facebook's oversight board and submitting to its authority could be just the opportunity they are looking for.

This would leave the policing of internet content in private hands, just as the internet domain system was privatized in 1998. This was originally run by the US Department of Commerce, until it realized that website name control was a global issue best left in private hands.

All this noise about a global oversight organization should not take our attention away from the front line in the war against reprehensible content. People with sick minds are everywhere, including on the internet, and routinely post hate speech, child pornography, crime videos, and live streams of the torture, maiming and killing of animals and humans online. Facebook, YouTube and others, in representations, have argued that artificial intelligence (AI) will be able to police such content and not allow it onto their platforms.

The sad truth is that AI is nowhere near being able to vet and keep out objectionable content the way it needs to be. And this is where the true travesty of Big Tech's Janus-like approach lies. Last year, a disturbing report on theverge.com pointed to the underbelly of policing content in the world of social networks online.

Facebook and other social network firms allegedly do not pay much attention to their workers-or those of contracted firms-who monitor their gigantic sites for objectionable content.

The aforementioned report presented a chilling and disturbing view of the operations of an information technology service provider retained by Facebook to monitor content on its platform. Evidently, at least one employee died of a heart attack suffered while he was at work. These guardians of our mental health are poorly paid and frequently have to endure audio-visual content that graphically depicts people's inhumanity towards fellow humans and other sentient beings. The job of the censors who must see all this is unenviable, for it is they who must expunge the horrors that twisted human beings put up online and whose decisions Facebook's new "supreme court" will now sit in judgment of.

It may be true that advances in AI will relieve workers of the trauma that these jobs could inflict, and the sooner such technology can help the process of filtering out stuff that should not be available to anyone in the world, the better.

But we cannot let vague promises about the future of AI, and the politically strategic but still sanctimonious setting up of independent oversight boards, give social media platforms a pretext to turn a blind eye to the mental torture faced by real human beings who are toiling on the front line of internet content control.

urn:contentItem:5F98-1G21-DXH2-62YX-00000-00Opower Inc at Goldman Sachs Technology & Internet ConferenceÂ - Final2015-02-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:39ZLexisNexis021015a5610766.766Opower Incat Goldman Sachs Technology & Internet ConferenceÂ  - Final

Corporate Participants

* Daniel Yates

Opower Inc.- Co-founder, CEO

* Thomas Kramer

Opower Inc.- CFO

Conference Call Participants

* Greg Dunham

Goldman Sachs - Analyst

Presentation

GREG DUNHAM, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Good afternoon. Very excited to have founder and Chief Executive Officer of Opower, Daniel Yates.

DANIEL YATES, CO-FOUNDER, CEO, OPOWER INC.: Thanks for having me.

GREG DUNHAM: Well, thank you. Opower-- brand new public company; came public early in 2014. Don't know if the audience is very familiar with kind of what you guys do. But maybe give us the two- to three-minute overview of why you founded the Company, what problems are you trying to solve, and how we should think about the opportunity.

DANIEL YATES: Absolutely. Definitely see some familiar faces here in the audience. So there's some who know this story well; others may be hearing it for the same time.

I co-founded this Company about eight years ago with my good friend and Opower's President, Alex Laskey. And we at the time had a simple vision, or idea, which was that people didn't know enough about their energy use. And if we could give people better information, we could help people save energy.

And that's how the Company started. It started with a product focused around using the power of information to drive large-scale reductions in energy consumption. And we've had great success with that. We ended this last year delivering 2.7 terawatt hours of energy savings, significantly exceeding all of our utilities clients' energy efficiency mandated goals, on average.

So really delivering for our clients. And I would put this in perspective. Solar City customer, a company many of us know well, one of -- the largest residential solar installer, by my calculations is generating less than half that amount of energy compared to the amount that we've saved. So we have really delivered on our goal of being a significant contributor to emissions reduction while building a big business. That was the first chapter of the Company.

Welcome Thomas Kramer, our CFO, who (inaudible) the mic as we speak.

What I'm excited about today is how much further we've taken the Company since that idea in 2007. In the position that we've been in in the market we've been able now to work with nearly 100 utilities, mostly in the US but all over the globe, out of the 100 utilities worldwide. And we're working with many of the largest utilities on earth. So our customers, our utility clients, they serve 135 million end customers, which represents about 20% of the overall market. So we're working with many of the leaders globally.

And in working with them, and as we've developed new applications and have expanded our technology platform, they've come back to us over and over again, saying, how can you take what you have, this capability and behavior change in a mass market engagement, and apply it to all of our other customer touch points? Because let's face it, we haven't historically been customer-focused. We don't really know how to get things done in that domain and we are under increasing pressure to do so.

And that's one of the exciting and perhaps not obvious dynamics in the energy industry, is that utilities are really becoming globally much more customer-focused, and it's a secular trend that's driving a lot of their investment and their attention.

And so what we've done now is take this starting position and evolved it, and this is our ambition now -- to be the company that leads the transformation of how utilities serve their customers for everything, ranging from billing to outage to call center activities to customer life cycle move-in move-out. And continuing to expand from this center of strength with demand management.

GREG DUNHAM: And let's hit on that a little bit. Why haven't the utilities focused on the consumers as customers historically? What is driving the change, and what's the technology that they're using today to interact with their customers, and what's going to cause them to change?

DANIEL YATES: Yes. The 1980 utility paradigm was very simple. It was demand is going up as a critical starting assumption, and so I need to build new stuff. And when I build stuff, whether it's a power plant or new transmission lines or distribution lines, I get to rate-base that, which means I get to charge my customers for that infrastructure and get a return on investments.

And what's happened now is all across the developed world, demand isn't going up. So utilities can't just keep building stuff. Environmental mandates, some of which include what drives our efficiency business but others that are totally unrelated, are shutting down coal plants and driving up the cost to provide electricity at the current stable not-growing levels that it's at.

And increasingly across the globe, whether here in the US, and particularly here at PG&E, where you're seeing customers switch to Solar City from their utility, or in other parts of the world where you can compete and actually people can choose their provider just like they choose their bank or their cell phone carrier, they're facing competition.

So it's earnings pressure from no growth in demand. It's the environmental mandates that are driving this cost up even further. And then, it's this competitive threat, that all combined utilities are realizing they have to switch.

Let me give you an anecdote. So I was just with Bob Powers, the CEO of AEP, which is American Electric Power. It serves almost, I think, 11 states in the Midwest. This is a coal-burning meat-eating utility. He has no interest in energy efficiency and previous meetings I've had with him, he has been somewhat like this as I've talked to him about our efficiency programs.

And I sat down with him last week because he had -- I'd talked to him about our new capabilities that we're exploring around customer engagement and helping [redo] costs to serve. And he lit up. His No. 1 priority -- and this guy has got this religion the last two years -- is around JD Powers scores. Because in his words, he said, I've always been an engineer and I always figured my customers will love me if I just keep the lights on. And it's come home to roost, and I admit it now -- have the highest reliability scores in the country and my customers hate me. It's not just about reliability; I've got to serve them better. And this is what I'm focused on -- how can you help me drive up customer sat?

And that was just, like, when AEP and Bob Powers is focused on this, it means that our industry, writ large, is focused on these issues.

GREG DUNHAM: And then from a technology perspective, what are they doing today? I think a lot of investors, they see the output -- what Opowerdoes. But they don't understand the technology underneath for what enables that output. So help investors understand why this is difficult, to do what you do. Why can't somebody else just kind of -- why can't the utilities invest and have a [best CRM] analytic solution that does this?

DANIEL YATES: And a lot of investors I talk to have experienced our very first product, which has wide distribution and it is, by design, very memorable, which is our paper home energy report. And by dint of how we focused our business, a lot of what we've developed since then may or may not be as -- not visible by the consumer per se. Because we are building a real enterprise software technology suite here and the consumer touch points are the tip of the iceberg.

Our platform sits on top of these legacy back-end systems and it sucks in data from them -- the billing system, the meter data management system, call center data -- and we integrate that on an ongoing basis as frequently as every few hours. We get data flows from each of our 100 utilities and we have 400 billion rows of smart meter data that we can run analytics on.

And then, we have a whole suite of utility-facing interfaces. So we have business intelligence, we have sophisticated segmentation and targeting and customer subscription capabilities to decide who gets which communications.

And then on top of that, we have all of the digital communications -- the Web, the mobile, the outbound, the triggered emails. And then of course, the paper reports.

It's kind of like some mix of GRM and Marketo that has a lot of advanced capabilities now. And again, it sits on top of these legacy systems, extending their life cycle.

So there's just a lot of tech there. I'll add a couple of other data points. There's a bunch of APIs and service-[oriented] architecture. And some of our deals we've won recently -- we announced one in Q3 -- we have other partners, actually, deploying their capabilities on our platform where one of them, for example in this latest deal, needs data to serve to provide their features, and all of the data -- their customer data they're getting -- is through a secure authenticated API access through our platform.

So we've enabled those kind of capabilities, and we've enabled tremendous pro-serve enhancement capabilities, which is strengthening our relationships with Accenture and other SIs.

GREG DUNHAM: So when you don't win a deal, who -- is it that you lose to somebody or is it more status quo?

DANIEL YATES: We don't lose very often, so we don't have a lot of -- competitive threats is not a major concern of mine on a daily basis. What we have focused on, and part of why I'm so excited about this new -- or, this clarified three -- five-year technology vision -- is that we want to have more products to sell to more customers more quickly. And for us, status quo is when we're set back; not competitive loss.

GREG DUNHAM: One of the things that immediately jumps to investors' minds is they hear the 130 million, and they think, holy cow, these guys are already in -- already have big penetration. Can you talk about when you win and a customer says, we've developed -- the penetration in that existing utility may be actually pretty small. What's the governor to you expanding?

And what's the range of outcomes? Can you get to 50%, 70%? How do you get the penetration rate up?

DANIEL YATES: Yes. Let me start with, actually the simplest view. We calculate our TAM to be about $11 billion, and that is a mix of energy efficiency, demand response, and customer care funding. We're only looking at residential and small, medium business.

Now within that, then, the question comes, what is our total serviceable market? I will, in a moment, go into it in sort of a line-by-line basis. But I actually think the easiest way to look at this is we have solutions like efficiency that price between $7 and $10 a home a year. We have demand response at $4 to $5. And then our customer engagement solution today is typically between $1 and $1.50. (I'm really emotional about the last $0.50.)

We're about to launch another product which we're announcing next week at PowerUp, our customer conference, which will also be in that kind of $1 to $1.50 range; will be certainly $1.50 or more. And those last two solutions will be applicable to absolutely every utility on earth.

So I'd say that in contrast to the demand response energy efficiency, there are some penetration questions within a utility as well as within regions.

So putting that aside for a moment, if you just take all of that and say -- gross underestimate, let's just call it $3 per home per year. I've got 700 million addressable home and small business customers. I've got 1200 utilities. If I take even just the top 600 utilities and I say those are the guys I'm going after, and I look at -- so first of all, they've got a $2 billion total serviceable market.

Then if I look at them and say, what's the replacement cycle on this customer stuff? Let's call it five to seven years. Okay, so average that at six -- 600 utilities -- I've got 100 a year, $3 a home, a million homes utility in this group -- I've got about $300 million of opportunity every year to go after. That is plenty of space to go after.

Now with that as a backdrop, let's go talk about efficiency and demand response. The reality is the efficiency market is very robust in the US. It's about $6 billion a year in the US alone. That includes some stuff that we can't touch, but we have 30 states in the US that have efficiency mandates, and that's where we get to play.

And within those, with our most penetrated customers we are 100% penetrated. On average, we're still only 10% penetrated. I don't think we will get to 100% penetrated, but we have a tremendous amount of headroom ahead of us.

So what drives the efficiency dynamics specifically -- and it's worth discussing because it's 70% of our business -- is really the goals that are set by the utility commissions. They're not buying penetration, what they're buying is gigawatt hours. And so on a per-utility basis we work with them and their portfolio manager, their efficiency portfolio manager, to figure out how big of an allocation we can get. And then we sell that, and we do that year in and year out.

I'll stop there.

GREG DUNHAM: Well, one of the examples was the Maryland utility that you announced earlier this year that moved up their penetration rate dramatically.

DANIEL YATES: That's right.

GREG DUNHAM: And so you have some data points.

DANIEL YATES: We've had a big efficiency expansion every quarter last year. So we had ComEd in Q1, we had PepCo in Q2, we had a big EE deal in Q3 that -- the utility hasn't been named. We'll be announcing another one in Q4, and we expect to see the same trajectory through 2015. And we're actually now excited to say we're getting -- we're starting to sign some efficiency deals overseas, too. So we'll be announcing some of those.

So that business is thriving and we have a lot of up side there.

GREG DUNHAM: And I want to ask Thomas a question, but before we get to that, one of the questions that we've gotten with Opowerand the falling oil prices -- and even natural gas has been volatile, too. How does that affect you? How does that affect the energy mandates? And help investors understand your --

DANIEL YATES: It's just a misunderstanding. Oil comprises less than 1% of the fuel for generating energy in the US. It's just a no-op. It has no impact on our business.

GREG DUNHAM: And what about natural gas?

DANIEL YATES: Natural gas prices came down something like three years ago now and it had also, effectively, no impact on our business. And we've been playing in that market, in that environment.

GREG DUNHAM: Okay. Switching gears a little bit, the other question I get is, what's the business model? You actually have a very recurring revenue business. Talk to me -- when you do contract with utilities, how is it typically structured? What's the invoicing cycle?

Because one of the points of confusion from some investors is, well, should I look at billing at the leading indicator on the business? What's the metric that I should look at to judge how growth is progressing?

THOMAS KRAMER, CFO, OPOWER INC.: That's an excellent point. Also going back to what Dan just said, the $300 million, which is the opportunity per year, is an incremental opportunity. Because when we sell it once, we go back and get the same revenue the next year on a subscription basis. Which means that there really is a lot of room for us to grow.

And the way we grow is that we will go to a utility and sell them in a pilot. A pilot is typically 20,000 to 50,000 households; get around $0.5 million on that first year. Once we have shown that this works, we will go back and sell them additional households on the energy efficiency solution, and we'll also extend the contract for several years.

Our average contract is about 24 months in length and about $1 million in size. And so this is very important for us because we know -- we have very good visibility into our future revenue, which is also -- when we announce guidance we know, to a very strong degree, where we're going to end up. We have about 87% 12-month forward visibility, which is exceedingly high.

And then, when it comes to -- what you should look at billing and invoicing is, it is different to sell $10 million deals and $7,000 deals. If you sell a small ticket item the terms are very standard deal to deal, and you have enough of it and it will average out.

We sell large contracts, and when we go in and we talk to the utilities, we agree on a price and we also agree on billing terms, and they will differ from contract to contract. Which means that you will have lumpiness, not just in our bookings but also in our billings.

So when you look at, for instance, the largest deal we sold in Q1 was billed partially in Q1 and then again in Q2. Now, the largest deal we sold in Q2, we actually billed first in Q2 and then it skipped a quarter and it billed again in Q4.

And so what you will see is that in normal smaller ticket item sales, you will just have a very flat billings curve. But we will have situations where you will see that we will have a large billings quarter and then we will have a quarter that isn't large. And so if you looked at our Q3, for instance, you would have seen a drop in billings and in deferred. And what we said was, this is completely -- actually every earnings call we've had, we've said, don't look at our deferred because you will see variability.

And you saw it in Q3 -- we also announced it's going to come back up to normal. And it will. And in the future it will also have another dip, and it will come back.

GREG DUNHAM: Okay; helpful. What do you typically see on renewal from a pricing perspective? We talked about this expansion -- how about a like-for-like pricing dynamic to date?

DANIEL YATES: We've seen -- like solid price, the ability to maintain price solidly writ large. And that's increasingly important with our increasingly largest customers. And what's driving it is actually a lot of the stuff that I just described; we're giving them more and more value. And then, what we're actually seeing in essentially every one of those conversations is additional expansion.

I was just walking through -- we have a slide from our IPO deck that we had three large clients and showed their history of expansion, where they were all starting at $0.5 million or down -- between $200,000 and $2 million four years ago. At the IPO, we were showing they had expanded to between $6 million and $12 million. A year later now -- these are some of our largest customers -- each of those have expanded again, and the $12 million one is up at $16 million per year. So these are, like $50 million, $60 million deals. The $10 million one's at $12.8 million. The $6.2 million one's gone up to $7 million. So we're not just renewing, we're renewing and increasing.

THOMAS KRAMER: When I walk into renewal discussions, I like to walk out of there with more money than I walked in with. And we're doing that with all of our customers, pretty much.

GREG DUNHAM: The other dynamic that was kind of noteworthy in 2014 was you ramped up your sales capacity investment. Can you talk about why? And what's the timing of when those reps are going to actually drive bookings? And where are you targeting some of those capacity investments?

DANIEL YATES: Yes. We had 20 reps at the beginning of 2014 and we targeted 37 reps for the end of the year. In Q3, really, where we last reported, we were on track and it's been a smooth process to get great reps on the team.

It takes about 18 months from the time you hire a rep till you start to see billings from that rep. And that's aggressive because it takes them months to ramp up and just get up to speed. Then we have a long sales cycle and then it takes, on average, between three and nine months to implement depending on the complexity of a project. So reps you hire mid-2014 are going to be delivering you billings in 2016.

That has been going very well. The quality of the reps and our ability to train them -- we invested a ton in sales support and in sales training, and I feel really good about and proud of the quality of the team that we've hired.

Where we've hired them -- I think -- we were talking about this earlier today. I think about 25% of our reps now are international. So there has been I think about 10 quota-carrying reps overseas. We have also added heads; obviously the balance in the US, or in North America.

GREG DUNHAM: I do want to open up to questions from the audience. If you have a question, feel free to raise your hand. Why don't we go right there?

Questions and Answers

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Yes, thanks for taking the question. As I look at your customer base, the majority of it's investor-owned utilities who are principally monopolies. So obviously there's sort of aesthetic benefits to having efficiency measures in place, but a lot of these guys have a lot of influence over the rate base. What real economic motivation do they really have to put in these efficiency measures? Because really, they want to sell more kilowatt hours, not less, at a higher price, not lower.

DANIEL YATES: Yes. So specifically with motivating energy efficiency, there's a 50-year history now of this regulatory construct where utilities are mandated and incentivized to deliver energy efficiency programs. And it's, again, about $6 billion in the US each year that is spent on energy efficiency.

The way it works is the utilities are given goals to hit and then the goals are funded by a tax on the utility bill. And then the utilities run these programs, and then they automatically as a calculation recoup their lost earnings from those programs. So they are made whole.

There are a few rare exceptions where they aren't, but in almost every case, and in every large efficiency market, utilities do not lose earnings from running these programs.

In many of them, like in Massachusetts and California, etc., they actually earn a preferred rate of return. Michigan, Minnesota. And these utilities covet these programs, in fact, because they get substantially higher rate of return on their efficiency quote, unquote investment than they would on building a new power plant. And this has been going for a long time. We've had nothing to do with it; we've just been a beneficiary of it.

At the same time, it is a mandated market. So the CEO of First Energy doesn't wake up in the morning and try and run around to drive up the efficiency market size. But it has happened to him and he is compliant. And that is a much bigger game that's happened on a scale that we don't play with and we deliver against it.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: They become more efficient but then they end up capturing back the profits lost anyways to do with rate case. So in the end, does the greater whole end up with the more efficient?

DANIEL YATES: Yes. Because the key thing is 90% of the spend is fuel costs, and those go away. So that's the thing that comes out of the -- that's what disappears and allows for savings and earnings.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Thanks. What percentage of business is IOU versus co-ops or munis? Do you know?

DANIEL YATES: I don't know the exact number, but the significant majority of our business is IOUs.

GREG DUNHAM: When you think about the cost to roll out your programs versus some of these other alternatives, how do you position -- a software versus hardware? And the decision for that utility.

DANIEL YATES: Yes, I think that's actually -- the way to think about the efficiency part of the business is this is a fact of life for these utilities. And while on the margins there are some places where efficiency is increasing, and there have been rare exceptions where it has decreased, for the most part it's a status quo component of being in the utility business.

So consequently their attention goes to, well, what do I pick? And we afford a very compelling option for utilities to meet their efficiency goals. First of all, we are very cost-competitive. So from a pure achieving their goals perspective, the only program in the residential sector typically that outperforms us are compact fluorescent light bulb subsidies, and those have already seen their heyday. So there's been increasing space for us.

Secondly, we're one of the few programs -- actually, we're the only program that affords the utility any ancillary benefits. So we give them customer sat improvements. We give them the ability to cross-promote other programs and other non-utility programs. And we even give them cost to serve benefits.

And as we're now entrenching more deeply into the core operating offerings of the utilities and looking at things like billing and outage, we're finding very compelling synergies. Inserting energy efficiency features on a bill is actually one of the most cost-effective ways to deliver efficiency, and it helps to -- simultaneously the utility benefits with a better bill.

So given that there's all this efficiency out there, we are well and increasingly well positioned to be the company they want to spend the money on.

GREG DUNHAM: Is the opportunity internationally much different than the opportunity in the US, and can you talk about which regions you make them your best and lessons learned at 18 months.

DANIEL YATES: So there are big differences. I'd highlight a couple. One is a larger part of the non-US market is competitive markets. And there their No. 1 focus is on churn reduction, reduction in their customer churn, or customer retention. And consequently they're very focused on customer satisfaction and self-service, etc.

The second difference is that the efficiency markets are less mature. So both point in the same direction, which is they are an accelerant for us to sell our customer engagement solution overseas, which is where we now focus almost all of our energy.

It also is -- what I'm very excited about as we start to roll out these new products, and the one we'd launch next week, in particular, is going to be very hot internationally because it just speaks to these problems and helps the utility offer a stickier, better service to their customers.

GREG DUNHAM: And what -- do you have a question?

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (Inaudible - microphone inaccessible)

DANIEL YATES: Does our data give us benefit for the next incremental customer? Yes, significantly. And the ways in which it helps us is -- it's a similar dynamic in each product we roll out.

So with energy efficiency, we have become tremendously more efficient at achieving the efficiency, which has enabled us to not reduce our per-unit pricing and to help our customers identify the lowest-hanging fruit in the right order.

And that's entirely on account of our forecast. We have this multivariate predictive model that uses a host of different demographic and geographic weather-based and energy usage data feeds to identify which sub-population will be most receptive to our communications.

We have then begun to develop that same model for demand response. And we are now building

the same capabilities around cost to serve. So we're beginning to identify which customers are most responsive to which kinds of services and which kinds of subscriptions for our new offerings.

And this stuff is -- there's a high noise-to-signal ratio here. So having large populations where we can run concurrent tests gives us a huge advantage.

I'll give you one specific -- the longest-running stuff on the efficiency stuff -- we've been able to achieve 30% better per-unit results in efficiency based upon the forecast model and the program designs that emerge from it.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (Inaudible - microphone inaccessible)

DANIEL YATES: Yes. So that doesn't affect us because we've never been taking a -- the whole challenge there is utilities saying, and power (inaudible) saying, we love ER but we want to do it. And that's our go-to-market is through them. So we've never been interested in a third party approach.

GREG DUNHAM: When you look at your interactions with consumers, how much of it is digital today and how has that evolved over the years? And what does that mean for margins?

DANIEL YATES: Yes. So two years ago was the first year that we had more digital touch points than paper touch points because our odd history -- we started off, first product, paper mailed report. This last year, two-thirds of our touch points were digital. So we continue to very quickly accelerate, grow, the non-paper part of the business.

And that's going to be -- that's not going to stop. And Thomas can talk --

THOMAS KRAMER: Yes, the impact of that, obviously, is that as paper goes away, our costs go up, which will have an upward pressure on the gross margin in the long term. In the immediate term what we will see is that the gross margin will actually vary based on us entering new markets where the investment costs are higher.

But that will actually be recognized immediately and as we are fully scaled into the market, and as we go over to more and more renewals, costs will go down and you should see an increased gross margin where we have a target model of 68% to 72%. We've already touched upon the lower end of that and we feel confident that we can reach that.

GREG DUNHAM: And who else is going after this opportunity in this way? And what are going to be the challenges for them to kind of -- if you buy into, hey, utilities totally need to change the way they interact with consumers because having all this data on their consumers, whether it's smart meters, whether it's billing information, all these metrics is going to demand that they have software solutions that take advantage of the data.

Who else is going after this opportunity and why is Opowergoing to win?

DANIEL YATES: So nobody's where we are today and it doesn't appear to me that there are any [BCs] funding companies in this space anymore. And I think they're probably right not to do so. We have a clear leadership position in the market. We have nearly 100 referenceable customers. We have many of the largest ones. We have an eight-year track record of results.

In these parts of the business that we work in, you cannot have that good of results until you put in the years generating the results. We have a data asset where we have 40% of all US energy data in our system today, 400 billion rows and counting of smart meter data.

And we have this big tech platform. The tech platform is giving us -- is the latest thing that's really giving us accelerating advantage. Because so much of the costs that utilities spend in this part of their business are systems integration costs to tie together crummy horizontal solutions to try to approximate something like what we can deliver for them.

I'll give you an example of a utility in the north Midwest who is spending $25 million on a digital customer experience project, and all they're getting out of it is a horizontal CMS that they're going to use for their website kind of management system. A rudimentary outage communication app from a small company, like a 20-person company. And a horizontal payment processing app, Paymentus, that they're then going to tie together to try and offer a small subset of what we could bring to them over time.

And they're paying $25 million for this because of all the system integration costs. So when you look at that and you look at what we can now because we have so many of these pieces and we're going to have even more put together, it's just -- it gives us a really significant lead over anybody else who's going to try and come in.

Even if they have a great point solution, it's just not -- besides the point.

GREG DUNHAM: Well Dan, on that note we'll close there. Thank you so much Thomas, thank you so much.

DANIEL YATES: Greg, thanks a lot. Thanks everybody.

Data law to allow govt to strike treaties wherein cos could store data overseas: MeitY official

Opposition to India's data localisation move from overseas companies may go down once a globally accepted framework of taxing big technology and digital companies comes into place, a senior IT ministry official has said.

Gopalakrishnan S, joint secretary in the Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology, told the India Mobile Congress on Wednesday that he was referring to a recent proposal by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) to expand government rights to tax multinationals, especially big internet firms, by releasing a methodology for such taxation.

The official said that according to the draft Personal Data Protection (PDP) Bill, the law would only set up the framework regarding necessarily localising 'critical data' only in India without a copy of it being elsewhere.

But “there will be a lag between the coming of the law and the implementation since the regulator would then work out the nitty-gritty of what comprises critical data and thus needs to be stored only in the country,” he said, adding that the entire process would take all the stakeholders into consideration.

The officer further clarified that even then, the law would allow the Indian government in the meanwhile to strike bilateral data treaties with other countries wherein companies from the partner countries could even store the critical data overseas.

Gopalakrishnan was chairing a session on Data Localisation and Global India. His comments came during a panel discussion on how some big technology giants were opposed to the Indian government's proposed data localisation rules as outlined in the draft PDP bill, which the senior government official said, could soon be tabled in the Parliament.

Speaking on the opposition from big technology firms on proposed Indian laws around privacy and security, Gopalakrishnan said, “The global tech companies have so far operated in a regime without specific privacy laws in the US but are now facing a situation where there are six states that have come out with privacy laws and a federal privacy law is expected. Under such circumstances, legislation of a privacy law in India should not come as a surprise or a shock to them.”

The discussion comes at a time when the draft of the data privacy bill has been firmed up and the government is now working on how to treat non-personalised data.

urn:contentItem:5X92-24H1-DXJR-H39R-00000-00'Oppn to Data Localisation may go Down with Global Model to Tax Big Tech Cos'2019-10-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:39ZLexisNexisCOMPANIES: PURSUIT OF PROFIT'Oppn to Data Localisation may go Down with Global Model to Tax Big Tech Cos'Our Bureau

Opposition to India's data localisation move from overseas companies may go down once a globally accepted framework of taxing big technology and digital companies comes into place, a senior IT ministry official has said.

Gopalakrishnan S, joint secretary in the Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology, told the India Mobile Congress on Wednesday that he was referring to a recent proposal by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) to expand government rights to tax multinationals, especially big internet firms, by releasing a methodology for such taxation.

The official said that according to the draft Personal Data Protection (PDP) Bill, the law would only set up the framework regarding necessarily localising 'critical data' only in India without a copy of it being elsewhere.

But “there will be a lag between the coming of the law and the implementation since the regulator would then work out the nitty-gritty of what comprises critical data and thus needs to be stored only in the country,” he said, adding that the entire process would take all the stakeholders into consideration.

The officer further clarified that even then, the law would allow the Indian government in the meanwhile to strike bilateral data treaties with other countries wherein companies from the partner countries could even store the critical data overseas.

Gopalakrishnan was chairing a session on Data Localisation and Global India. His comments came during a panel discussion on how some big technology giants were opposed to the Indian government's proposed data localisation rules as outlined in the draft PDP bill, which the senior government official said, could soon be tabled in Parliament.

urn:contentItem:60P8-R641-DYT4-K2HY-00000-00Opportunity in volatility2020-08-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:39ZLexisNexisECONOMY, BUSINESS & FINANCEPg. 22Opportunity in volatilityPedro van Gaalen

Opportunity in volatility

EM economies offer attractive long-term growth prospects, writes

Covid-19 relief efforts have worsened SA's fiscal position. The government has increased sovereign debt levels to fund its response, while stringent lockdown regulations have eroded tax revenue.

The resultant funding shortfall, coupled with SA's legacy structural challenges, will likely dampen the pace of the country's economic recovery. The rationale for local investors to boost offshore allocations and build globalised portfolios is more compelling than ever.

However, differences in country-specific pandemic responses mean that the global economic recovery will not be uniform. Particular sectors will also benefit more than others.

Accordingly, offshore investors who apply a geographic and thematic lens to their investment decisions stand to benefit from more robust recoveries.

& North Asia has experienced a stronger recovery and has suppressed the virus more successfully than other regions. In the absence of a meaningful second wave, this gives North Asia a head start, which makes it more likely that this region will lead a recovery,& says Dorian Carrell, fund manager, multi-asset, at Schroders.

A vaccine will likely change the global dynamic. In this scenario, the US looks well placed, says Carrell, as it has secured more doses of a potential vaccine per capita than other regions.

& Conversely, Europe's swiftly implemented employment furlough schemes left the region less vulnerable to economic scarring and will likely provide a boost should a vaccine become widely available.& Hein Klee, head of international at Nedbank Private Wealth, adds that the EU's commitment to a €750bn stimulus package will support the region's recovery.

& The US is looking more vulnerable, which is starting to reflect in a weakening dollar.& Diversification across sectors and geographies remains prudent.

& We think that global emerging markets [EM] are attractive, with their low valuations and 'cheap' currencies. While specific EM economies have their issues, with some more pronounced than others, as a collective, they offer the best long-term growth prospects,& says Klee.

Regionally speaking, Klee says it is hard to ignore Asia, with China at its centre. & However, it is important to gain broad EM exposure, rather than trying to pick which region will perform best.& Pieter Koekemoer, head of personal investments at Coronation Fund Managers, highlights sector-specific EM opportunities.

& The biggest concern is that the big five tech stocks did all the running in the strong US and China equity market recovery. In this narrow market, the Faang stocks [Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Alphabet, Google's parent company] grew by more than 70% while the overall market is flat.& Koekemoer believes that investors should be circumspect in how they allocate their offshore investments.

& All the good things driving these tech stocks are known and already reflected in their prices. It becomes debatable whether investors can expect that performance to continue.& But not all global tech stocks are overbought. With strong fundamentals driving the technology theme, such as the e-commerce boom and the shift to working from home, Koekemoer sees attractive opportunities in selective big tech assets in Asian EMs such as China, India and Russia.

& In China, equivalent big tech and media companies to US peers are more attractively valued and are well positioned to benefit from these trends. That is why we hold more EM exposure than normal, but these positions are stock-specific and often in niche tech.& Outside of tech stocks, Koekemoer suggests investors identify strong cyclical businesses hit by the pandemic.

& It's hard to predict how the recovery will unfold, which makes picking individual winners and losers a tough proposition. For instance, we believe the travel sector offers a strong recovery play. However, we prefer Airbus, rather than specific airlines. As one half of the long-haul plane duopoly, Airbus is further up the value chain and more likely to benefit from a broad sector recovery.& But investors shouldn't discount the opportunities that exist in volatility, says Daniel Kibel, founder of CM Trading.

For instance, the recovery in a country such as Brazil, which entered the crisis with a more compromised economy, will likely take longer.

& Conventional wisdom says that in a crisis, investors should put their money somewhere safe. That's why bankable investments like Google, Alphabet, Tesla and Amazon continue to rise.& But Kibel says investors who make the biggest returns are those who take the biggest risks. & Numerous serious investors are considering EMs like Brazil and other riskier options, perhaps not right now but certainly in the future.&

urn:contentItem:5W7X-GYB1-F03R-N00D-00000-00Opportunity Zones: A Technocrat Deception To Plunder America2019-06-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:39ZLexisNexisOpportunity Zones: A Technocrat Deception To Plunder AmericaActivist Post

Jun 02, 2019( Activist Post: http://www.activistpost.com Delivered by Newstex)   https://www.activistpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/technocracy-1024x576-1-1024x576.jpgBy Patrick Wood[1] How much more financial plundering can Americans endure before America is declared an outright Oligarchy and the middle class declared dead? The Trump Administration has aggressively teamed up with Big Tech billionaires to diversify their fortunes into 'underserved areas' by allowing tax deferment on realized capital gains derived from liquidation of their core investments. This is a massive Public-Private Partnership operation that could push as much as $6 trillion of 'unlocked capital' into areas that would be turned upside down, and worse, inundated with Smart City technology designed to create a data extraction extravaganza for years to come.

In short, this is an operation of Big Tech, for Big Tech and by Big Tech, but President Trump has aided and abetted their efforts to manipulate government rules for their own self-interest. Undesired consequences will most certainly follow. IntroductionWhen President Trump signed the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 in December 2017, few read or understood the small print authorizing the creation of Opportunity Zones. One year later on December 12, 2018, Trump created and signed an Executive Order titled, Executive Order on Establishing the White House Opportunity and Revitalization Council[2], which created a highest-level committee that includes the very top leadership of the Administration: the Secretaries of the Treasury, Agriculture, Interior, Commerce, Labor, Health and Human Services, Transportation, Energy and Education; the Administrators of the EPA and the Small Business Administration; the Chairmen of the Council of Economic Advisers and the Council on Environmental Quality and a few other assorted big-wigs. https://www.activistpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/poverty-map-usa-777x437.jpg The EO instructs the Council to 'work across agencies' to 'assess the actions each agency can take under existing authorities to prioritize or focus Federal investments and programs on urban and economically distressed communities, including qualified Opportunity Zones.' The object is to 'minimize all regulatory and administrative costs and burdens.' Furthermore, the EO uses the phrase 'public and private investment' no less than six times and then stresses that the Council must evaluate, whether and how Federal technical assistance, planning, financing tools, and implementation strategies can be coordinated across agencies to assist communities in addressing economic problems, engaging in comprehensive planning, and advancing regional collaboration. There are three immediate problems with this Executive Order. First, Public-Private Partnerships have developed over the years as a mainstay of the United Nations to finance Sustainable Development and in particular, infrastructure that supports its Sustainable Development Goals. Second, blanket cross-agency coordination can be a dangerous vehicle to create policies that represent no agency in particular, and that no single agency would ever create by itself. Third, the term collaboration is a buzzword for collaborative governance that brings many types of stakeholders to the table to make binding decisions outside of traditional citizen representation or accountability. Furthermore, regional collaboration adds an additional dimension that promotes regionalism, which is patently unconstitutional. Article 4, Section 4 of the U.S. Constitution states that 'The United States shall guarantee to every State in this Union a Republican Form of Government.' Regionalism is not a Republican Form of Government, period.The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017Opportunity Zones were created[3] in Section 13823 of this 131 page bill, the summary of which states: This section authorizes the designation of opportunity zones in low-income communities and provides various tax incentives for investments in the zones. Taxpayers may temporarily defer the recognition of capital gains that are invested in opportunity zones. Investments in opportunity zones or opportunity funds that are held for at least five years are eligible for capital gains tax reductions or exemptions, depending on how long the investment is held. The governor of each state is given authority to define the Opportunity Zones within their state boundaries, which are then submitted to the Department of the Treasury for automatic certification. Zones are supposed to be low income or under-advantaged communities, but several governors have stretched the definition to include prime development areas as well. Thus far, over 8,700 of these Zones have been established nationwide. (An interactive map can be seen here[4] and the IRS Q...age is here[5].) Obviously, this is no small undertaking. According to Smart Growth America[6], currently designated OZs represent 10 percent of America's landmass, containing 30 million people. It adds[7], The newly created Opportunity Zones program will likely go down as the largest and most significant federal community development initiative in U.S. history, with trillions of dollars in new private investment about to start flowing into pre-designated low-income communities around the country. It is noteworthy that one survey[8] of state Opportunity Zone designation procedures revealed that less than 10 percent of states published their draft selections for public comment and only one-quarter of states formed a citizen advisory panel. Thus, the public has been largely left in the dark. The IRS issued its first set of rules in early 2018 with little fanfare or public interest. However, when the second set of rules were released in October 2018, the barn doors were thrown open and the free-for-all began. The New Orleans Advocate noted on May 19 that 'It's like the Wild West out there now'. The article elaborated: It's not only the last-minute rules-setting that has given the Opportunity Zone scheme a sense of anarchy: Literally anyone can set up a qualifying OZ fund, and there is no formal way yet for the government to track them and determine if they're directing investment to truly deprived areas as intended.The Economic Innovation GroupThe brains and lobby effort behind the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 is now known to be The Economic Innovation Group (EIG[9]), which, by its own admission, was the original creator of the Opportunity Zone concept in a 2015 paper titled Unlocking Private Capital to Facilitate Economic Growth in Distressed Areas[10]. EIG boasts that 'the idea has since been championed by a wide-ranging coalition of investors, entrepreneurs, community developers, economists, and other stakeholders.' Subsequently, Sen. Cory Booker (D-NJ) and Sen. Tim Scott (R-SC) introduced Senate bill S.293, the Investing in Opportunity Act into the 115th Congress on February 2, 2017. Matching legislation was introduced in the House by Rep. Patrick Tiberi (R-OH). While both bills were stuck in committee, the key provisions were slipped into the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 which was passed and then signed into law by President Trump. Such a skillful, persistent and successful lobbyist effort begs the question, 'Who are these people, anyway?' I'm glad you asked. The Founder and Executive Chairman of EIG is Sean Parker, a well-known black-hat hacker in his youth who co-founded Napster at age 18 to illegally share copyrighted music for free, without authorization from the creators. At age 25, Parker joined Mark Zuckerberg in 2004 when Facebook was only 5 months old, and became its first President shortly thereafter. Parker is credited with convincing Zuckerberg that Facebook could one day be something 'really big'. Forbes Magazine lists Parker as a venture capital investor and philanthropist. Other members of EIG's Founders Circle include: Ted Ullyot - General Council of Facebook from 2008 to 2013 Ron Conway - Founder of SV Angel and included in 2010's Vanity Fair 100 most influential people in the Information Age Dan Gilbert - Founder and Chairman of Quicken Loans, Inc. And a leading venture capitalist specializing in technology companies Rebecca Lynn - Ranked #23 out of 100 top tech investors on Forbes 2015 Midas List Joseph Sanberg - Private and public-sector entrepreneur and investor; he is a board member of the Sierra Club Foundation Dana Settle - Former investment banker at Lehman Brothers, she is a leading venture capitalist specializing in high-tech startups. In short, every one of these people are key players in the Big Tech/venture capital world, especially on the West Coast. Furthermore, they have close connections with some top economists who are listed on their Economic Advisory Board[11]: Jared Bernstein, PhD - Chief Economist and Economic Adviser to Vice President Joe Biden, executive director of the White House Task Force on the Middle Class, and a member of President Obama's economic team. Austan Goolsbee - Former chairman of President Barack Obama's Council of Economic Advisers, cabinet member and chief economist for the President's Economic Recovery Advisory Board Kenneth Rogoff - Former Chief Economist at the International Monetary Fund Matthew Slaughter, PhD - Professor of International Business at Dartmouth, Senior Fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, advisory committee member of the Export-Import Bank of the United States and advisor to the McKinsey Global Institute. The EIG Policy Council generally follows the same lines as the Founders Circle but for this discussion, it has one noteworthy member: Chris Camacho of Phoenix, Arizona. Camacho is President and CEO of the Greater Phoenix Economic Council (GPEC), which he has used to spearhead a public-private partnership called Smart Region Initiative (SRI). This is a three-way collaboration between Arizona State University[12], GPEC[13] and the managing partner Arizona Institute for Digital Progress[14]. Camacho is a hard-nosed business development expert and an unequalled promoter of unconstitutional regionalism. One Phoenix journal reported[15] Camacho as saying, No one market across the country has unified multiple jurisdictions. There's been strategies to do smart cities in various places, but we're talking about, 'how do we connect the entire region.' Indeed, the Smart Region Initiative is being billed as the very first national attempt to create a regional authority to implement uniform smart city technology across 22 cities and 4.2 million people. National and even global eyes are watching to see what happens next in the Valley of the Sun, and if this regionalism takeover is successful here, it will be used as a model for similar public-private partnerships all across across America and around the world. While this writer intends to thoroughly cover the Smart Region Initiative movement in a separate report, it is important to see the potential connection between Opportunity Zones and Smart Region Initiatives. Both are full of venture capitalists specializing in Big Tech initiatives like the Internet of Things, Smart City surveillance technology and most importantly, data, which many are calling the 'new oil' of the 21st century. Both are new, riddled with Public-Private Partnerships and promote similar unconstitutional practices.The Counter-ArgumentSome will undoubtedly argue that these billionaires and venture capitalists are simply acting as benevolent benefactors who are sharing their wealth with poor communities; or that they are merely seeking to diversify their investments. This is a logical absurdity and terribly naive. For high-velocity money extracted from Big Tech, there is no return on buying real estate or starting businesses in poor communities. Investors always put their capital into the areas of highest possible returns. On the other hand, if data collection is the target, which is high-return, then Opportunity Zones fit the bill perfectly.Who will manage the OZ Funds?For the most part, every Opportunity Zone Fund will typically have a managing partner that makes all decisions for investment, structuring and accounting. Investors will simply pick a fund or fund manager in which to invest. Who are these fund managers? One needs to look no further than EIG's Opportunity Zones Coalition[16] page to get the idea: This page lists 49 such would-be managers with names like Reinvestment Fund, Riaz Capital, Newark Venture Partners, Ur Opportunity, KeyBank, Institute for Portfolio Alternatives, Fund for Our Economic Future, Calvert Impact Capital, Bridge Investment Group, etc. Some of these will very likely end up with tens of billions under their direct management.Case Study: How Erie, PA Uses Opportunity Zones To Fund Its Smart City MakeoverOn March 4, 2019, Government Technology reported[17] that Erie, Pa., Wants to Overlay Security Tech into Its Smart City. The article states, Eight 'opportunity zones' throughout the city could soon see new smart city technology equipped with license plate-reading cameras and facial recognition capabilities. Officials say the goal is to boost safety and spur investment. Additional security cameras, LED lighting and free public Wi-Fi were introduced to downtown Erie in 2018 as part of a pilot program for what's known as smart city technology. Mayor Joe Schember's administration and other local officials want to bring the same technology to local neighborhoods targeted for reinvestment under the federal Opportunity Zone program. Schember, in an interview last week, said his administration — working with the Erie Innovation District and others — is working to bring 'secure smart city' equipment and technology over the next 12 months to the eight Opportunity Zones in the Erie region that have been designated by Gov. Tom Wolf's office and certified by the U.S. Treasury Department. According to Schember, that would include security cameras that could read license plates and have facial-recognition capabilities; energy-efficient LED street lights; and free Wi-Fi in public spaces throughout the Opportunity Zone tracts. The intent is to make those areas safer and more attractive for investment. 'It's kind of an aggressive goal. But let's get these areas done and within the next three years, I'd like to see that technology throughout the entire city,' Schember said.Needless to say, Erie got the message of how Opportunity Zones could best serve its pressing need to get someone else to pay for its Smart City makeover. Once a beachhead is established in a lower-income area, which can hardly protest anything the city does, rolling out to the rest of the city will be a cake-walk. Furthermore, the early city 'partners' (tech providers and investors) will have their foot in the door and will be eager participants. But, why would anyone be eager to pour money into low income or underserved areas? There are three good reasons. First and foremost, the value of data collection is found in all living human beings, regardless of their socio-economic status. Second, the early-bird gets the worm for the rest of the data plundering operation in other parts of the city or region. Third, once embedded, the data stream continues to pump into the coffers of those who 'own' the collection infrastructure.ConclusionIt's time to face the dark reality of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017. The promised tax cut for individuals was largely a myth. Conversely, tax cuts for the wealthy and corporations were ostentatious. A just-released report[18] by the Congressional Research Service confirms this: 'the main consequence was that real tax rates for corporations fell by nearly half while individual income taxes barely budged.' The key sentence in the report states,From 2017 to 2018, the estimated average corporate tax rate fell from 23.4% to 12.1% and individual income taxes as a percentage of personal income fell slightly from 9.6% to 9.2%.Thus, a Republican-led Congress betrayed the American people, and President Trump offered no rebuke to get it right. Instead, he eagerly signed the Jobs Act into law and subsequently created an Executive Order to insure the streamlining of its provisions throughout all levels of government agencies. It should be duly noted and with alarm that this kind of globalization transcends the ideological labels of Republican or Democrat, liberal or conservative, left-wing or right-wing, etc. Technocrats are apolitical on one hand, but will use or manipulate any convenient political platform to advance their own goals. urn:contentItem:5X95-44G1-DXMP-K47N-00000-00Opposition to data localisation may reduce after taxation framework for internet companies come into place: MEITY's S. Gopalakrishnan2019-10-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:39ZLexisNexisOpposition to data localisation may reduce after taxation framework for internet companies come into place: MEITY's S. GopalakrishnanNishtha Vishwakarma

Opposition by foreign companies to India's data localisation move may come down once a globally accepted framework of taxing digital companies comes into place, according to S. Gopalakrishnan, joint secretary to the IT Ministry. He was referring to a recent proposal (https://www.ft.com/content/b16fd228-ea72-11e9-a240-3b065ef5fc55) by the Organisation of Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) to expand the governments' rights to tax MNCs - especially big internet firms such as Google and Facebook - by releasing a methodology for such taxation.

Gopalakrishnan was speaking at a panel discussion on 'Data Localisation and Global India' at the India Mobile Congress 2019. He also said that the draft Personal Data Protection Bill is very likely to be tabled in the upcoming Winter Session of the Parliament.

Data embassies/zones to manage Indian data

The government may think about creating data zones/embassies in other countries to manage Indian data outside of India, Gopalakrishnan said. He further noted that the draft PDP bill requires a framework for localising critical data, and "not the trivial non-personal data".

"There is a lag between the coming of the law and the implementation since the regulator would then work out the nitty-gritty of what comprises critical data and thus needs to be stored only in the country", he said, adding that the entire process would take all the stakeholder views into consideration.

US is framing privacy laws, so India's law shouldn't come as a shock

Speaking on opposition by big tech firms on the draft Personal Data Protection Bill, Gopalakrishnan said, "the global tech companies have so far operated in a regime without specific privacy laws in the US but are now facing a situation where there are six states [in the US] have come out with privacy laws and [a] federal privacy law is expected."

Under such circumstances, the legislation of privacy law in India should not come as a surprise or a shock to them". He also said that the biggest beneficiaries of the data localisation in India will be the "citizens of the country", as this will protect their data from being misused.

urn:contentItem:4KCH-1S70-TXFC-X2J6-00000-00Option expensing creating confusion among employees2006-10-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:39ZLexisNexisTOP OF THE NEWSPg. 5Option expensing creating confusion among employeesCynthia Harrington

While Congress and the Financial Accounting Standard Board churn over accounting standards regarding stock options, employees are left wondering about their financial lives.

Some Fortune 500 companies like Coca-Cola and The Washington Post have already made the move to voluntary expensing, as has Bank One. The question is whether the proposed change would do away with this type of compensation or not.

Despite the fact that the headlines are full of stock option expense fever, the long-term implications for executive clients may not be so onerous. However, expensing options might cause such a drag on the profitability of some companies that the lower stock prices greatly reduce the attractiveness of options as a form of compensation.

If all companies must expense options, the impact on employees at old-line companies, like those mentioned above, would not be as great as at smaller companies. New companies without much cash depend on stock options to reward employees, and loudly claim that if they are required to expense the options they will no longer be able to afford them.

CPA Michael Gray's San Jose, Calif., office is in the heart of a start-up capital of the world. "Stock forms of compensation have been important in my area," he said. "In the recent tech heyday, even the secretary at the front desk received stock options."

Not only are options a critical source of compensation for smaller companies, but, when counted as an expense, they are a larger drag on earnings. Big tech companies like Cisco and Inteldisclose the potential option expense in the required footnotes. Cisco's earnings would drop by $1.21 billion, or 28 percent, if the accounting standards change; Intel's would drop by $991 million, or 16 percent. "Even some of the big winners from the tech boom may well have not had any earnings at all if they had had to record expenses related to options," Gray said.

As the impact would be less for big companies than for small, the expensing requirement will affect executives less than other employees. "Even start-ups are still going to do whatever it takes to attract talent," said Gray. "But it's less likely that options will be offered to employees outside the key group under the new rules."

From a financial planning perspective, the larger task is often diversifying out of the position of assets concentrated in one stock. Tanager Financial recently raised minimums for new accounts to $2 million, and deals only with the key group of executives that are less likely to be affected by any accounting changes on their employer's income statements. "We look at stock options from the micro view, or how to advise our clients once the awards have been made," said manager Glenn Frank, CPA, PFS, CFP. "From the investor's point of view, the biggest decision is whether to exercise."

Uncertainty surrounding options and the future of the stock price, as well as the tax treatment of the incentive stock options, make the decision difficult. "There's so much misinformation out there that encourages them not to exercise," said Frank. "So many people get paralyzed about their options and do nothing."

Tanager's concept of the financial floor helps their clients pull the trigger. During the planning process, clients work with advisors to determine how much is enough to meet their financial goals. "What's insane is that people's net worth can fluctuate so wildly," said Frank. "Investors need to learn to pull the trigger on what is enough."

The tax treatment of incentive stock options adds to the paralysis on the part of many clients. When exercised, the option becomes a preference item and investors must pay up to the Internal Revenue Service even if the stock is not sold. The new accounting rules at the employer would not change the personal tax rules, but if expensing options becomes a drag on earnings, stock price volatility could increase.

For investors, price volatility confuses the decision to exercise. "We tell clients it's illogical not to exercise as soon as they can," says Frank. "And while they don't like to hear it, we make the point that even the top executives do not know where the stock price is ultimately going to go."

Frank's goal is to reduce volatility throughout the holdings. "Some of these clients own the options as well as company stock in other plans, on top of having their job tied up in one source," he said. "They question how any new investments might perform, but mathematically a diversified portfolio will be less volatile than a single stock."

When the employer is a small company, however, the volatility could be greatly increased by a move to expensing stock options. "Companies had a free ride using non-qualified options," said Gray. "They could use them to pay for something of value, but they didn't have to record the expense."

In addition to the confusion of company-level accounting changes, the IRS is tinkering with the investor's tax regulations. Specifically troubling Gray is Treasury Decision 9144, which changes the treatment of options exercised before vesting. Some pre-initial public offering companies allow employees to exercise early if the stock issue is imminent. The new ruling does not allow the favorable election under Section 83(b), and investors who sell before a two-year holding period get hit with ordinary income.

Part of Gray's practice is to assist other advisors on the changes in stock option laws through his newsletter, Michael Gray CPA Option Alert, which can be accessed at www.stockoptionadvisors.com.

Big companies can also swallow the ongoing costs of accounting for options, making it easier to continue to reward employees, but the costs may be too high for smaller companies. "Start-ups are hit on several levels, with options accounting as well as Sarbanes-Oxley compliance," said Gray.

Big companies can also swallow the ongoing costs of accounting for options, making it easier to continue to reward employees, but the costs may be too high for smaller companies. "Start-ups are hit on several levels, with options accounting as well as Sarbanes-Oxley compliance," said Gray.
