LARRY ELLISON, EXECUTIVE CHAIRMAN AND CTO, ORACLE CORPORATION: Okay, well, we are approaching $2 billion, I would say. $2 billion. We are the second-largest cloud company on the planet. So I realize that and people say well, it is only 6% of your revenue or something like that, that's -- okay.

We could try to get rid of that other revenue. Then it would be -- the $2 billion would be 100% of our revenue. But the other revenue is quite profitable.

So first of all, let me disagree. The last couple of years, we have been -- we have been. The last couple of years we have been very vocal, but eight -- more -- no, nine and a half years ago, we started rewriting all of our applications.

We -- Fusion ERP. You think we did that in the last two years? We did that in the last nine and a half years. We had to rewrite all of our middleware for the cloud. We had to rewrite big chunks of our database for the cloud. Then we had to rewrite our entire ERP/HCM suite for the cloud.

Now if you think we did that in the last two years, hey, we are really good. Because it actually took as nine and half years to do. So we have been working on this for a very long time.

Again, I will go back -- this is a little, you know, me feeling insecure. People said I was a CEO until very recently and I just didn't get the cloud. I started NetSuite. It was the first cloud company. And I don't think I invest -- I wasn't an investor in that suite.

I mean, I put in -- it was my idea. We started it to do small companies, the ERP in the cloud, and we didn't know it was called cloud. In fact, I have ridiculed the name cloud. That is pointless now. It just -- it is the name. People decide to call servers on the Internet, God bless, and we -- the cloud is great. It is a very charismatic name.

But we started working on this thing -- might -- I made a major -- I started NetSuite a year later and made a major investment in salesforce.com. It is not that I didn't notice or think this was a good idea. I thought this was a good idea for a very long time.

For Oracle to move to the cloud is very different than NetSuite building an application for the cloud or Salesforce building an application for the cloud.

When we move to the cloud, we have to move all of our middleware, all of our database, rewrite our entire ERP suite, HCM suite, and CRM suite. That is a lot of work. It takes a long time. It takes a decade. We have been at it for almost a decade.

Now there is no reason for us to be enormously vocal about cloud, cloud, cloud, cloud, cloud when we are in the middle of engineering for the cloud, but not delivering cloud products.

And we started getting aggressive in promoting cloud is the right way to go a couple years ago, because it is when our first cloud product started coming out. And now, two years later, we think we are in a much, much stronger position. To move our middleware business and our database business customers to the cloud just by pushing a button.

Java is an important brand. By the way, Java is not like a dinosaur technology from a dinosaur company. Maybe it is, but Google thought it was important enough to steal. And they are, like, really cool.

So the Android phone is entirely a Java phone. That is our technology. And it is the most popular programming environment in the cloud and on-premise. That is our technology and our brand.

So -- but us moving our enterprise customers to Java in the cloud and re-doing our middleware for the cloud, putting mobile interfaces on all of our middleware -- that is just an enormous job. Making our database multi-tenant. Big job.

But at the same time, making the database handle all of the data in memory. Big job. There was a lot of work to do to move this Company to the cloud. No reason to spend a lot of time talking about it until we actually had products to start to sell. And that was a couple years ago.

So I do think -- I mean, I think this is an inflection point. It was my speech on Sunday. It was my speech again on Tuesday that this is a turning point for the Company. Because now we have the exact same database that we have had out -- we have on-premise.

We have that exact same database capability in the cloud and you can simply move the database by pushing a button. We have never had that before. There are millions of Oracle databases out there.

Now you have a choice -- you can rewrite from MongoDB and rebuild all of your applications or you can push a button. By the way, in the cloud, everyone uses Oracle. 19 of the top 20 SaaS companies use Oracle in the cloud.

Oracle is by far the number one enterprise database and if people want to move to the cloud and get the benefits of the cloud and have lower costs and monthly payments and all these other things and not pay upfront license fees and have us run on our servers on our network, use our storage, do all of that, they can now do that with the push of a button.

It is the same exact database that they have on-premise they can count move to the cloud. That is a big deal. We think that is going to be our biggest cloud business very quickly.

And that is why we are quite confident we will blow by salesforce.com. Because salesforce.com's -- has had no platform competition. What used to be called force.com and now is called Salesforce1 is a highly proprietary programming language that you use for extending and building applications on Salesforce's platform.

Well, we don't have -- it is interesting and I pointed this out before, Salesforce builds on top of our Oracle and our Java. That is how they build applications, but that is not how they encourage their customers to build applications.

We encourage our customers to build on top of the same platform we build build on: Oracle and Java. We encourage our customers to build on the same platform that Salesforce builds on: Oracle and Java. Except you can't get from Salesforce; you can only get it from us.

We encourage our platform -- our customers to build on the same platform that SAP builds and runs on. Ariba runs on Oracle. SuccessFactors runs on Oracle and Concur runs on Oracle. Those are that is their entire cloud story.

They do say Hana powers the cloud, but I don't know what cloud they are talking about. Certainly not theirs. Not ours, not these other 19 guys. And the other -- the one, the one of the top 20 SaaS companies that don't run on Oracle is Workday and they sure don't run on Hana. They run on their own proprietary object database.

And by the way, Workday has no platform. I mean, at least Salesforce has a platform. I think it's -- I think there's a problem that it is not [sanders-based] and it is proprietary and there is only one place in the world you can get that platform. You don't get more closed than Salesforce's platform. Because the only one that sells Salesforce's platform is Salesforce.

Java and the Oracle database are based on hundreds of industry standards. Their stuff is based -- isn't 100% proprietary. So we have what we think will be the most attractive platform in the cloud and that is going to be a very big business for us. So that is, yes, that is an inflection point in and of itself.

We finally got our ERP suite out. The whole thing. The whole thing -- there's a few missing pieces, but the bulk of the ERP suite is out. And we sold more ERP customers in our last quarter. You see no evidence that we are doing okay in cloud.

We sold more ERP customers in our last quarter than Workday has sold since the beginning -- since they started their company. We have totally blown by them in midrange and high-end ERP.

We are selling more HCM systems than Workday right now. And we have had lots of big brand wins against them, against Workday. We are Salesforce's only serious competitor in high-end sales automation.

We are competing and lots and lots of areas of the cloud. Platform, database, Java, I know you have seen a lot -- the fact that our -- that our platform also includes social mobile and this hold big issue of security, where we think we have a huge lead over salesforce.com.

I mean, do I have to sit here and convince you that our platform is more secure than salesforce.com's platform? We have been working on this problem for 30 years.

So we provide, I think, a very attractive platform made up of Java and the Oracle database where customers can migrate to it with the push of a button. No one else has anything like that.

You might look -- does IBM have that? IBM has DB2. Does it -- can you push a button and move your DB2 database to the cloud? Can you? No.

IBM has WebSphere. Can you push a button and move your WebSphere application to the cloud? No. So our primary database competitor, IBM and Enterprise, and our primary database competitor in middleware, IBM WebSphere, has no -- nothing for the cloud.

That is good for us. So we go from competing with IBM in the platform business to competing with salesforce.com with their proprietary platform. I like our chances.

So, yes, now that we are in the platform business, it took us a while to get there. We have a lot of software. When you re-engineered a lot of software, it takes a long time.

But we have the platform in the cloud. We have CRM -- customer experience suites, sometimes called -- used to be called CRM. I have got to get with it. It is now called CX.

HCM suite, ERP suite -- they are all available and they are all quite differentiated. If you look at our user interfaces, everything we have, all of our applications have mobile interfaces. All of our cloud applications, mobile interfaces, because it is built into the platform.

We didn't put multi-tenancy at the application layer like Workday did and Salesforce did with all of the inherent security problems of mixing data. Different customers' data in the same database.

We didn't do that. We gave you secure, separate, pluggable databases. We gave you a multitenant database where all of the security stuff still works.

So it is much harder for Oracle to move its portfolio of platform applications and ERP and CRM. It takes much longer than for a Salesforce to write a single app. It takes us a long time to get there.

But now that we're there, we think we just have huge competitive advantages in saying gee, if you buy ourselves automation application, you can extend it using the Oracle database and Java. The same thing that it is written in.

You have built in in-memory Big Data analytics built in. Because it is built into the platform. Salesforce doesn't have that. Workday doesn't have that.

And we have security because we don't have multi-tenancy. And security is going to become a bigger and bigger deal every year in the cloud. And we have been working on that. As I said, we have been working on that problem for more than 30 years.

So we think it is an inflection point for us. We -- our platform business is basically at a point of zero today. We don't think it is going to be a zero a year from now and certainly not -- it is going to be a big number in a couple years. It is going to be our biggest cloud business.

So it is going to help us sell our SaaS applications, because people don't want -- well. If people can buy sweets, they want to buy sweets. Here is another story. Suite [went] vendors always win.

In the early days of a new technology, a new platform, you get a lot of point applications. This clever point application, that clever point application. Like I concur, it is a very narrow area, travel expenses.

And they put the one application up, but they don't have a platform to go with it. They don't have a suite of applications. In the end, those point application companies never survive. They never survive. It is -- all in the end, it is always one by suite providers.

If you look at the last generation, the two big application companies were SAP, number one, with their ERP suite and us, number two, with our ERP suite. Suite companies always win. The point guys always disappear. They get acquired or they just fail to compete.

Now the suite in the cloud is really interesting, because it is not only is the suite in the cloud, customer experience in HCM and ERP, but to compete in the cloud, there has to be some kind of platform.

There has got to be a way to extend your database. To extend your applications, to enhance your applications. To connect your applications one to another. There has got to be a way to do that.

So you got to offer a platform. Salesforce offered a platform. They've been around for a while. A lot of these guys have no platform. You can't make it without a platform, I don't think.

IBM hasn't started. There -- IBM, no DB2 in the cloud. No WebSphere in the cloud. SAP -- their business isn't -- they are not the giant in expense reporting for travel. There an ERP company. They have no ERP in the cloud, none. Nothing. They haven't started moving their stuff to the cloud yet. Took us 10 years.

Now maybe they are twice as smart as we are. Maybe they can do it in five years. I don't think so. I really don't. So they are 10 years away. I will tell you, we don't even think about them as a competitor anymore or IBM.

We worry about the new generation of cloud companies and we think we just have a huge advantage over those companies, given our breadth of application products and the power of our standards-based platform and the ability to move all of our existing customers' applications and all of our existing customers' databases to the cloud with the push of a button. They spend less, we get paid more. We like that model.

If you ask a nicer question, I will give you a shorter answer. Way in the back.

KASH RANGAN: Hi, Larry. Kash Rangan at Merrill Lynch. Nice question would be the database cycle -- and you've sounded quite bullish on in-memory and multi-tenant. And it harkens back to RAC back in 2003. You talked about how people can save money by using commodity service instead of more expensive ones.

So that was a very obvious cost save for the customer; the cycle worked out quite great. In this cycle, what do you think could be those compelling factors that would allow the customer to see the value so obviously that he can start to see that kind of cycle? Thank you.

LARRY ELLISON: Well, I think everyone is talking about real-time analytics. IBM talks about real-time, real-time. Everyone is talking about Big Data. To way -- the way to process huge amounts of data very, very quickly is to put it in memory.

I mean, Hadoop is a batch system. Again, without going into all the details. We sell Hadoop, we support Hadoop, we connect Hadoop -- we are big Hadoop supporters. But it is basically batch. It is like a big sort -- sort merge project.

In terms of real-time enterprise, real-time Big Data analytics, the way you do that is you put your data in memory. That is not what Hadoop does. Hadoop does something -- what it does, it does quite well. It doesn't do that.

So we think as customers want to analyze large volumes of data, they want to put in a columnar database, compress that data, put it in memory, and be able to query that data very fast. And then build all sorts of dashboard-embedded analytics in their applications, et cetera.

We think that is a huge -- obviously, SAP has been talking about it for -- ever since they have been pushing Hana. And there have been tons of university papers on it before that. I mean, in-memory database has just been something that we as an industry have been working on for a decade.

And, okay, so why did Oracle come out with in-memory database recently? As opposed to -- did SAP really beat us to the market with in-memory database? Well, kind of. But not really. So let me explain.

The -- when we put in-memory into Oracle, the Oracle database, it means that every existing Oracle application has to run in-memory without any changes. We got to have -- there's this business concept of upper compatibility.

We got to take all of our millions of databases and make sure that they work. All of our millions of applications have to be able to work in-memory with the customer not even -- with the customer not changing anything.

Now SAP didn't have that small problem, because they just came up with the first version of their in-memory database, called Hana. Which I don't want to go into, but it's -- I think it is quite a primitive product. But it is a laboratory product. It came out of the labs, it is version 1. Okay. It is a version 1 product. Great.

There are lots of version -- I mean there is a company called -- HP bought somebody called Vertica. They are -- which is a columnar database. This has been around for -- this is not a new idea.

The thing is, when Oracle adopts these things -- Oracle didn't have the first object database, but we have objects in our database right now. We didn't have the first text database, but we have text in our database.

When we do that, we have to put those things in a way that is completely upward compatible and accessible to all of our existing customers. So it is much harder for us, if you will, it is a much bigger challenge for us to build in-memory into our database and not perturb -- and customers push a button, just like moving to the cloud.

You push a button, you go to in-memory. You push a button, you go to the cloud. It is called upward compatibility. And we had been doing it for a very, very long time and we have to do it. And it is part and parcel of the job.

A startup or a lab project that doesn't worry about any of that stuff or doesn't worry about in-memory having to work with RAC, in-memory having to work with Data Guard, in-memory having to have seven levels of security.

I mean, it has to be the real -- it has to do all of those things. We can't regress in any way. We have to be as secure, as fast, and add this new feature where customers just press a button, everything is in-memory, and it runs 100 times faster. It is a much harder job for us than for others. But we do it.

Now how does that benefit customers? Well, here is what the customers have got to decide between: totally rewrite your application for Hana or install the new version of Oracle and it runs 100 times faster. Plus we are a lot faster than Hana. We did a better job.

But that is not that big thing -- whether we are faster in-memory or they are faster in-memory. The fact is those millions of databases and those millions of applications now run in-memory without change. It is just a totally different issue.

So in terms of adoption, which is what you are asking -- in terms of adoption, who doesn't want to press a button and runs 100 times faster? Who doesn't want to press a button and enable Big Data analytics in all of their applications?

We think this will be -- we are already seeing adoption rates. People using this in terms of bringing it in-house, developing stuff, moving staff. We have already seen a very rapid early adoption of in-memory, which is not -- it hasn't been around for that long.

So we think this is going to drive our database business on-premise and as well as driving our database business, our platform business in the cloud, if you look at those two things.

So we think we are on a very good cycle for the database with two major features. Again, I will use the word charismatic again. Two features that have caught people's imagination. To make your existing applications multi-tenant by moving them to Oracle 12c. Make your existing databases run in-memory 100 times faster by moving to Oracle 12c.

What else do I have to do? Nothing. Just upgrade your database. All the applications are multi-tenant and all of your data runs in-memory. That is all you have to do. And we think that means we are going to have a very strong couple of years on-premise, but I would say even more exciting, you are going to see our platform business just take off.

Way in the back, right here.

PHIL WINSLOW, ANALYST, CREDIT SUISSE: Hi, it is Phil Winslow from Credit Suisse. You provided some good historical context that application suites win in the cloud, they won in client/server, they are going to win now in the cloud. What if you put (multiple speakers)

LARRY ELLISON: No, they won in mainframes, they won in client/server, they won in Internet. So we have seen it happen three generations where the suite providers have won. But keep going.

PHIL WINSLOW: But I was hoping you could provide us similar type of historical context, but for the database. And some of the perceived threats that the Oracle database might be facing right now -- NoSQL, Hadoop -- and maybe how the Oracle database managed the previous technology waves like object oriented, XML and maybe just provide some context there.

LARRY ELLISON: I can't. This is -- by the way, this is our 87th and 88th threats to our very existence is NoSQL and Hadoop. And we are kind of dead. I mean -- dead with object databases. We are dead with unstructured data.

I mean, some people spent in excess of $10 billion built -- unstructured. I mean, getting a database to store all of your cat videos. It's -- I mean, unstructured data was going to -- I never give the -- the pitch was un -- most data is unstructured.

And Oracle only handled structured data. And we are going to kill them, because we are going to be the kings of unstructured. And they are kind of screwed, because they just handle structured data.

Well, yes, structured data like banks, and phone companies, phone records, and connecting phone calls, and banks, and the military targeting things, and insurance companies, and all of that structured stuff. Versus unstructured stuff like cat videos, dog videos. Videos. Pictures of your friends; pictures -- your Facebook pictures of what you had for breakfast.

Now the question is -- which -- are the banks going to pay more to keep track of money than consumers are going to pay to keep track of their cat videos. And it turns out banks are still paying more than consumers in terms of monitoring.

Cat videos, you store for nothing. So it turns out that unstructured data versus structured data was not the death knell for us. Either were objects.

Okay, NoSQL. We have a NoSQL database. We had a very -- we bought -- Berkeley DB was the biggest NoSQL database. It wasn't called NoSQL database. It is called a keyvalue payer.

It is called -- let me tell you what it was called. It is usually called ISAM. I think this is -- talk about back to the future. This is 19 -- late 1950s technology. I am not saying it doesn't have value. We have one. We have a NoSQL database. It has value. You don't need to -- you don't need an [opri] or schema.

There are things that it is very good at. And you should use it for, but it has nothing to do with competing with us.

I remember when MySQL was going to kill us. Another relational database was going to wipe us out. I can't -- the death knell for Oracle has sounded so many times, it is hard for me to jump up and run out of the house every time -- in my underwear every time that happens.

The -- now Hadoop. I know what Hadoop is. I actually know what it does. Most people writing about Hadoop -- I am not accusing you of anything -- have no idea what Hadoop even does.

All they know it has got an elephant and it is written kind of by Google and Yahoo, it is open source, and oh, is Oracle is screwed. I mean, it has nothing to do with what we do.

It is a big sort merge. It handles massive amounts of data; it is highly parallelized, MongoDB, and we actually follow all this stuff. It is not a competitive product. It doesn't do the same.

Why do you think 19 out of 20 of the biggest SaaS providers today are running Oracle? You think they are all confused? You think they all -- they couldn't find -- they couldn't download MongoDB? It is just preposterous.

Again, MongoDB is a highly distributed. It does some very interesting things. We have a NoSQL database. We have -- we sell Hadoop. We put SQL in front of Hadoop. We have done a lot of things with Hadoop. Again, it does some things extremely well.

It just is not a product that competes with what we do. It coexists with what we do. And the -- Workday doesn't run on Hadoop. Workday doesn't run on NoSQL. Even the one guy that doesn't run on Oracle, it doesn't run on those things. It doesn't run on Mongo.

It runs on its own proprietary object database, where you can actually build applications and actually do online transaction processing. Which none of these -- well, Mongo kind of does it. But Hadoop certainly doesn't.

Okay so it is just -- they really aren't a threat to what we are doing. They are interesting new technologies -- insofar as we can incorporate those technologies into Oracle, we have done that. Insofar as that -- hey, Hadoop does certain things. Does its -- lots and lots of servers doing basically sort/merge. It is not exactly sort/merge, but what -- it is called MapReduce.

In parallel, process a lot of data and we put the SQL language in front of it or we have very tight coupling to Hadoop for -- so customers can use Hadoop and use Oracle in concert.

This is not something that is -- will take the place of Oracle. It is different. It is a little, I don't know, it is a little bit like saying laptops will take the place of steamships. They won't. I mean, they won't. (laughter). They are too different.

So our big database competitors, we continue to gain database share on-premise and in the cloud and we think now with our platform, we'll be able to amplify that advantage because our biggest competitor, IBM, is not there.

The other -- the interesting -- other competitor that has kind of shown up relatively recently, like us, is Microsoft, which has moved a lot of its stuff to the cloud. And they do have a legitimate relational database that is pretty good and a bunch of -- and platform services.

They have got .NET -- we have Java. We have always kind of -- the world has always kind of self-selected between Oracle and Microsoft in terms of what you want. We have Linux, they have windows, we have Java, they have .NET. We have the Oracle database, they have SQL Server.

But Microsoft has a pretty complete port -- pretty complete platform. It is kind of the other pretty complete platform out there with a lot of applications built on top of it. And they are going to be an interesting competitor going forward.

I think Bill's return to the company, while it hasn't been heralded, has made a very big difference. I mean, I have always had -- I mean, when competing with Bill over the years, always thought he is a very smart guy. And he is. And he is helping a lot over there. Yes, sir?

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Ryan (inaudible - microphone inaccessible) Cantor Fitzgerald. Just a question on the -- a lot of media reports around consolidation in the industry lately. Not small companies, massive companies -- EMC, HP, and a couple of their big IT vendors who were mentioned.

So I would just be curious in getting your view on the IT landscape. Do you think there is going to be more consolidation among these vendors, big vendors? Last year, you talked about cloud consolidation, but where do you see it and how does this impact Oracle?

LARRY ELLISON: Well, I think if your business, or if our -- if we hadn't made some moves to the cloud -- in other words, if we just said, okay, we are never going to offer anything in the cloud. We are just going to keep selling on-premises hardware, keep selling on-premises software. That is what we are going to do and that is all we are ever going to do.

That would be a precarious strategy. I mean, I would not be comfortable with that. I think we can do fine. I don't think on-premise is going away. But I would like to have one foot in on-premise and one foot in the cloud to get some hypergrowth in the cloud. And some decent growth on-premise, so we can grow our profit -- grow our cloud share and grow our profitability at the same time. And we have to grow in both areas, I think.

But if you look at -- oh, EMC is interesting because of VMware. But VMware, while it has done very well with enterprise customers, has -- is not represented in the cloud at all. There are no cloud companies that use VMware.

So that is really an enterprise -- kind of an early enterprise software play. Virtualization was a big deal. They were there first, but as you move to the cloud, Azure doesn't use it. Google doesn't use it, Amazon doesn't use it, we don't use it. We use something called Xen, an open-source VM.

And all the big providers have gone with open source and standards based. And we use a lot of open-source stuff, by the wait, without going into -- it would -- not just Linux, but Xen VM. There's a long list.

Some of us gets us into trouble because there are -- sometimes there are security issues with open source software, but us along with the rest of the community are working very hard to address those issues.

But -- so EMC with VMware and in their storage business, VMware nowhere in the cloud. Their storage business really nowhere in the cloud. I mean, that is not good. So people have said well, they haven't grown Oracle -- but Oracle, your growth hasn't been so great.

If you look at the growth of our software business, it has been pretty good. What has shrunk is our hardware business and our consulting business. But our software business is now in excess of 80 -- what percent is in our business? In the 80%s.

I know it is in the 80%s. I don't know offhand, but I'm guessing 82%, 80 --? Anyone, no one, but it is almost mid80%s.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: 76%, Larry.

LARRY ELLISON: Total? That is what I said, mid-80%s. 76%. Okay. We will have to go back and check her math, but she is the boss now. What can I say? I just move on.

But if you look at our software business, our software business has grown quite well. And our cloud business has gone from nothing a couple years ago to we are the number two player. And I don't think it is -- we are very far away from being the number one player, given the kind of growth we are expecting over the next 24 months in our platform.

But if you are an HP, what is your -- what are you selling? If you are an IBM, what are you selling? If you are EMC, or -- what are you selling? It is what you have always been selling.

And as the world changes, if you don't make it across the chasm, you really are a dinosaur. We hope to be the only dinosaur that makes it across the Cretaceous/Tertiary boundary. And all those little soft furry mammals -- yummy, yummy, yummy.

So imagine a velociraptor and a bunny. (laughter). And that is how we see the opportunity, but we have got to make it across. And it is hard.

And it is not simply a matter of -- in answer to Rick's question, I talked about a lot of the engineering we had to do. And that is a big job. That is just the start. Once you get all of the engineering right, you have got to restructure your sales forces against a whole new set of competitors.

You got to lower your cost of selling, because the size of a lot of these cloud transactions are smaller than what we are used to doing. We have to add a lot of salespeople to get better coverage, because we can go lower in the market than we used to be able to go.

And again, we have to change the focus of the sales force from on-prem to cloud. And it is much easier doing a startup, you have got one and only one. You are a startup and you sell on -- selling the cloud and that is all you do. It is very easy to do.

For us, we have to say that is not priority one anymore. Priority one is ERP in the cloud. Priority one is HTM in the cloud. And we have to get the comps [in]. We have to train the people. We got to get the composition systems right; we got to get the coverage right.

So there are -- there is a huge amount of engineering work to do on the foundation side and then there is a huge amount of distribution work that has to follow that. And then you have to get your first wave of references and your next generation references for all these new products.

So it is kind of a startup inside of an existing company. It is very tough. It is a cultural change, structural changes, engineering changes. That is why most companies don't make it across the chasm.

But the opportunity, the opportunity, if you think about it, just -- let's say you just toss a coin. What happens if we, in fact, make it across the chasm? We with our $5 billion of year of R&D become the cloud company. What happens to the little furry bunnies over there?

And I think, I think we -- I mean, we got to do it. And I think we are well on our way. And I would say the difference is now we are actually in the cloud. At $2 billion -- just under two -- $1.5 billion a year, we are really in the cloud -- we are in the business.

We have real customers, real references, we are winning big brands. Not just midmarket -- we are getting some very, very large customers. We are competing aggressively with Salesforce. They beat us more often than we beat them, but we are competing aggressively with Salesforce.

We are competing aggressively with Workday. We beat them more than they beat us. So we are actually in the game. We are on the field.

And just kind of -- you are handicapping it. What is the percentage? You are trying to -- you are trying to pick a percentage. What is the likelihood that Oracle actually makes it across the chasm? This big tech company makes it across the chasm to compete with this whole new generation of startups. I think we are the only one.

SAP hasn't started. You can't just do three acquisitions and say we are in the cloud. We rebuilt all of our ERP. We rebuilt all of our HCM. We rebuilt all of our database. We rebuilt all of our middleware for the cloud. You just can't -- you can't buy three things and say we are in -- hey, we are big in the cloud. Look at our revenue.

Not the point. So if we make it, we are going to be a very formidable competitor in the cloud and we are going to make it.

Gentleman right here.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Thank you. Larry, you see significant upside from the cloud and not from your on-prem business. Where do you see the dollars coming from? Is it just the dinosaurs or is it more internal in terms of IT, et cetera?

LARRY ELLISON: Well, okay, so that's -- I mean, where are we taking share from? Well, I think we will -- even if we ran Workday completely out of business, it is not very much money, right? You would all yawn. Great job, you ran Workday out of business, who cares? That is $40. Great. What do you --

So you are right. The big money is replacing -- taking more database share with our platform business from IBM. And to a lesser degree from Microsoft, because Microsoft is actually competing in the cloud with a platform. Microsoft should be able to move their .NET SQL Server applications to their platform.

I mean why would you come to our platform? The application is built; you can move to Microsoft's platforms at .NET SQL Server application. People do convert from SQL Server to Oracle because they want to go larger scale, handle bigger customers and more data. But if that is not a problem for you, you just move to Microsoft.

Our customers -- and we have got a lot of them -- will move to our platform. But what -- where do IBM's customers go? Where do the DB2 customers go? Where do the WebSphere DB2 customers go?

So we think we pick up a huge -- we continue to take share from IBM. We have been taking share from IBM for a very, very, very long time.

We think in ERP, midrange and high-end ERP, now it is going to be a slow process, but I would love to hear what SAP's plans are. I know they are talking about some simple Edge applications. They have done a few acquisitions.

They have got nothing. Their last big internal development they canceled. This is by design. Just shut it down. Whoops, it didn't work. They are now obsessed with Hana.

But they don't even use it. They market it aggressively, but I mean think of how embarrassing it would be for me if I said hey, Oracle Fusion applications run on Hana. But not Oracle database. Pretty preposterous. But all of SAP's cloud apps run on Oracle, not Hana. Everything.

And they have been obsessed with this. They have had another obsession before that was NetWeaver. So they -- Hasso, bless his heart, has always wanted to be a techie, not an accounting guy, accounting apps guy, and he wanted to be techie.

So he wants -- first he wanted to compete in middleware and he tried with NetWeaver. And that didn't work out so well. So now he said okay, I couldn't beat Oracle at middleware. I know what I am going to do. I am going to beat Oracle in database.

Okay. I mean, you can try. I thought that he was insane. I actually said get me the name of that pharmacist. He wants to play us in database. They are the number one ERP company in the world. We are number two. If I were him, I would want to play us in ERP, where they are the leader. They are not in the top 500 in database.

I know, okay, they bought Sybase. Great. They did Hana. So they want to play us in database and they talk about it and talk about it and they never talk about ERP.

So they shut down business by design, give up on NetWeaver. And I am telling you they don't use Hana. What does that say? How long have they been talking about Hana? Rick, you have been a big Hana supporter. How long have they been talking about Hana?

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Right about four years.

LARRY ELLISON: About four years. Rick -- I know Rick has been really saying this thing looks really good. Why do you think they don't use it?

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: They are porting all of their products over to it.

LARRY ELLISON: Yes, four years to -- okay. They are porting all of their products over to it, right. Okay, so they have had four years. They don't use it. They don't use it. It is astonishing.

And that is where they are putting their marketing efforts. That is where their ego is. That is where their R&D is. They lost a lot of key people, including the primary architects of Hana.

And I am telling you it is not going to work. It is going to be like NetWeaver. It is an unmitigated disaster. But that is not the problem. Hana never needed to work. NetWeaver never needed to work.

What needs to work is ERP. That is their business. At least 98% of their business. And they have not started moving that to the cloud. What are they going to do?

So where is the money going to come from? IBM, SAP. We are going to -- one by one, we are going to take a lot -- starting in the midmarket, we are going to take ERP customers from them. And they got no answers. They got no -- they got nothing.

Now people don't make ERP changes every day, but if you want ERP in the cloud, you can't get it from SAP. So that is another huge reservoir of money, answering your question. So IBM, SAP.

And strangely enough, though it sounds funny. A lot of the hardware companies, because we sell storage-as-a-service and we sell compute-as-a-service. So now when you buy our ERP applications, it comes with storage and it comes with compute and it comes with networking and all that stuff.

So -- and we charge -- and you -- over a ten-year period, you pay a lot more for our ERP as a service than you would pay for the license on-premise with support. And the reason you pay more is we do more.

We do the backups, we do the resource, we do the upgrades, so you get a much higher quality of service. But also we provide the computers. We provide compute and storage and networking and all that other jazz.

And that means companies aren't going to -- especially in the midmarket, companies aren't going to be buying servers. They are not going to be buying storage. So that is also money that can come to us.

So in this massive shift, as computing begins to look like a utility, we have our traditional competitors -- SAP in ERP applications, and IBM in database, and Java in middleware.

And then we have people we really, historically, have not been competing with, which are kind of all of these different server companies. And whether it is an Intel server running Linux, or a Windows Intel server running Windows, or a UNIX server running IBM AIX, doesn't really matter.

We don't -- we think people are going to be buying less and less of those. And they are going to be buying a lot of that stuff in the cloud. Again, it is just a gradual trend. Especially in the midmarket.

In the high-end, our engineered systems are still growing nicely. People like engineered systems, because people are coming to expect their suppliers to do the system integration so they don't have to.

Why do I like the cloud? I like the cloud because it includes compute and storage and memory and the operating system and the VM and the database and the Java platform and the application and the service to upgrade it and back it up and run the whole thing.

I like it because -- so the cloud provider, the cloud services provider integrated all those pieces for me. I don't have to. I don't have to.

Same idea behind engineered systems. Exadata -- it includes storage and networking and the VM and the OS and the database. And we will manage it for you, if you want us to our not. If you don't want us to be attached to the system.

But it is a lot easier for you to manage, because when we patch an Exadata system, we send you one file and it patches the firmware and the VM and the OS and the database all at once. And it has all been tested. Together.

So the fact that we have these pre-integrated suites of hardware and software that go on-premise. We have the cloud, obviously, pre-integrated and you just access over the Internet as a service.

Kind of the same benefits. Getting the labor out of enterprise IT. Getting the human element, the cost of the labor, and the human errors, and the project delays, and the overruns, and all of those things out. Because suddenly, the supplier is responsible for the integration -- doing the integration, not the enterprise customer.

And we think that is attractive in the cloud, obviously. But we also think for those banks that are not going to move to the cloud overnight, we think an Exadata sure makes more sense than buying your own storage, your own network, your operating system, your own servers, your own virtual machine, your own database, and piecing it all together and patching it all separately.

Think about what happens when you become a new -- Red Hat comes out with a new version of Linux, VMware comes out with a new version of VMware, Oracle comes out with the new version of the Oracle database. The server manufacturer changes the storage firmware.

I mean, it costs a lot to keep that stuff current and there are -- and who does the testing? The customer does the testing. The customer is the system integrator. It is a very bad model. It is a very inefficient model. So we like our cloud business and we like our engineered system business. Yes, sir?

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (inaudible - microphone inaccessible) SaaS company. You said you thought you could be the largest SaaS company in a couple years. And if you look at Salesforce's growth rate, if they grow at a similar declining rate for the next couple of years, they will be an $8 billion company.

And if you grow at a mid-30%s rate, over the next couple of years, you will be a $4 billion company, so -- ?

LARRY ELLISON: No, we are certainly planning to grow in excess of 50% a year in SaaS. So I mean, our internal plans are well above 50%. And remember, Salesforce has to make the right acquisitions to keep growing at that rate and they have to continue enjoying almost no competition.

So we think we can slow Salesforce down and accelerate our business. So we are not -- our business has got to be the first digit of growth that we are targeting is a five and -- but not five zero. Maybe mid-50%, let's say.

And that is not including pass. So our intent -- we think we can and should be the number one SaaS company, because we have -- we think we are very strong -- we are kind of the pioneer in the ERP, midrange in high-end ERP.

NetSuite is a pioneer of ERP and kind of mid to low. We are the pioneer mid-to-high ERP. We think that is a very valuable market for us and we are way in front of anybody. So we think we can be, clearly, the number one player there.

We are worldwide -- are we the number one player in HCM? Probably. I mean it is close. But we think we are ahead of Workday. And we are certain in the last couple of quarters, we sold more customers -- we had more wins than Workday.

We are number one in marketing. We think we are slightly in front of Salesforce in service. We just added Fields Serv -- we just had a Field Service acquisition. We can keep on adding around.

We have got a very strong data -- data business is new for us, but we think it -- we are very optimistic about that. We think it can strengthen our -- it helps us strengthen -- it is an all new business for us and strengthens our position in marketing.

We have such a large part -- we are number one in recruiting and talent management. We have such a large portfolio of products. And the real challenge, since we have done, I think, a pretty good job of engineering and acquiring -- and I'll just list the things we bought versus what our competitors bought.

I think we bought at better prices and better assets. We have been the first mover in acquisitions. And we have been building for the last decade -- or almost last decade, ERP/HCM sales, things like that.

We have got a very strong portfolio. Now the big thing is getting all of the secular sales forces lined up to compete with Salesforce in sales. To compete with Salesforce in service and compete with Workday in core HCM.

And just blaze a trail -- compete with ourselves, compete with ourselves in midrange and high-end ERP. Just go ahead and aggressively pioneer that market.

So we think we have all the -- we the right portfolio to do that and then a very strong platform underneath, which is a differentiator at the SaaS level. In other words, if you are buying HCM SaaS, do you want to buy -- let's say the products are equivalent. I think our product is much better than theirs. Ours is social; theirs is not social.

But without going into that big argument, why we are better than Workday. We have a platform that allows you to extend those applique -- our HCM application and connect it to other applications. They don't have a platform that they sell. They have nothing.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (inaudible - microphone inaccessible) without acquisitions? Is that an organic type of number?

LARRY ELLISON: Well, the organic number actually is -- if you look at our organic, what we built, I mean, our organics is way over 100%. And so -- and unfortunately, it is a small number -- it is a fairly small number.

But yes, no, we will continue to look at acquisitions. There's not a lot out there. Let me tell you. We looked at Concur. We looked at Concur and thought it was -- again, I know I am just sitting here knocking SAP.

Why do we want to do travel expenses? How is that strategic? How does that help us? What other products -- the simple question is what other products did it help us sell?

Again, we say suites win, right. The big thing. We think talent management helps us sell core HCM. Core HCM helps us sell talent management. It is the same buyer.

ERP -- general ledger payables receivable helps us sell enterprise performance management, budgeting, and reporting. And so enterprise performance manages -- management helps us sell ERP. HRP helped us sell EPM.

They are related products. Same CFO is very interested in both. Same buyer would like to buy the suite.

With Concur, if we had bought Concur, how do we leverage that into selling more products? That is what we did -- we didn't buy. We could have bought Ariba. We have much more money than SAP.

We could have bought Ariba and SuccessFactors and Concur. No problem. There would not be a problem. We have a lot more money than they do.

None of them were deemed strategic. Ariba doesn't have -- they don't even use the Ariba software at SAP. They just use the procurement network. They still use their own procurement software.

Concur -- there is no leverage out of Concur. It is a very high priced product. And maybe they can convince some analysts, look how big we are in the cloud. There is no growth in Concur.

So it would slow down our growth. You would complain. If we bought Concur, it would cost us a lot of money and it would slow down our cloud growth. Except for the first year, which would create the illusion of growth.

We have got hypergrowth from our Fusion apps. Again, we think ERP is just a matter of getting the sales force focused. Okay, guys, stop selling on-prem in the midmarket and just sell cloud, cloud, cloud, cloud. Get all that done.

We are -- we have kind of won the battle against Workday in Europe and outside the US and we are still fighting in the US. Finish that. Get that thing won.

And then continue chipping away at Salesforce's 15-year lead. We think our sales products -- well, we are ahead of them in marketing. We are ahead of them in service, but -- in their strength. In their strength.

We have got to compete aggressively in their strength, where our pitch is we have tools to help you sell more. We do more than simply manage your opportunities and forecast the quarter. We also have tools that allow you to engineer sales processes and actually sell more.

So we have just got to compete aggressively on all of those areas. And even without additional acquisitions, we think we can maintain that mid-50%s.

It is not a matter of we got to look for a big acquisition to do that. By the way, there are no big acquisitions left. I mean, what -- we have looked around. When we look -- you look at TOA Field Service, we were buying a relatively small business that had very good technology that we can grow.

Good corps of engineers, good core of customers, but a relatively small business. It wasn't for that one shot of the illusion of growth through acquisitions. But that is a business we think we can grow. I don't think SAP can grow Concur.

So -- but again, your question is do we need to make big acquisitions to get to the mid-50%s. No.

BILL WHYMAN, ANALYST, ISI GROUP: Bill Whyman from ISI. So 10 years ago, you said the tech industry wouldn't growth, that the leading companies would do nicely, but the industry over all wouldn't. Cloud would seem to put that on steroids.

What do you think, if anything, has changed, what would were your next chapter be, and what does that imply about M&A -- not just in software that you talked about, but across software and hardware?

LARRY ELLISON: Okay, so are you saying cloud is making -- I am not sure what your question was. Did you say cloud is really making the industry grow rapidly or cloud is proving it is not growing rapidly? What does cloud prove?

BILL WHYMAN: Cloud would seem to deflate tech spending, which you had indicated as well.

LARRY ELLISON: So you are saying cloud has depressed overall tech spending, including cloud?

BILL WHYMAN: Everything. Hardware, software, services.

LARRY ELLISON: Right and I think that is right. I think cloud has hurt the traditional vendors. I totally agree with that. However, if we make it across into cloud -- I will tell you who it's really hurt are the system integrators.

So I don't think it has hurt our business. I don't think it has hurt our business. The -- if it has, it is a very small -- it is a very, very small amount. And I think, ultimately, it is destined to dramatically help our business, because we think we can deploy our software assets and our hardware assets very effectively and package them in the cloud. And that is what we are going to do.

But it is much harder for an IBM to do that. It is much harder for an EMC to do that. And so a lot of these guys -- I mean, there are companies I think that are really under a lot of -- big companies that are under a lot of stress.

We look at that as an opportunity to take money that would have gone to IBM middleware and IBM database and get that as part of our platform service.

We look at it -- money that would have gone to EMC to buy disk drives and HP to buy servers and get that as part of our infrastructure service. So the thing in the cloud, you have to have -- we don't want to sell just infrastructure.

Infrastructure, for better or for worse, is a commodity. You are competing with -- it has got Amazon prices and Google prices and you are selling compute and storage. And are we going to sell that? Yes. Is that where we are going to make our money? No.

I mean, yes, we got to sell infrastructure as a service and yes, it is profitable. Believe it or not, even those low prices is profitable. But we make our money on platform-as-a-service. We make our money on software-as-a-service, the application layers.

And then we deliver infrastructure-as-a-service at the same price as Amazon, but with more security and more reliability. And with one security model. So you can buy -- it is one-stop shopping for the whole thing.

You move some applications to infrastructure-as-a-service, some applications to Java-as-a-service, some to database -- the database is the database-as-a-service -- and you buy some number of SaaS applications. You build some -- you extend some, you build some stuff around -- blah, blah, blah.

That is what -- who else offers that? Kind of Microsoft. No one else offers that. So we think with that huge portfolio, when we sell a cloud service, we get paid for the software. We get paid for the hardware.

We get paid for the labor, the service about -- well, actually, there is not much labor in backing stuff up, because it is highly automated. There is not much labor in upgrading our software, because it is highly automated. But we get paid for all of those additional services that right now is done by human beings at the enterprise level.

So we are -- we also do the integration. We do all the integration, which is done by the customer or the system integrator. So the biggest move -- the biggest problem in terms of the industry getting smaller is the labor being automated away.

As the labor gets automated away and the system integrators get smaller and smaller and these -- I mean, you remember how big an SAP implementation was for a big company? Anyone remember? Yes, I mean, it was just astounding.

That is not going to happen anymore. That is huge amounts of money. The EMC storage business. I mean a lot of these businesses -- if you look at what Amazon charges for storage and what EMC charges for storage, it is a big gap. That is going to be -- it is a problem if what you sell is storage. These are commodities.

But we are not in a lot of commodity businesses. I mean, we have some commodity hardware businesses and they are getting smaller. Our engineered -- our non-commodity hardware businesses are growing nicely: Engineered Systems, Exadata, Exalytics, Exalogic, our Big Data machine, which runs Hadoop, by the way.

So we have got out lot of engineered systems. SPARC SuperCluster -- all of these things. Our zero data loss backup appliance. I mean, a lot of these -- they are a collection of hardware and software all pre-integrated, which are designed to take the labor out. You don't do the integrations.

And what we are trying to do is get rid of all of that integration money that is spent. Plus, think about the number of errors that are made as every company does their own unique SAP, ERP implementation.

I mean, it is not just the system integrator, but how much of the IT Department of that consuming company spend in terms of labor to put that thing in and then upgrade it and upgrade it again. And then bring in the EMC drives and blah, blah, and this other stuff and the HP servers.

And so we think we have an opportunity to package those technologies in the cloud with lots of differentiation and lots of value-add and make our business grow really nicely at the expense of other people.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: This will be last question.

LARRY ELLISON: (laughter). Yes, ma'am. Okay, boss. Last question. This is hard. Could I have two? (laughter).

KARL KEIRSTEAD, ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANK: Karl Keirstead of Deutsche Bank. Larry, it would be a shame for you to leave without taking the CEO question, so I will ask it and there's two parts. One is I am wondering if you could give us some context to your decision to give up the CEO title, that is the easy one.

And then the other one I would love some color on is how things might change now that you have got more time to devote to the technology function?

LARRY ELLISON: Okay, I think -- I don't think there are going to be any large changes. I mean, it has always been a team effort for a very, very long time. So Safra and Mark have been running the vast majority of the Company for a long time.

I have run engineering at Oracle from day one and I continue to run engineering now. With extraordinarily able help of Thomas Kurian and John Fowler and Ed Scrivens, so with a phenomenal team of people.

But it has always been a team effort. I think we get along very well. I mean, we are all kinds of -- we are all both specialists and generalists. I think we all, if we have to, can go out and sell. We all -- if we have to, we can go out and manage processes and do all of those things.

I think we can all analyze acquisitions and figure out if it is accretive or dilutive and all of those. I think, but frankly, I specialize in the product areas. Safra runs everything from finance and legal to manufacturing and what we will call the back office in the broadest sense. And Mark runs everything that is customer facing.

And does it mean I am going to stop making sales calls? No. But it really means that they get the recognition that they have long deserved. They have been doing this job for a very, very long time. And I have been focusing on engineering for a very, very long time.

We will continue to work together as a team. I think we get along very well. It is not as a matter -- an issue that like Lincoln and his -- believe it or not, I don't want to compare myself to Lincoln -- but Lincoln after Reconstruction held a vote and there were all nays in the Cabinet and one aye and Lincoln overruled everybody.

That is not how we work. It is not that we are consensus managers. It is just that we discussed everything thoroughly. And I think people with the same facts and who are good at reasoning tend to agree.

And I think we are all very fact-based. I think we are all slaves to reason and we communicate well together and we tend to agree on things and work extremely well as a team. And for me, it was important that both of these guys get the recognition and the credits that they deserve.

I mean, they really have been running their parts of the Company for a very, very long time and the world should know that. Their titles are now correct.

And I have always wanted to be -- I like the product. It is my favorite part of the business. It is where I started -- I started as a computer programmer. And I will, as I said on stage, I am excited about my new job. I am excited about all of the things we have in the pipeline that has just come out.

And you ain't seen nothing yet. I mean, we spent a lot of money on R&D and I think we get good return on our investments. So I am very excited to be on the team and we are all in it to win it. And these guys -- again, these guys now have the titles they have long deserved.

And this is the last question.

JAMES GILMAN, ANALYST, DREXEL HAMILTON: Thank you, Larry. James Gilman, Drexel Hamilton. You have a very exciting vision going forward. My question, though, portends around vendor lock-in. Division would say that single source supplier, but I think enterprises want to avoid that vendor lock-in. Can you comment on that? Thank you.

LARRY ELLISON: Well, if that was true, no one would buy from Workday and no one would buy from Salesforce. It would be great. So if you build an application on force.com, let me tell you where you can run it. On a computer owned by Marc Benioff. That is it. And let me tell you how much you pay. Whatever he wants you to pay.

If you build an application on our platform, you write it in Java in the Oracle database. Where can you run it? You can run in your datacenter. You can run it on Amazon.com. You can run it on -- in the Microsoft cloud. Azure.

I mean, you got lots of choices. You can move it back off our cloud. Our stuff is all standards-based. There is no lock-in in our platform. Their platform exists one and only one place. It is 100% proprietary, runs on one set of computers, the computers owned by salesforce.com.

Workday. Same thing. I mean the only place you can buy Workday is Workday.

We -- our -- the bulk of our business, our platform business, our Java business. Java is open source, for God's sakes. Java is open source standards-based. The Oracle database is based on standards. Hundreds of industry standards. There is no lock-in.

You can actually -- that is why people move from DB2 to Oracle. That is why people move from SQL Server to Oracle. God forbid, I hope that no one moves from Oracle to SQL Server.

Maybe it has happened; maybe one guy some place in Mongolia did that. Nothing against Mongolia. I love Mongolia. I used - I've ridden horses in Mongolia. It is a fantastic place. Great history.

But there is no lock-in with our platform. There is a lock-in with the Salesforce platform. And there is no lock-in with the Workday platform, because they don't have one.

Thank you very much.

urn:contentItem:7YN8-6Y30-Y9NC-P121-00000-00Oracle cutting more Sun jobs2010-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:39ZLexisNexisBREAKINGTechnologyNewsBusinessHigh-TechScience and TechOracle cutting more Sun jobsBy Brandon Bailey bbailey@mercurynews.com

Oracle said late Friday that it will embark on a new round of layoffs as it continues to overhaul the operations of Sun Microsystems, the financially struggling computer maker that it bought earlier this year.

Most of the cuts will occur in Europe and Asia, the company said in a regulatory filing.

A spokeswoman declined to say how many jobs will be affected, but the filing said Oracle will spend $675 million to $825 million on restructuring costs chiefly for employee severance payments on top of $325 million that it previously allocated for restructuring related to the Sun deal.

Redwood City-based Oracle, which had 106,492 employees at the end of February, is traditionally tight-lipped about job reductions. But in January, CEO Larry Ellison emphatically denied speculation that Oracle planned to make major cuts in Sun's work force, which was then about 27,000.

At that time, he said he planned to hire about 2,000 people in sales and engineering jobs "to beef up Sun's business," while adding that he would cut about 1,000 jobs that involved administration or other redundant functions.

Last month, however, Ellison told a Reuters news service reporter that Oracle had found many examples of inefficiency as they reviewed Sun's operations. Though widely respected for its technological innovations, Sun had struggled financially in recent years. Sun cut about 3,000 jobs last fall while the Oracle deal was pending.

Oracle executives have repeatedly said they expect to make Sun's operations profitable by improving efficiency and combining Sun's intellectual property with Oracle software to create new, high-performance computing systems for commercial use.

But a report last week by industry research firm IDC shows Sun's core business has continued to decline. IDC estimated Sun's revenue from selling computer servers declined almost 32 percent, from $1 billion in the first quarter of 2009 to $683 million in the first quarter of 2010, while Hewlett-Packard and Dell both increased their share of the server market, at Sun's expense.

Oracle's announcement caps a week of mixed news for big tech company hiring. HP said Tuesday that it will cut about 9,000 jobs over the next few years as it automates and consolidates some of its computer centers, while adding about 6,000 jobs in sales and other functions.

Cisco Systems CEO John Chambers, however, said Friday that his company will "accelerate" hiring and will add about 4,000 jobs this year, or about 1,000 more than he previously indicated when discussing hiring plans in February.

A Oracle, multinacional americana de tecnologia e segunda maior fabricante de softwares do mundo, é a mais nova interessada em comprar as operações do aplicativo chinês TikTok nos Estados Unidos. A empresa se junta à gigante Microsoft na disputa pelo app, ...

A Oracle, multinacional americana de tecnologia e segunda maior fabricante de softwares do mundo, é a mais nova interessada em comprar as operações do aplicativo chinês TikTok nos Estados Unidos. A empresa se junta à gigante Microsoft na disputa pelo app, que pode ser banido dos EUA caso as operações no país não sejam vendidas para alguma empresa americana até novembro. A Oracle está trabalhando com um grupo de investidores americanos que já detém participação na ByteDance, empresa chinesa que desenvolveu o TikTok, que inclui a General Atlantic e a Sequoia Capital, informa o britânico Financial Times . Além das operações no território norte-americano, o negócio envolve o controle do aplicativo no Canadá, na Austrália e na Nova Zelândia. ASSINE VEJA A encruzilhada econômica de Bolsonaro Na edição da semana: os riscos da estratégia de gastar muito para impulsionar a economia. E mais: pesquisa exclusiva revela que o brasileiro é, sim, racista Clique e Assine Estimativas apontam que o valor dos negócios do TikTok nos EUA podem variar entre 20 e 50 bilhões de dólares. Com valor de mercado na casa dos 166 bilhões de dólares, a Oracle possuía aproximadamente 43 bilhões em caixa no fim de maio. No quarto trimestre fiscal da multinacional de tecnologia, a receita caiu 6%, o que representa uma queda de 10,4 bilhões de dólares. A empresa sofre forte concorrência da Amazon, do Google e da própria Microsoft no serviço de computação em nuvem. Às 16h20, as ações da Oracle subiam 1,83% na Bolsa de Nova York. A venda da operação do TikTok nos EUA movimenta o mercado corporativo após uma decisão do presidente americano, Donald Trump.” Há evidências confiáveis ​​que me levam a acreditar que a ByteDance pode tomar medidas que ameacem prejudicar a segurança nacional dos EUA”, disse, em meio ao acirramento das tensões com a China e suas empresas de tecnologia. Por recomendação do Comitê de Investimento Estrangeiro nos Estados Unidos, o presidente americano expediu um decreto na última sexta-feira, 14, que prevê justamente o banimento do aplicativo em 90 dias caso nenhuma transação seja acertada até lá . “Como já afirmamos, 100 milhões de americanos adoram o TikTok porque é um local de entretenimento, autoexpressão e conexão social. Estamos decididos a continuar levando alegria às famílias e carreiras significativas aos que criam em nossa plataforma durante muitos anos”, declarou um porta-voz da ByteDance em resposta ao decreto. A entrada da Oracle na jogada ocorre porque o bilionário Larry Elisson, co-fundador da empresa, é um dos poucos empresários do Vale do Silício que apoiam abertamente Donald Trump, tanto que no último mês de fevereiro o magnata organizou — em sua propriedade na Califórnia — um evento de arrecadação de fundos para a campanha do republicano. Apesar da relação próxima entre eles, a Casa Branca ainda não se posicionou sobre algum tipo de apoio para alguma das empresas envolvidas no negócio. Até então, a Microsoft despontava como a favorita para a corrida. A big tech fundada por Bill Gates chegou a cogitar, inclusive, a compra das operações globais do TikTok, mas a desenvolvedora da rede social chinesa rechaçou qualquer possibilidade de incluir novos países além dos já envolvidos atualmente. De toda forma, qualquer transação terá que enfrentar uma lista de desafios, o principal deles é separar a tecnologia de apoio do TikTok da tecnologia da ByteDance, razão pela qual Donald Trump exige a venda do aplicativo nos EUA, em vista que acusa a desenvolvedora chinesa de espionar os usuários americanos para o governo chinês. Continua após a publicidade Com a chegada da Oracle ao pleito, as chances do Twitter, que demonstrou interesse na disputa , se tornaram ainda mais remotas, em vista que a rede social teria pouco tempo para levantar o capital necessário para a operação. O Twitter tem uma capitalização de mercado de cerca de 30 bilhões de dólares, praticamente o valor de ativos do TikTok a ser alienado. Por outro lado, joga a favor da companhia comandada por Jack Dorsey o fato de que sua oferta enfrentaria menos entraves regulatórios do que a da Microsoft, por exemplo, e que também não passaria por pressões da China, uma vez que não atua no país.

urn:contentItem:4CV7-5MF0-TW84-N2XX-00000-00Oracle Feels the Software Squeeze;The threat posed by lower-priced competition is a driving force behind its hostile bid for PeopleSoft.2004-07-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:39ZLexisNexisBUSINESSBusiness DeskPart CPg. 1Oracle Feels the Software SqueezeThe threat posed by lower-priced competition is a driving force behind its hostile bid for PeopleSoft.Joseph MennTimes Staff Writer SAN FRANCISCO

To see why Oracle Corp.Chief Executive Larry Ellison is so intent on gobbling up business software maker PeopleSoft Inc., look no further than Sabre Holdings Corp.

Two years ago, the multibillion-dollar travel services company set up an elaborate test to determine which database program could best handle the stresses of tens of millions of customers looking for the best airfares on its Travelocity.com website.

Sabre's chief architect, Bob Offutt, figured that Oracle's flagship database program would outperform its rivals. Instead, a program called MySQL, available for less than half of Oracle's $2-million-plus list price, scored about the same.

"Everybody scratched their head," Offutt recalled last week. And Southlake, Texas-based Sabre signed up for MySQL, an open-source product along the lines of Linux that is distributed, usually at low or no cost, by a small Swedish firm also named MySQL. Sabre joined an impressive customer lineup that includes Yahoo Inc., Google Inc.and Cisco Systems Inc.

Oracle was once the clear leader in the $14-billion global market for database programs, which allow operations dealing with masses of information to store, retrieve and manipulate figures. But Oracle has been scrambling recently to deal with stiff competition.

Although Oracle's total database-related revenue of $7.7 billion is greater than IBM Corp.'s, for example, Big Blue passed Redwood City, Calif.-based Oracle in sales of new databases three years ago. And although overall sales of new databases increased 5% in 2003, Oracle's new database sales grew by just 2.4%, putting it just shy of IBM with about one-third of the market. IBM is the foe Oracle faces most often when it bids for big-dollar contracts.

Oracle's efforts to diversify by selling business software tools that run on top of its database programs -- the market where PeopleSoft plays -- aren't faring much better. Documents introduced during the antitrust trial over Oracle's hostile bid for PeopleSoft show that Oracle often slashes its list prices for such software by 70% or more and still loses deals to Pleasanton, Calif.-based PeopleSoft or to the biggest maker of such programs, SAP of Germany.

Meanwhile, Microsoft Corp., which enjoys a massive development budget and the ability to sell customers a full set of interlocking programs, is taking share from Oracle on the low end of the market with its own database program, called SQL Server. (SQL refers to a standard computer language for dealing with databases.) Microsoftwon 19% of the global market for new database installations last year.

In testimony at the antitrust trial, Ellison and his colleagues were motivated to paint a bleak picture of Oracle's competitive prospects. U.S. District Judge Vaughn Walker might be more inclined to let Oracle continue its quest for PeopleSoft, over the objections of government regulators, if he agrees that Oracle is facing threats from all sides and that its best shot at long-term survival was to get bigger.

Walker is scheduled to hear closing arguments July 20.

Industry analysts, database customers and competitors agree that Oracle is exaggerating the predictions of its possible demise. But they also concur that Ellison is correct in concluding that the database market has fundamentally changed.

"Are they going to grow the way they're used to growing in the database market? No," said Gartner Inc. database analyst Donald Feinberg.

One reason is MySQL, which Feinberg said "could become a major player" in the next three to five years.

Oracle executives declined to be interviewed for this story.

But at least in the past the company recognized the power of open-source software. Oracle was an early champion of Linux, the computer operating system program developed through a worldwide collaboration of volunteers. Oracle introduced a version of its database that could run on Linux in 1998, before most other big tech companies embraced it.

Since then, Oracle has tied its fortunes to the operating system by designing products to work on bundles of cheap, Linux-powered machines. The company even offers to oversee its customers' use of Linux when Oracle databases are used on top of it. In that way, Oracle has helped Linux reach deep into big companies, where its use is now routine.

MySQL could follow a similar trajectory. In court, Oracle President Safra Catz testified that she viewed MySQL as a competitor.

The first version of MySQL came out in 1996, the work of Michael "Monty" Widenius of Finland, where Linux also began. He and a colleague were developing a system for a large retail chain to keep track of its inventory. As they added more functions, "it started looking like a database," said friend Marten Micklos, an entrepreneur later recruited as privately owned MySQL's chief executive.

The team's free release attracted hundreds of thousands of users, and in 2000 the company shifted to an unusual two-tier method of distribution. The most basic software and its underlying code are still available free of charge and are downloaded 35,000 times daily; 5 million copies already have been installed, making it the fourth-most-used database in the world.

Versions with more features or technical support are sold for as little as $249 per computer, compared with about $5,000 for a bare-bones Oracle installation. Sabre and other large customers often buy even more sophisticated types of MySQL and install them on hundreds of machines.

By revenue, MySQL has less than one tenth of 1% of the market, but sales have doubled annually for three years and now stand at $12 million. The company turns a small profit from its operations and hasn't touched the $20 million it received from venture-capital investors last year. Industry analysts at San Francisco brokerage Thomas Weisel Partners estimate that MySQL is a contender for as much as 20% of new database deals.

The easy availability of MySQL has popularized the technology, attracted helpful reports of bugs and kept the company's full-time staff of 50 engineers motivated to make continual improvements to the product, Micklos said.

Knowing anyone can see their work, "those who produce it have much higher pride," Micklos said. "Frontyard gardens are in much better shape than backyard gardens."

MySQL will never have the same overwhelming army of unpaid contributors that has fashioned Linux into the most serious threat to Microsoft's ubiquitous Windows operating system.

Database expertise is more rare, and fewer people need a database than an operating system, the core ingredient on any computer.

All that means MySQL isn't likely to steal Oracle's most lucrative contracts. In any case, Micklos said it wasn't in his company's DNA to shoot for the highest-function needs of the Fortune 500.

"I'm absolutely convinced there will always be a high end of the database market, where you can charge any price you can think of," he said. "We produce at low cost and we sell at low cost. We try to be the Ikea of databases."

In order to move upstream, MySQL would need to make major upgrades to the main product and get other companies to sell programs that use the database for managing sales, payroll and other business functions. SAP is working on such programs, but they will take a few years to develop, Micklos said.

"That's the key event that needs to happen in order for MySQL to be validated in the marketplace and really move forward," Gartner's Feinberg said.

In the meantime, the database is creeping into big companies from the ground up. At Yahoo, software developer and MySQL expert Jeremy Zawodny first used it to run Yahoo Finance.

"It was a success, and within the next year, I had all these groups at the company banging on my door" to help them extend the database to Yahoo News, the My Yahoo personalized portal and elsewhere.

Other pieces of Yahoo run on more established databases. Yet even where MySQL doesn't win, it is taking a bite out of Oracle's bottom line.

At Sabre, Offutt decided that MySQL was good enough for the air travel system, where many more people look at prices than make reservations. For hotels, where the ratio of "lookers to bookers" is lower and transactions are more common, he decided to go with Oracle.

After losing the airfare contract, "Oracle came back with some extremely aggressive pricing, something we've never seen," Offutt said.

That oft-repeated scenario is beginning to make Oracle executives nervous, analysts said. They said the company could afford a price war with SAP and PeopleSoft over the business software they all sell.

It can't afford to be the next victim of the open-source movement.
