urn:contentItem:5Y98-DGX1-F05M-K2YM-00000-00Oracle is waging a war against its Big Tech rivals - here's a look at one of its tactics2020-02-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:39ZLexisNexisOracle is waging a war against its Big Tech rivals - here's a look at one of its tacticsRyan Fernandez

For years, Oracle Corp. has been waging battles against some of the biggest companies in tech, jockeying for government contracts and dueling over patents.

But it has come to light that the Redwood City-based company has also been fighting on another front within the legal system, funding groups that, in turn, offer their support in the courts.

Bloomberg reports that Oracle is one of the benefactors behind the Internet Accountability Project, a conservative nonprofit that advocates both for enforcing antitrust laws against tech giants and for stronger privacy regulations. The company donated between $25,000 and $99,999 to the nonprofit last year, according to its   2019 Political Activity Report.

In February, the Internet Accountability Project filed an amicus brief supporting Oracle in a patent lawsuit against Alphabet Inc.-owned Google, saying it wants to "ensure that Google respects the copyrights of Oracle and other innovators," per Bloomberg.

Oracle also appears to have backed at least four other organizations that filed briefs on its behalf. The case will be heard by the U.S. Supreme Court on March 24.

Google declined to comment to Bloomberg, though the publication notes that the Mountain View-based web search and advertising giant has provided funding to at least 10 organizations that have filed briefs to support its claims in the case.

According to Bloomberg, IAP President Mike Davis said in a statement that Oracle did not fund the amicus brief, and that his group does not disclose the identity of its backers. It is a Section 501(c)(4) organization, meaning that it does not have to disclose its donors as long as it doesn't spend more than half of its money on campaign ads or election activities.

The IAP was founded in September by Davis and Rachel Bovard to "lend a conservative voice to the calls for federal and state governments to rein in Big Tech before it is too late," according to its website. David and Bovard are former aides to Republican Sens. Chuck Grassley of Iowa and Rand Paul of Kentucky, respectively.

Oracle has also been in conflict with Amazon.com Inc. over the awarding of the Pentagon's Joint Enterprise Defense Infrastructure cloud contract, having joined with companies like Google and Microsoft to oppose Amazon while lobbying Congress and President Donald Trump. Microsoft ultimately won the contract, but its victory is still being contested in court.

Oracle's Political Activity Report revealed that it is a funder of the Free and Fair Markets Initiative, a nonprofit that has criticized Amazon's business practices. According to the Wall Street Journal, the initiative is also backed by Amazon rivals like mall owner Simon Property Group and Walmart.

Elsewhere on the political front, Oracle has been in the news in the last week for Chairman Larry Ellison's hosting of a fundraiser for President Donald Trump's reelection campaign in Coachella Valley, and the subsequent reaction by a portion of Oracle's workforce.

When news came out about the fundraiser, employees circulated a petition calling on the company to oppose the association with Trump. The petition gathered 9,576 supporters by the time it closed. On Feb. 20, about 300 employees - out of 136,000 workers globally -   staged a "log-off" protest called No Ethics/No Work. Participants were encouraged to spend the time doing volunteer work, or to donate a half-day's pay to charity.

urn:contentItem:4BTV-SRY0-00G9-20Y6-00000-00Oracle sets up legal case;PeopleSoft merger to be compared with SunGard case2004-03-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:39ZLexisNexisBUSINESS;RELATED STORY ATTACHEDOracle sets up legal case;

PeopleSoft merger to be compared with SunGard caseBenjamin Pimentel

As Oracle Corp. prepares to beat back the Justice Department's efforts to block its hostile bid for PeopleSoft Inc., the company is pointing to another merger that the government tried to stop -- and failed.

In late 2001, the Justice Department filed a lawsuit, based on anti-competitive grounds, to block the sale of Comdisco Inc.'s disaster services business to SunGard Data Systems Inc.

But a federal court threw out the suit, saying the Justice Department's definition of the market in which the two companies were competing was too narrow.

The Justice Department had argued that the merger would have allowed SunGard to dominate the market for computer systems that businesses use to back up company data.

But the court said the agency failed to consider other vendors offering similar services and products in that market.

Chronicle Staff Writer

Oracle plans to make the same argument when it goes to court against the Justice Department, which it claims has presented a very limited view of the market in which the two software giants are competing.

The Justice Department has argued that an Oracle-PeopleSoft merger would reduce the number of enterprise softwaremakers serving big customers to two -- the other being SAP of Germany.

"We think the department is mistaken," Oracle attorney Dan Wall said. "Any structure that you can propose, I can show you companies within that circle that are buying from companies other than Oracle, PeopleSoft and SAP."

While the three tech giants compete for big contracts to manage the human resources and financial management networks of big corporations, they also often deal with smaller players in that arena.

He cited other softwaremakers such as Lawson Software in Minnesota and Kronos in Massachusetts.

Contrary to the Justice Department's claim, he added, the proposed merger would lead to a more vibrant and competitive market, by giving more business opportunities to smaller software firms.

Wall explained that customers typically solicit two or three bids before choosing a vendor. But, he said, if there are fewer big players competing, smaller players will become more visible on customers' radar.

"There will be a scramble for the so-called strong third," Wall said. "There will be companies that will portray themselves as the strong answer to Oracle and PeopleSoft."

Jim Kizielewicz, vice president of marketing at Kronos, agreed.

"I think they're right," he said. "To be honest with you, I'd love to see Oracle buy PeopleSoft. From our perspective, there will be nothing but good news in terms of impact on our company. … We think we'll get pulled into more deals."

And the expected layoffs that would follow a merger would also give smaller firms such as Kronos an opportunity to recruit talent, he said.

"It would be a great opportunity for us to pick up some people," he said. "The fear, uncertainty and doubt it creates is good for us."

Gary Beach, publisher of CIO magazine, said Oracle's argument underscores the difficulty of defining the different segments within the software market, which includes firms that make operating systems and different kinds of applications.

But he said that if Oracle succeeds in buying PeopleSoft, its dominant position would worry many chief information officers.

Beach pointed out that while there are many other software firms that compete with Oracle, "lots of them are small businesses that cannot set standards and cannot move markets."

Kizielewicz of Kronos underscored this point as he described the competition between big tech companies like Oracle and PeopleSoft, which offer a broad portfolio of products to customers, and smaller players that specialize in specific areas such as supply chain or payroll management.

"The big guys like Oracle and PeopleSoft say, 'We're one vendor, and you can buy everything from us,' " he said. "We say, 'Yeah, they're one vendor, but if something goes wrong, and you're with the wrong vendor, you're in trouble.' "

Referring to the proposed merger, he added: "If you're looking to standardize on one vendor, it does limit choices."

Despite what Oracle sees as parallels between its hostile bid and the SunGard-Comdisco deal, there are also major differences that could work against the software firm.

For one thing, the Justice Department had only 17 days to investigate and then subsequently try to block SunGard's acquisition, which gave the federal government little time to prepare a stronger case.

But that's not the situation with the Oracle bid -- the Justice Department has been looking into the deal for eight months.

Oracle appears to face stronger opposition from PeopleSoft customers than SunGard did from Comdisco clients.

Beach said there's also simply more attention focused on the Oracle bid.

"Oracle is paying a price for its high profile," he said, adding that fewer people cared about the SunGard-Comdisco transaction. "When you think of SunGard, you think it's sunscreen you put on when you go to the beach."

Still, Wall, the attorney for Oracle, was optimistic: "The Justice Department wins a lot of cases, but they lose cases, too. This is not a forgone conclusion."

------------------------------------------------------------------

HOSTILE HISTORY

The merger battle between Oracle and PeopleSoft has lasted for nine months, and could drag on a lot longer.

June, 2003 2: PeopleSoft announces agreement to buy J.D. Edwards for $1.7 billion, solidifying its No. 2 spot in enterprise software behind SAP. 6: Oracle issues $5.1 billion hostile takeover bid for PeopleSoft. 12: PeopleSoft's board rejects Oracle's offer. 13: PeopleSoft says that it has sued to block Oracle's bid and that it faces six lawsuits from shareholders angry that the board nixed the Oracle offer. 16: PeopleSoft accelerates its merger with J.D. Edwards and says it is offering a money-back deal to reassure customers nervous about the proposed takeover. 18: Oracle increases its PeopleSoft bid from $16 to $19.50 per share. 20: PeopleSoft's board rejects Oracle's sweetened offer. 30: The Department of Justice opens a review of the proposed merger..

July, 2003 18: PeopleSoft successfully takes control of J.D. Edwards..

October, 2003 3: Fueled by positive earnings and forecasts, PeopleSoft stock closes at $19.81 per share, above Oracle's offer price. 27: PeopleSoft discloses it has expanded its money-back offer to customers..

November, 2003 10: Oracle and a group of shareholders sue to block the expanded money-back offer. 17: The European Commission says its investigation of the proposed merger could take up to four months..

January, 2004 12: European regulators say they suspended their review of Oracle Corp.'s $7.3 billion bid after the software giant missed a filing deadline. 23: Oracle starts a proxy battle by nominating five candidates for the board of PeopleSoft. If elected, Oracle's candidates would be expected to reverse PeopleSoft's opposition to the buyout offer.

24: Oracle vows to introduce an alternative slate of PeopleSoft directors for shareholders to vote on, turning the fight into a proxy battle..

February, 2004 4: Oracle raises its cash offer 33 percent to $26 per share, valuing the deal at $9.4 billion. 9: PeopleSoft advises its shareholders to reject Oracle's latest bid, saying it is still too low and that the proposal is under too much regulatory scrutiny. 10: The Department of Justice staff recommends that the agency file suit to block Oracle Corp.'s hostile takeover bid on antitrust grounds. 26: The Justice Department files a lawsuit to block Oracle's bid. Oracle says it will "vigorously" fight it. The company also says it was withdrawing its nominees for PeopleSoft's board.

urn:contentItem:7WP2-4H40-Y9NC-P3B0-00000-00Oracle's Larry Ellison says Sun losing $100 million a month2009-09-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:39ZLexisNexisBREAKINGTechnologyNewsBusinessHigh-TechScience and TechOracle's Larry Ellison says Sun losing $100 million a monthBy Brandon Bailey bbailey@mercurynews.com

Declaring that Sun Microsystems is losing $100 million a month, Oracle CEO Larry Ellison expressed frustration Monday over an extended European antitrust review that has delayed his plans to acquire the struggling computer maker.

But he also told a Silicon Valley audience that he expects the deal will eventually win approval.

"The longer this takes, the more money Sun is going to lose, and that's not good for anybody," Ellison said while speaking to an after-dinner audience at the Fairmont San Jose hotel, in an event organized by the nonprofit Churchill Club.

"We want to get this done," he said of the acquisition, adding that he wants "to save as many jobs as we can."

Analysts have predicted Oracle will have to make major cuts in Sun's work force and spending, to achieve its goal of increasing operating profit from Sun's business. Some analysts have said an extended delay could lead Oracle to cut more deeply, since uncertainty over Sun's future may be driving more customers to rivals such as Hewlett-Packard and IBM.

Ellison, who was interviewed on stage by former Sun President Ed Zander, also vowed that he will not sell off Sun's open-source database program, known as MySQL. European regulators have raised concerns that Oracle's acquisition of MySQL would discourage competition in the database market. They have said their review may take until January to complete.

Oracle's own flagship database program doesn't compete with MySQL, Ellison asserted, adding that the two are generally used for different purposes. Oracle sells its database software to big corporations and government agencies that need to crunch massive amounts of data. MySQL is widely used but, as an open-source program, is often downloaded for free by programmers who use it for Web-based functions and less "mission-critical" operations.

Noting that U.S. antitrust regulators have already approved Oracle's plans to buy Sun for $7.4 billion, Ellison said "the Europeans have to do their job," but he expects that European officials will eventually approve the deal as well.

His remarks came during a rare extended public appearance that was billed as an unscripted, although generally friendly interview before an audience of several hundred tech industry workers and executives. One of the planet's richest men, Ellison has run Oracle since its founding in 1977, building it into one of the world's biggest software companies.

Known for his strong ego and outspoken views, Ellison drew laughter when he ridiculed the industry trend known as "cloud computing," saying as he has before that it's nothing more than a faddish term for the established concept of computers linked by networks. "A cloud is water vapor," he observed.

On a more sober note, he predicted the economy will take a long time to recover from the current recession. Despite government stimulus efforts, he said, "The American consumer is so deeply in debt; this is not going to come back, certainly for five years."

Ellison expounded on several other points that he has made before, including his plans to increase Oracle's current competition with IBM by selling high-performance computer systems that combine technology from Oracle and Sun. He described the pending acquisition with enthusiasm, saying, "Sun has fantastic technology."

Oracle, of Redwood City, is primarily known as a commercial software company, while Santa Clara-based Sun makes software, computer servers and data storage systems. Sun, which was struggling even before the current recession, saw its sales drop further over the past year as high-end customers in the banking and telecommunications sectors were hit hard by the downturn.

Several other big tech companies, including HP, IBM and Cisco Systems, are also vying to offer a range of products for big corporate computing centers. Ellison said he plans to compete with all of them. HP, IBM and to a lesser extent Dell also have pursued a strategy of selling consulting services advising customers on how to assemble their hardware and software. But Ellison said he believes he will be more successful by selling hardware and software that is "integrated at the engineering level," or designed to work together from the start.

"We have no interest in the hardware business. We have a deep interest in the systems business," he said, suggesting that Oracle will focus on high-performance computing systems rather than on lower-cost standardized components that have been a growth sector for the computer industry in recent years.

It was the first time Ellison spoke publicly since Oracle Corp.announced in April that it had agreed to pay $7.4 billion to acquire Sun Microsystems. (AP Photo/Paul Sakuma)

urn:contentItem:7WV2-P720-Y9NC-P03M-00000-00Oracle takeover of Sun to be center stage at OpenWorld2009-10-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:39ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYNewsBusinessOracle takeover of Sun to be center stage at OpenWorldBy Brandon Bailey bbailey@mercurynews.com

It may be bogged down in a European antitrust review, but the year's biggest tech deal will be center stage at one of the industry's biggest annual events, as Oracle CEO Larry Ellison highlights his company's pending $7.4 billion purchase of Sun Microsystems when Oracle's annual OpenWorld bash kicks off in San Francisco today .

Never one to be intimidated by government regulators, Ellison will share the stage at Moscone Center with top Sun executives including Chairman Scott McNealy during an opening presentation that will focus on Sun's products and technology.

For the first time, Oracle is also providing a stage though not a keynote speaking slot to one of its most outspoken competitors, CEO Marc Benioff of upstart software providerSalesforce.com.

As in previous years, OpenWorld is expected to draw more than 40,000 Oracle customers, software developers, analysts and industry representatives. They'll attend five days of seminars, sales pitches, product demos and speeches by executives from Oracle and other big tech vendors, such as Hewlett-Packard and Dell, before queuing up for the traditional "customer appreciation" concert on Treasure Island. This year's lineup includes dinosaur rockers Aerosmith, the Who's Roger Daltrey and the Wailers reggae band.

Analysts expect Redwood City-based Oracle, one of the world's leading commercial software suppliers, to use the event to introduce new products in its Fusion line, which incorporates application software and middleware from Oracle's previous acquisitions of BEA Systems and other companies.

But it's clear that Oracle also hopes to build momentum behind the pending Sun deal, which Ellison has touted as a major opportunity to expand beyond software, by combining Sun's high-end hardware into integrated systems for corporate and government data centers. Along with McNealy, other scheduled speakers include James Gosling, who created Sun's widely used Java programming language, and John Fowler, Sun's executive vice president for systems.

While it's not unusual for executives from other companies to speak at OpenWorld, organizers are giving unusual prominence to Sun, said industry analyst Kenneth Chin, who follows Oracle for the Gartner research firm.

"It's focused on keeping Sun in front of users and helping shore up the Sun customer base," added Chin, who noted that competing vendors such as HP and IBM have tried to lure away Sun customers by exploiting uncertainty over the pending deal.

Oracle had hoped to complete the Sun acquisition by now, after announcing the deal in April, but European regulators are withholding approval while they look into concerns that it could stifle competition in the database software market.

Though less momentous, meanwhile, Benioff's appearance is notable because it will be his first presentation at OpenWorld since launching his company in 1998. Benioff previously worked at Oracle and Ellison was an early investor inSalesforce.com., but in recent years the two have been fierce competitors.

Even so, many customers use Oracle's database program along with software applications fromSalesforce.com., said Bruce Francis, vice president for strategy at the latter company. He said Benioff's presentation, which comes at Oracle's invitation, will stress that the two firms have a "multifaceted relationship" and a "joint mission of making our customers very successful."

urn:contentItem:60VN-YVB1-DY7P-T42M-00000-00Oracle Wins Bid for TikTok Following Executive Order2020-09-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:39ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Oracle Wins Bid for TikTok Following Executive OrderLuke Garcia

TikTok logo / Photo by play.google.com

It was announced on Sunday that Oracle Corporation won the bidding for the U.S. operations of the video sharing app, TikTok. This does not mean that Oracle will have majority ownership of the app, but they will have control of TikTok in America which includes over 100 million users.

The rushed sale was prompted by an executive order signed by President Donald Trump stating that TikTok had to sell its U.S. operations to an American company before September 20 or the app would be blocked in the U.S. TikTok was seen as a security threat to the U.S. because of the way that it stores user information along with the parent company of the app, ByteDance, being a Chinese company.

The official White House website addressed the "threat" of TikTok and the executive order. Here is an excerpt of theirexplanation of why they believe it may be unsafe for Americans to use the Chinese video-sharing app: 

TikTok automatically captures vast swaths of information from its users, including Internet and other network activity information such as location data and browsing and search histories. This data collection threatens to allow the Chinese Communist Party access to Americans' personal and proprietary information - potentially allowing China to track the locations of Federal employees and contractors, build dossiers of personal information for blackmail, and conduct corporate espionage.

The sudden concern for cyber safety by Trump really put ByteDance backed up against a wall. By having to sell U.S. operations before September 20, they were forced to look quickly for a buyer and did not have quite the leverage in the deal that they would have wanted. The way ByteDance chose their buyer also raises questions about their intentions.

Last month, the Chinese government issued new regulations that would prohibit TikTok from selling its technology to a foreign company without their explicit permission. They did this by updating the list of technologies that they have the power to veto from being sold to a foreign country. This list now includes data processing and speech and text recognition, which are used for the TikTok app.

The timing of these new regulations have sparked speculation that the Chinese government might not have been thrilled with the idea of Microsoft obtaining the coveted computer code which would give Microsoft the power to decide what videos are seen by the 100 million U.S. users, among other functions.

Microsoft, who is in the consumer technology industry with products like Xbox, was seen by many industry experts as the most likely buyer of TikTok. There is no question that they have the money, resources and power to clean up any security risks that TikTok may have posed. However, Microsoft made their initial offer, which was rejected, and was never asked to make another. After the somewhat surprising deal struck by Oracle, Microsoft had this to say in astatement: 

We would have made significant changes to ensure the service met the highest standards for security, privacy, online safety, and combating disinformation.

Oracle is known for making software designed for businesses, not consumers. This leaves some experts scratching their heads at this move. According toUSA Today, Jefferies Analyst Brent Thill believes Oracle's interest in TikTok is questionable to say the least. He stated that it "does not fit with the rest of the company." He went on to compare it to "Delta Airlines buying a motorcycle company."

Unlike the other big tech executives, Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison is a massive public supporter of President Donald Trump. He was reportedly the first person to recommend Hydroxychloroquine to Trump as a drug to treat COVID-19, despite a lack of scientific proof that it is effective against the virus. Back in February, he even went as far as to host a fundraiser for Trump at his ranch in California.

Trump has said that Oracle "could handle" buying TikTok and that they are a "great company" but when asked to state his preference between Oracle and Microsoft as buyers he declined to answer. This relationship between Trump and Ellison begs the question of if the executive order was implemented to assist Ellison and his company in acquiring TikTok's U.S. operations.

Although, by placing the executive order, Trump's intentions to eliminate any security risk with the app seem reasonable, since over 100 million Americans use TikTok (and that number is growing fast). It just seems like a peculiar coincidence that he placed this executive order, forcing an American tech company to run TikTok or else the country is not allowed to use it, and then it ends up in the hands of one of his corporate buddies.

This sale changes the tech landscape in the U.S. Microsoft being pushed to the side is not something that they are used to. It is especially confounding since Oracle is not in the consumer tech business whatsoever. The deal certainly raises as many questions as it answers.

Whether the Chinese and American governments influenced this deal or not, Oracle ended up as the winner here and they now have control of the hottest video-sharing/social media app on the planet. TikTok has the extraordinary capability to jump-start the careers of many "influencers" into the entertainment industry. The app spreads popular content like wildfire causing the simplest of videos to go viral and boost teenagers and young adults into stardom.

For questions/comments about this story, email arts@thewhitonline.com or tweet@TheWhitOnline.

urn:contentItem:5S0C-8PG1-JBHT-D4XP-00000-00Orange County Votes To Join Feds To Oppose California's Sanctuary Law; Federal Safety Investigators Examine Another Fatal Tesla Crash2018-03-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:39ZLexisNexisOrange County Votes To Join Feds To Oppose California's Sanctuary Law; Federal Safety Investigators Examine Another Fatal Tesla CrashLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, March 28th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Technology tanks stocks, the major indices tumbled yesterday, weighed down by major tech names facing concerns over new regulatory scrutiny.

The Dow Industrial down 345 points, 1-1/2 percent, the NASDAQ 211 points yesterday, that was almost three percent yesterday. Among the big losers, Facebook, Alphabet, Apple, which all turned negative for the year. The news comes as Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg reportedly agrees now to testify before lawmakers on Capitol Hill. Markets this morning are bouncing on the heels of that loss yesterday. Dow Industrials now at the high of the morning, up almost 70 points, up a quarter of a percent higher. The S&P and the NASDAQ also in positive territory. We are waiting on the final reading of the fourth quarter GDP. It is due out in 30 minutes time. Economists are expecting growth of 2.7 percent for the fourth quarter. In Europe this morning, right across the board although here too off of the lows. FT-100 just slipped into positive territory. It's up two points right now and the CAC quarante is down 32, two-thirds of a percent, the DAX index is down 61, that's one-half of one percent, off of the lows. In Asia overnight, steep declines across the board. Worst performers were Hong Kong and Japan and Korea, down 2-1/2 percent on the Hang Seng. The global selloff comes amid a possible crackdown, speculation is mounting that the White House is considering regulating Chinese investments in technology companies. Senator Lindsey Graham weighed in on taking action against China.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: There's still everything you bring to China, they manipulate the currency, they dump steel below market value into the world economy and Trump said during the campaign, he was going to push back. He has. And if the French and the Germans were smart, they would join President Trump to change Chinese business practices.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The major implications for technology and the markets coming up this morning. New problems for Tesla. The details as the National Transportation Safety Board investigates yet another fatal crash. And too slow, the FBI Director Christopher Wray finally responds. He says he will double the number of personnel assigned to reviewing the GOP's request for documents in the investigation of the Clinton e-mail investigation as well as the FBI abuse and the firing of Andrew McCabe. What you need to know coming up this morning. Saudi Arabia bets on solar. The major investment the country is making with SoftBank on a solar park in the kingdom. Plus, too sexy for the aisle? Why Wal-Mart is removing cosmopolitan magazine from the checkout lanes. All those stories are coming up this Wednesday morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Benchmark Managing Partner Kevin Kelly, and the Wall Street Journal Editorial Board Member, Fox News Contributor, Mary Kissel. Great show so far, you guys.

MARY KISSEL, EDITORIAL BOARD MEMBER, WALL STREET JOURNAL: Great to be here, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you. Good morning.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, KELLY AND COMPANY: And we haven't covered the Kim Jong-un meeting as much I would figured because I figure this is a really big turning point in the relations between China and the United States, given the fact that, you know, the South China Sea is a big contentious issue, what's going on with Japan. I mean, I think this is a bigger deal than it's actually being played out.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes. I don't know about that, Kevin. Maybe I'm just cynical because I've been covering this story for so long both in Asia and here in the United States. And I am telling you, I am really glad that President Trump is keeping the pressure up on North Korea. That's exactly the right thing to do. It's the only reason that they're coming to the table. But the idea that they're somehow going to voluntarily give up nuclear weapons, that is a fantasy, an absolute fantasy.

BARTIROMO: I think so. Good op-ed in the Journal today by Robert Zoellick.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Top 10 Tips for Negotiating With Kim Jongu Un.

MCDOWELL: Thank you for saying that because I was just accused by one of the viewers of being grouchy and grumpy this morning.

KISSEL: No.

MCDOWELL: No, pragmatic. That's what I call it.

(CROSSTALK)

KISSEL: Well, let's learn some history here.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Believe nothing that Kim Jong-un says.

KISSEL: Republicans, Democrats, both sides of the aisle, they have appeased this country for decades. Look at where it's gotten us.

BARTIROMO: We're going to talk more about this this morning and we kick it off this hour right now with this top story. Investors are watching a possible crackdown by the Trump administration on Chinese investments in U.S. technology companies. This coming as President Trump seals his first trade deal with South Korea. Adam Shapiro covering the story at the White House right now with the very latest. Adam, good morning to you.

ADAM SHAPIRO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: And a good morning to you, Maria. When President Trump last week signed the memorandum authorizing the United States trade representative to come up with a list of potential items for tariffs in regards to China, the administration also talked about enhancing the ability of the Committee on Foreign Investments in the United States, CFIUS over the Treasury Department to also crackdown on what the administration calls the theft of intellectual property and the forced transfer of technology to Chinese corporations. Well, yesterday it was apparent that one of the negotiating areas that's going on between Treasury and China could possibly limit or end investment from China into technology companies in the United States on technology which is still emerging, and that was something that upset investors. Wilbur Ross from the Commerce Department actually talked about what is on the table and here's what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WILBUR ROSS, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF COMMERCE: There will be limitations on foreign investment. As you know, the entity that regulates foreign investment. As you know, CFIUS which is the entity that regulates foreign investment has new legislation pending both in the House and in the Senate. So that will be part of it. And then some other action by the President will be the other part of it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAPIRO: And Maria, of course, the administration is touting the success of its negotiations with South Korea. We will limit imports of South Korean steel. It will be 70 percent of an average of their production over the last three years as well as increasing the number of U.S. cars that can be exported to South Korea. Right now, every manufacture can export up to 25,000 cars. It will go to 50,000 cars. Critics point out that no manufacturer in the United States has exported more than 11,000 cars in any given year to Korea -- to South Korea at least but the administration is calling this a victory. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Adam. Thanks. We will watch that. Adam Shapiro at the White House. I want to turn now over the uproar over the census. At least 12 states now say they will sue the Trump administration to block the administration from adding a question about citizenship to the 2020 census. The Commerce Department says the question will help determine possible violations of the Voting Rights Act and protect minority voting rights. But Democrats say it amounts to a "craven attack on our democracy. Joining me right now is the host of "MICHELLE MALKIN INVESTIGATES", CRTV.com, Michelle Malkin. Michelle, good to see you.

MICHELLE MALKIN, POLITICAL COMMENTATR: You too, Maria. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Why are Democrats so up in arms about this? It seems logical to have that question in there.

MALKIN: It does. And I think to most people in fly-over countries, the idea of a country asking who is in it is something that should be basic. But only in America will a Federal government get sued by states for asking that basic question. It is bizarre. What it really is about is a power grab. It's about control over the electoral landscape because the census is used to divvy up seats in the House based on a proportion of the head count. And then of course, it doesn't just affect those Congressional districts because the Electoral College uses the size of Congressional districts as well as a gauge. And the thing that I think people are missing in terms of context here is that dating back to the Carter administration, the open borders lobby has used the annual census as an argument to freeze immigration rates and ICE actions at worksites. That was the policy officially under Clinton. It was the unspoken policy through the Obama administration as well. And what's happened is that you have a Trump administration now that has showed at every level that it is serious about immigration enforcement and finally for the first time when the next census is taken, they are not going to be in charge and in control. They do not have the reins. It's a $3 billion industry, if you think about it. That's what the census budget is. I think people's minds would be blown if they've know that. And it's been a slush fund for a number of left wing groups that are used as the census workers to go out there and pound the pavement and do these questionnaires.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Michelle, I mean, you also have to be just, you know, shocked at what's going on in California. I don't know -- I don't know about shocked but I mean, it's just a stunner. Officials in Orange County, California voting to join a lawsuit fighting the state's sanctuary city laws hours after the county sheriff's department announced it will publicly list release dates of inmate including those in the country illegally. Here's what vice chairman of the county's board of supervisors told me about the moves earlier on the program. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SHAWN NELSON, ORANGE COUNTY SUPERVISOR: The board took action basically to stand up for the people of Orange County, stand up for the sheriff and let California know that despite their desires to release criminals into our neighborhoods under the guise of being kind, that we weren't going to tolerate that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Your reaction, Michelle?

MALKIN: Well, there is somewhat of a new opt-out movement in California. I don't know if it's too little too late. But there are still pockets of sanity. Orange County is one of them, certain regions in San Diego County as well. We've already heard from a couple of localities including Los Alamitos that are moving to pass ordinances to defy the sanctuary status. Remember, there were three bills that were passed and signed by Jerry Brown. One of them dealt with worksite enforcement. And the state basically ordering private employers not to allow ICE onto their premises which is just astounding that this is even legal. And then the other two dealing with detention and as the law enforcement officer just mentioned about being able to notify the public when criminal illegal aliens are about to be released, if they're not going to be picked up by ICE. So you have an anti-sanctuary sanctuary movement. Again, I wonder if it's too little too late and really the bottom line is, if these outlaw counties and cities in places like San Francisco are not prosecuted for breaking our immigration laws, for aiding and abetting illegal aliens, how does it stop.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. No. I think this is -- this is really a stunning story and we will of course be watching it. Let me ask you about the FBI news because finally the director of the FBI, Christopher Wray responds to the subpoena which we told you about a week ago. Now Wray says he will double the number of staff members combing through documents to comply with the request from Republicans for records on the investigation into the Hillary Clinton e-mail server. This move comes just days after House Judiciary Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte subpoenaed the Justice Department to get those documents. Here's what Goodlatte first told me about obtaining the records right before he issued that subpoena.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. BOB GOODLATTE (R-VA), CHAIRMAN, HOUSE COMMITTEE ON THE JUDICIARY: We need to have those documents. The Department and the Bureau have been slow, I would say now very slow in getting them to us. The last time I was on your program I expressed confidence that we would have those documents forthcoming. Here we are several weeks later, still don't have them. So this is coming to a head.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So, it is coming to a head. And Christopher Wray now has responded and he agrees, it's been slow.

MALKIN: Yes. Thanks a lot. You know, the F in the FBI has always stood for foot-dragging when it comes to document production in FOIA request, public records request. This is something that the I.G. of the DOJ currently, Michael Horowitz pointed out under the Obama administration. They did it with fast and furious, they did it with the IRS investigation and hide -- the hide and seek and run out the clock have been their M.O. So finally you actually have somebody in FBI brass who is acknowledging that. But it took a long time, didn't it?

BARTIROMO: Well, we don't have the documents yet. So, let's not, you know, jump the gun here.

KELLY: Yes, the Saudis are capitulating doing a deal with the Russians on a 10 to 20 year cooperation. But, Jeff, I'm more interested in this Toyota RAV4 situation that you would brought up. The best-selling sort of mini- crossover, is there any indication why?

FLOCK: Isn't that amazing.

KELLY: Yes, is there any indication why that is? Have you gotten any color on that?

FLOCK: Well, people -- especially with the gas prices as they are and, of course, RAV4 gets pretty good mileage anyway. You know, people have just gone away from cars. There's plenty more room in these vehicles, if you've got kids, whatever you're doing, the SUVs work, you know? It's the station wagon of the new age.

MCDOWELL: Mama McDowell -- Mama McDowell, can sum up in one sentence why people buy SUVs and pickup trucks. I can see out of it that's why people buy them.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: They don't like little cars.

FLOCK: Thinking high, they like to be high.

MCDOWELL: Yes, I'm flying high and I can see -(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Rather than sitting deep into a Sevan. That's absolutely right. Jeff, thank you.

FLOCK: Like always great.

BARTIROMO: Jeff Flock at the International Auto Show in New York.

Coming up final thoughts from the officer panel. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: All right, final thoughts of officer panel. Kevin Kelly.

KELLY: Earning season is going to be -- do very well. It's coming up in the next couple of weeks. We'll hear from bank first. That's going to lead the rally higher.

BARTIROMO: 60 percent earnings good, (INAUDIBLE) Mary.

KISSEL: Yes that's true. And I just want to make a quick note about trade, Maria. The White House is going to come out and really try to sell this deal with South Korea. Don't buy it, they're going to talk about the trade deficit. As if it's a problem. It's not, this is not a market opening. This is managed trade, it's the wrong way to go. Sorry (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: Wow, you are not liking that deal.

KISSEL: I don't.

KELLY: Kissel the missile.

MCDOWELL: And this real quickly, thank you to John Paul Stevens, former Supreme Court Justice. For actually proving to people who believe in the second amendment. That the left does want to take it away. Give me a pickup truck with a Gun Rock.

BARTIROMO: Wow, Dagen McDowell, whacking it up. All right, Dagen, Mary, great to see everybody. Thank you so much. Kevin, (INAUDIBLE) take it away.

KELLY: I will. Thanks, Maria. Crunch time the big tech. They led the market rally.

END

urn:contentItem:5S0C-8PG1-JBHT-D4YF-00000-00Orange County Votes To Join Feds To Oppose California's Sanctuary Law; Federal Safety Investigators Examine Another Fatal Tesla Crash2018-03-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:39ZLexisNexisOrange County Votes To Join Feds To Oppose California's Sanctuary Law; Federal Safety Investigators Examine Another Fatal Tesla CrashLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, March 28th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Technology tanks stocks, the major indices tumbled yesterday, weighed down by major tech names facing concerns over new regulatory scrutiny.

The Dow Industrial down 345 points, 1-1/2 percent, the NASDAQ 211 points yesterday, that was almost three percent yesterday. Among the big losers, Facebook, Alphabet, Apple, which all turned negative for the year. The news comes as Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg reportedly agrees now to testify before lawmakers on Capitol Hill. Markets this morning are bouncing on the heels of that loss yesterday. Dow Industrials now at the high of the morning, up almost 70 points, up a quarter of a percent higher. The S&P and the NASDAQ also in positive territory. We are waiting on the final reading of the fourth quarter GDP. It is due out in 30 minutes time. Economists are expecting growth of 2.7 percent for the fourth quarter. In Europe this morning, right across the board although here too off of the lows. FT-100 just slipped into positive territory. It's up two points right now and the CAC quarante is down 32, two-thirds of a percent, the DAX index is down 61, that's one-half of one percent, off of the lows. In Asia overnight, steep declines across the board. Worst performers were Hong Kong and Japan and Korea, down 2-1/2 percent on the Hang Seng. The global selloff comes amid a possible crackdown, speculation is mounting that the White House is considering regulating Chinese investments in technology companies. Senator Lindsey Graham weighed in on taking action against China.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: There's still everything you bring to China, they manipulate the currency, they dump steel below market value into the world economy and Trump said during the campaign, he was going to push back. He has. And if the French and the Germans were smart, they would join President Trump to change Chinese business practices.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The major implications for technology and the markets coming up this morning. New problems for Tesla. The details as the National Transportation Safety Board investigates yet another fatal crash. And too slow, the FBI Director Christopher Wray finally responds. He says he will double the number of personnel assigned to reviewing the GOP's request for documents in the investigation of the Clinton e-mail investigation as well as the FBI abuse and the firing of Andrew McCabe. What you need to know coming up this morning. Saudi Arabia bets on solar. The major investment the country is making with SoftBank on a solar park in the kingdom. Plus, too sexy for the aisle? Why Wal-Mart is removing cosmopolitan magazine from the checkout lanes. All those stories are coming up this Wednesday morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Benchmark Managing Partner Kevin Kelly, and the Wall Street Journal Editorial Board Member, Fox News Contributor, Mary Kissel. Great show so far, you guys.

MARY KISSEL, EDITORIAL BOARD MEMBER, WALL STREET JOURNAL: Great to be here, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you. Good morning.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, KELLY AND COMPANY: And we haven't covered the Kim Jong-un meeting as much I would figured because I figure this is a really big turning point in the relations between China and the United States, given the fact that, you know, the South China Sea is a big contentious issue, what's going on with Japan. I mean, I think this is a bigger deal than it's actually being played out.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes. I don't know about that, Kevin. Maybe I'm just cynical because I've been covering this story for so long both in Asia and here in the United States. And I am telling you, I am really glad that President Trump is keeping the pressure up on North Korea. That's exactly the right thing to do. It's the only reason that they're coming to the table. But the idea that they're somehow going to voluntarily give up nuclear weapons, that is a fantasy, an absolute fantasy.

BARTIROMO: I think so. Good op-ed in the Journal today by Robert Zoellick.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Top 10 Tips for Negotiating With Kim Jongu Un.

MCDOWELL: Thank you for saying that because I was just accused by one of the viewers of being grouchy and grumpy this morning.

KISSEL: No.

MCDOWELL: No, pragmatic. That's what I call it.

(CROSSTALK)

KISSEL: Well, let's learn some history here.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Believe nothing that Kim Jong-un says.

KISSEL: Republicans, Democrats, both sides of the aisle, they have appeased this country for decades. Look at where it's gotten us.

BARTIROMO: We're going to talk more about this this morning and we kick it off this hour right now with this top story. Investors are watching a possible crackdown by the Trump administration on Chinese investments in U.S. technology companies. This coming as President Trump seals his first trade deal with South Korea. Adam Shapiro covering the story at the White House right now with the very latest. Adam, good morning to you.

ADAM SHAPIRO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: And a good morning to you, Maria. When President Trump last week signed the memorandum authorizing the United States trade representative to come up with a list of potential items for tariffs in regards to China, the administration also talked about enhancing the ability of the Committee on Foreign Investments in the United States, CFIUS over the Treasury Department to also crackdown on what the administration calls the theft of intellectual property and the forced transfer of technology to Chinese corporations. Well, yesterday it was apparent that one of the negotiating areas that's going on between Treasury and China could possibly limit or end investment from China into technology companies in the United States on technology which is still emerging, and that was something that upset investors. Wilbur Ross from the Commerce Department actually talked about what is on the table and here's what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WILBUR ROSS, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF COMMERCE: There will be limitations on foreign investment. As you know, the entity that regulates foreign investment. As you know, CFIUS which is the entity that regulates foreign investment has new legislation pending both in the House and in the Senate. So that will be part of it. And then some other action by the President will be the other part of it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAPIRO: And Maria, of course, the administration is touting the success of its negotiations with South Korea. We will limit imports of South Korean steel. It will be 70 percent of an average of their production over the last three years as well as increasing the number of U.S. cars that can be exported to South Korea. Right now, every manufacture can export up to 25,000 cars. It will go to 50,000 cars. Critics point out that no manufacturer in the United States has exported more than 11,000 cars in any given year to Korea -- to South Korea at least but the administration is calling this a victory. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Adam. Thanks. We will watch that. Adam Shapiro at the White House. I want to turn now over the uproar over the census. At least 12 states now say they will sue the Trump administration to block the administration from adding a question about citizenship to the 2020 census. The Commerce Department says the question will help determine possible violations of the Voting Rights Act and protect minority voting rights. But Democrats say it amounts to a "craven attack on our democracy. Joining me right now is the host of "MICHELLE MALKIN INVESTIGATES", CRTV.com, Michelle Malkin. Michelle, good to see you.

MICHELLE MALKIN, POLITICAL COMMENTATR: You too, Maria. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Why are Democrats so up in arms about this? It seems logical to have that question in there.

MALKIN: It does. And I think to most people in fly-over countries, the idea of a country asking who is in it is something that should be basic. But only in America will a Federal government get sued by states for asking that basic question. It is bizarre. What it really is about is a power grab. It's about control over the electoral landscape because the census is used to divvy up seats in the House based on a proportion of the head count. And then of course, it doesn't just affect those Congressional districts because the Electoral College uses the size of Congressional districts as well as a gauge. And the thing that I think people are missing in terms of context here is that dating back to the Carter administration, the open borders lobby has used the annual census as an argument to freeze immigration rates and ICE actions at worksites. That was the policy officially under Clinton. It was the unspoken policy through the Obama administration as well. And what's happened is that you have a Trump administration now that has showed at every level that it is serious about immigration enforcement and finally for the first time when the next census is taken, they are not going to be in charge and in control. They do not have the reins. It's a $3 billion industry, if you think about it. That's what the census budget is. I think people's minds would be blown if they've know that. And it's been a slush fund for a number of left wing groups that are used as the census workers to go out there and pound the pavement and do these questionnaires.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Michelle, I mean, you also have to be just, you know, shocked at what's going on in California. I don't know -- I don't know about shocked but I mean, it's just a stunner. Officials in Orange County, California voting to join a lawsuit fighting the state's sanctuary city laws hours after the county sheriff's department announced it will publicly list release dates of inmate including those in the country illegally. Here's what vice chairman of the county's board of supervisors told me about the moves earlier on the program. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SHAWN NELSON, ORANGE COUNTY SUPERVISOR: The board took action basically to stand up for the people of Orange County, stand up for the sheriff and let California know that despite their desires to release criminals into our neighborhoods under the guise of being kind, that we weren't going to tolerate that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Your reaction, Michelle?

MALKIN: Well, there is somewhat of a new opt-out movement in California. I don't know if it's too little too late. But there are still pockets of sanity. Orange County is one of them, certain regions in San Diego County as well. We've already heard from a couple of localities including Los Alamitos that are moving to pass ordinances to defy the sanctuary status. Remember, there were three bills that were passed and signed by Jerry Brown. One of them dealt with worksite enforcement. And the state basically ordering private employers not to allow ICE onto their premises which is just astounding that this is even legal. And then the other two dealing with detention and as the law enforcement officer just mentioned about being able to notify the public when criminal illegal aliens are about to be released, if they're not going to be picked up by ICE. So you have an anti-sanctuary sanctuary movement. Again, I wonder if it's too little too late and really the bottom line is, if these outlaw counties and cities in places like San Francisco are not prosecuted for breaking our immigration laws, for aiding and abetting illegal aliens, how does it stop.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. No. I think this is -- this is really a stunning story and we will of course be watching it. Let me ask you about the FBI news because finally the director of the FBI, Christopher Wray responds to the subpoena which we told you about a week ago. Now Wray says he will double the number of staff members combing through documents to comply with the request from Republicans for records on the investigation into the Hillary Clinton e-mail server. This move comes just days after House Judiciary Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte subpoenaed the Justice Department to get those documents. Here's what Goodlatte first told me about obtaining the records right before he issued that subpoena.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. BOB GOODLATTE (R-VA), CHAIRMAN, HOUSE COMMITTEE ON THE JUDICIARY: We need to have those documents. The Department and the Bureau have been slow, I would say now very slow in getting them to us. The last time I was on your program I expressed confidence that we would have those documents forthcoming. Here we are several weeks later, still don't have them. So this is coming to a head.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So, it is coming to a head. And Christopher Wray now has responded and he agrees, it's been slow.

MALKIN: Yes. Thanks a lot. You know, the F in the FBI has always stood for foot-dragging when it comes to document production in FOIA request, public records request. This is something that the I.G. of the DOJ currently, Michael Horowitz pointed out under the Obama administration. They did it with fast and furious, they did it with the IRS investigation and hide -- the hide and seek and run out the clock have been their M.O. So finally you actually have somebody in FBI brass who is acknowledging that. But it took a long time, didn't it?

BARTIROMO: Well, we don't have the documents yet. So, let's not, you know, jump the gun here.

MALKIN: True. Yes, that's right.

BARTIROMO: But it is pretty extraordinary that they would just blow-off the committee that has jurisdiction over them for so long and not produce these documents, especially since the documents that we've had already have, you know, shown all of these text messages that explain to us and shown us the bias at the top of the FBI. So, without the 3,000 pages we would not have known that. And without the I.G. report, Michael Horowitz.

MALKIN: Yes. That's right. Which I think it points to the fact that there's so much more here and, you know, we've heard the cliche tip of -- tip of the iceberg. And -- but that is, you know, anybody who is a journalist who had to file public records requests know even at the local level that public records acts are really seen as subvert the public and so obviously, you know, you multiply that by thousands for the FBI. I mean, there are ongoing public records requests that have -- you know, date back to 20, 25 years. And thank god we have good watchdog groups like Judicial Watch out there fighting these battles for us, you know, outside of the Congressional Committees as well.

BARTIROMO: Michelle, thanks for weighing in on all that. Great to see you.

MALKIN: You too. Take care.

BARTIROMO: Michelle Malkin joining us there. Coming up, SoftBank and Saudi Arabia teaming up again, now to build the world's largest solar park. We break down the $200-billion deal, they signed a memorandum of understanding last night. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Futures erasing early losses. A complete turnaround here, Dow Industrials now expected to be up about 90 points on the session when the market opens in about an hour and 15 minutes. So we're looking at money moving into stocks after that tough selloff yesterday. Meanwhile, a fatal crash of a Tesla Model X in California prompting a Federal investigation. Cheryl Casone with the story now. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, Maria. The National Transportation Safety Board says it's conducting a field investigation to determine whether the vehicle's semi-automated driving system was actually engaged. The driver died when the Model X SUV struck a barrier and caught fire on a highway last week. Shares of Tesla plunged more than eight percent yesterday as you can see on your screen, 279.18. This morning the company's stock is lower in the premarket by more than two percent. Well, Saudi Arabia turning to solar power in a big way. They've teamed up with SoftBank to build the biggest solar park in the world. SoftBank's founder Masayoshi Son and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman sitting there with you, Maria, has signed a preliminary agreement for the $200-billion project. They did this yesterday here in New York. The venture is going to create as many as 100,000 jobs and generate enough electricity to power 150 million homes. It's part of the Prince's plan to reduce Saudi Arabia's dependence on oil. Shares of SoftBank have lost four percent so far this year.

Well, actor Corey Feldman says that he was stabbed last night. Feldman post a picture to Twitter about an hour or so ago saying that three men pulled up and one attack him while he was sitting in his car. Here's what he tweeted. I'm in the hospital. I was attacked tonight. A man opened my car door and stabbed me with something. Please say prayers for us. Well, security was distracted a guy in a car pulled up and attacked. I'm OK. According to Feldman, the LAPD is investigation the alleged as an attempted homicide. He believes the attack could be connected to a number of threats made to him on social media. Feldman has been outspoken for years actually against alleged sexual predators in Hollywood. Predators that go after young actors like himself at one point in his life.

Well, Wal-Mart has decided to ban cosmopolitan from the checkout line at its stores. The National Center on Sexual Exploitation is actually claiming credit for this, saying Wal-Mart made the decision following conversations that they had with the organization. The magazine is famous for its sexy covers and giving out love and sex advice to women but the NCSC calls it pornography and has been lobbying Wal-Mart to remove it from the sight of children. Cosmo has logged in the most profitable title for publisher Hearse, maybe there's a reason for that. Shares of Wal-Mart slightly higher in the premarket, Maria. Pornography. Come on.

BARTIROMO: This is crazy.

CASONE: Really.

BARTIROMO: Removing Cosmopolitan from the aisles, what do you think?

KISSEL: I don't know. They do run some kind of racy topics, don't they?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KISSEL: Because I'm a regular reader of Cosmo --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: -- for the 70s.

KISSEL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And then there's this. Mark Zuckerberg, guys, he will reportedly testify before Congress on the Facebook data scandal. How the social media company responds to the scrutiny from Washington, next. And then the iPad gets a reboot. The high-tech features from the new Apple device that's under $300 for students. Wait until you see it, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We are watching Facebook this morning. The company announced this morning new privacy features allowing users to download and delete data, should they want to. This comes after CEO Mark Zuckerberg reportedly agreed yesterday to testify before Congress over the company's data practices. The Senate Judiciary Committee wants him questioned. The stock is now in bare market territory of notice, trading higher right now, it is down 20 percent from the most recent high which was on February 1st. The stock yesterday was down five percent. This morning it's bouncing about one percent. Joining us right now GBH Insights Chief Strategy Officer and head of technology research Daniel Ives. Dan, good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

DANIEL IVES, CHIEF STRATEGY OFFICER, GBH INSIGHTS: Great to be here.

IVES: You still like Facebook stock. You're bullish on the stock despite?

IVES: Yes. I mean, look, this has been the darkest chapter for Zuckerberg in Facebook's 14-year history. But we view it -- as what's really baked into the stock is a draconian type of regulatory environment. If you think it's anything less caught slight to modest in our opinion, this is a significant buying opportunity. If you can navigate through these dark clouds that are going to become over the coming weeks and months for Facebook and Zuckerberg.

(CROSSTALK)

KELLY: I have a hard time with that given the fact that there's so much uncertainty. And one of the things that we don't know, what's going to happen to management?
