urn:contentItem:5S01-3W51-DXH2-64DM-00000-00Orange County Votes To Join Feds To Oppose California's Sanctuary Law; Federal Safety Investigators Examine Another Fatal Tesla Crash2018-03-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:39ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTKevin Kelly, Daniel Ives, Glenn HubbardNEWSFinancial032803cb.231Orange County Votes To Join Feds To Oppose California's Sanctuary Law; Federal Safety Investigators Examine Another Fatal Tesla CrashMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Adam Shapiro, Mary Kissel, Nicole Petallides, Stuart Varney

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, March 28th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Technology tanks stocks, the major indices tumbled yesterday, weighed down by major tech names facing concerns over new regulatory scrutiny.

The Dow Industrial down 345 points, 1-1/2 percent, the NASDAQ 211 points yesterday, that was almost three percent yesterday. Among the big losers, Facebook, Alphabet, Apple, which all turned negative for the year. The news comes as Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg reportedly agrees now to testify before lawmakers on Capitol Hill. Markets this morning are bouncing on the heels of that loss yesterday. Dow Industrials now at the high of the morning, up almost 70 points, up a quarter of a percent higher. The S&P and the NASDAQ also in positive territory. We are waiting on the final reading of the fourth quarter GDP. It is due out in 30 minutes time. Economists are expecting growth of 2.7 percent for the fourth quarter. In Europe this morning, right across the board although here too off of the lows. FT-100 just slipped into positive territory. It's up two points right now and the CAC quarante is down 32, two-thirds of a percent, the DAX index is down 61, that's one-half of one percent, off of the lows. In Asia overnight, steep declines across the board. Worst performers were Hong Kong and Japan and Korea, down 2-1/2 percent on the Hang Seng. The global selloff comes amid a possible crackdown, speculation is mounting that the White House is considering regulating Chinese investments in technology companies. Senator Lindsey Graham weighed in on taking action against China.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: There's still everything you bring to China, they manipulate the currency, they dump steel below market value into the world economy and Trump said during the campaign, he was going to push back. He has. And if the French and the Germans were smart, they would join President Trump to change Chinese business practices.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The major implications for technology and the markets coming up this morning. New problems for Tesla. The details as the National Transportation Safety Board investigates yet another fatal crash. And too slow, the FBI Director Christopher Wray finally responds. He says he will double the number of personnel assigned to reviewing the GOP's request for documents in the investigation of the Clinton e-mail investigation as well as the FBI abuse and the firing of Andrew McCabe. What you need to know coming up this morning. Saudi Arabia bets on solar. The major investment the country is making with SoftBank on a solar park in the kingdom. Plus, too sexy for the aisle? Why Wal-Mart is removing cosmopolitan magazine from the checkout lanes. All those stories are coming up this Wednesday morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Benchmark Managing Partner Kevin Kelly, and the Wall Street Journal Editorial Board Member, Fox News Contributor, Mary Kissel. Great show so far, you guys.

MARY KISSEL, EDITORIAL BOARD MEMBER, WALL STREET JOURNAL: Great to be here, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you. Good morning.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, KELLY AND COMPANY: And we haven't covered the Kim Jong-un meeting as much I would figured because I figure this is a really big turning point in the relations between China and the United States, given the fact that, you know, the South China Sea is a big contentious issue, what's going on with Japan. I mean, I think this is a bigger deal than it's actually being played out.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes. I don't know about that, Kevin. Maybe I'm just cynical because I've been covering this story for so long both in Asia and here in the United States. And I am telling you, I am really glad that President Trump is keeping the pressure up on North Korea. That's exactly the right thing to do. It's the only reason that they're coming to the table. But the idea that they're somehow going to voluntarily give up nuclear weapons, that is a fantasy, an absolute fantasy.

BARTIROMO: I think so. Good op-ed in the Journal today by Robert Zoellick.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Top 10 Tips for Negotiating With Kim Jongu Un.

MCDOWELL: Thank you for saying that because I was just accused by one of the viewers of being grouchy and grumpy this morning.

KISSEL: No.

MCDOWELL: No, pragmatic. That's what I call it.

(CROSSTALK)

KISSEL: Well, let's learn some history here.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Believe nothing that Kim Jong-un says.

KISSEL: Republicans, Democrats, both sides of the aisle, they have appeased this country for decades. Look at where it's gotten us.

BARTIROMO: We're going to talk more about this this morning and we kick it off this hour right now with this top story. Investors are watching a possible crackdown by the Trump administration on Chinese investments in U.S. technology companies. This coming as President Trump seals his first trade deal with South Korea. Adam Shapiro covering the story at the White House right now with the very latest. Adam, good morning to you.

ADAM SHAPIRO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: And a good morning to you, Maria. When President Trump last week signed the memorandum authorizing the United States trade representative to come up with a list of potential items for tariffs in regards to China, the administration also talked about enhancing the ability of the Committee on Foreign Investments in the United States, CFIUS over the Treasury Department to also crackdown on what the administration calls the theft of intellectual property and the forced transfer of technology to Chinese corporations. Well, yesterday it was apparent that one of the negotiating areas that's going on between Treasury and China could possibly limit or end investment from China into technology companies in the United States on technology which is still emerging, and that was something that upset investors. Wilbur Ross from the Commerce Department actually talked about what is on the table and here's what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WILBUR ROSS, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF COMMERCE: There will be limitations on foreign investment. As you know, the entity that regulates foreign investment. As you know, CFIUS which is the entity that regulates foreign investment has new legislation pending both in the House and in the Senate. So that will be part of it. And then some other action by the President will be the other part of it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAPIRO: And Maria, of course, the administration is touting the success of its negotiations with South Korea. We will limit imports of South Korean steel. It will be 70 percent of an average of their production over the last three years as well as increasing the number of U.S. cars that can be exported to South Korea. Right now, every manufacture can export up to 25,000 cars. It will go to 50,000 cars. Critics point out that no manufacturer in the United States has exported more than 11,000 cars in any given year to Korea -- to South Korea at least but the administration is calling this a victory. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Adam. Thanks. We will watch that. Adam Shapiro at the White House. I want to turn now over the uproar over the census. At least 12 states now say they will sue the Trump administration to block the administration from adding a question about citizenship to the 2020 census. The Commerce Department says the question will help determine possible violations of the Voting Rights Act and protect minority voting rights. But Democrats say it amounts to a "craven attack on our democracy. Joining me right now is the host of "MICHELLE MALKIN INVESTIGATES", CRTV.com, Michelle Malkin. Michelle, good to see you.

MICHELLE MALKIN, POLITICAL COMMENTATR: You too, Maria. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Why are Democrats so up in arms about this? It seems logical to have that question in there.

MALKIN: It does. And I think to most people in fly-over countries, the idea of a country asking who is in it is something that should be basic. But only in America will a Federal government get sued by states for asking that basic question. It is bizarre. What it really is about is a power grab. It's about control over the electoral landscape because the census is used to divvy up seats in the House based on a proportion of the head count. And then of course, it doesn't just affect those Congressional districts because the Electoral College uses the size of Congressional districts as well as a gauge. And the thing that I think people are missing in terms of context here is that dating back to the Carter administration, the open borders lobby has used the annual census as an argument to freeze immigration rates and ICE actions at worksites. That was the policy officially under Clinton. It was the unspoken policy through the Obama administration as well. And what's happened is that you have a Trump administration now that has showed at every level that it is serious about immigration enforcement and finally for the first time when the next census is taken, they are not going to be in charge and in control. They do not have the reins. It's a $3 billion industry, if you think about it. That's what the census budget is. I think people's minds would be blown if they've know that. And it's been a slush fund for a number of left wing groups that are used as the census workers to go out there and pound the pavement and do these questionnaires.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Michelle, I mean, you also have to be just, you know, shocked at what's going on in California. I don't know -- I don't know about shocked but I mean, it's just a stunner. Officials in Orange County, California voting to join a lawsuit fighting the state's sanctuary city laws hours after the county sheriff's department announced it will publicly list release dates of inmate including those in the country illegally. Here's what vice chairman of the county's board of supervisors told me about the moves earlier on the program. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SHAWN NELSON, ORANGE COUNTY SUPERVISOR: The board took action basically to stand up for the people of Orange County, stand up for the sheriff and let California know that despite their desires to release criminals into our neighborhoods under the guise of being kind, that we weren't going to tolerate that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Your reaction, Michelle?

MALKIN: Well, there is somewhat of a new opt-out movement in California. I don't know if it's too little too late. But there are still pockets of sanity. Orange County is one of them, certain regions in San Diego County as well. We've already heard from a couple of localities including Los Alamitos that are moving to pass ordinances to defy the sanctuary status. Remember, there were three bills that were passed and signed by Jerry Brown. One of them dealt with worksite enforcement. And the state basically ordering private employers not to allow ICE onto their premises which is just astounding that this is even legal. And then the other two dealing with detention and as the law enforcement officer just mentioned about being able to notify the public when criminal illegal aliens are about to be released, if they're not going to be picked up by ICE. So you have an anti-sanctuary sanctuary movement. Again, I wonder if it's too little too late and really the bottom line is, if these outlaw counties and cities in places like San Francisco are not prosecuted for breaking our immigration laws, for aiding and abetting illegal aliens, how does it stop.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. No. I think this is -- this is really a stunning story and we will of course be watching it. Let me ask you about the FBI news because finally the director of the FBI, Christopher Wray responds to the subpoena which we told you about a week ago. Now Wray says he will double the number of staff members combing through documents to comply with the request from Republicans for records on the investigation into the Hillary Clinton e-mail server. This move comes just days after House Judiciary Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte subpoenaed the Justice Department to get those documents. Here's what Goodlatte first told me about obtaining the records right before he issued that subpoena.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. BOB GOODLATTE (R-VA), CHAIRMAN, HOUSE COMMITTEE ON THE JUDICIARY: We need to have those documents. The Department and the Bureau have been slow, I would say now very slow in getting them to us. The last time I was on your program I expressed confidence that we would have those documents forthcoming. Here we are several weeks later, still don't have them. So this is coming to a head.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So, it is coming to a head. And Christopher Wray now has responded and he agrees, it's been slow.

MALKIN: Yes. Thanks a lot. You know, the F in the FBI has always stood for foot-dragging when it comes to document production in FOIA request, public records request. This is something that the I.G. of the DOJ currently, Michael Horowitz pointed out under the Obama administration. They did it with fast and furious, they did it with the IRS investigation and hide -- the hide and seek and run out the clock have been their M.O. So finally you actually have somebody in FBI brass who is acknowledging that. But it took a long time, didn't it?

BARTIROMO: Well, we don't have the documents yet. So, let's not, you know, jump the gun here.

MALKIN: True. Yes, that's right.

BARTIROMO: But it is pretty extraordinary that they would just blow-off the committee that has jurisdiction over them for so long and not produce these documents, especially since the documents that we've had already have, you know, shown all of these text messages that explain to us and shown us the bias at the top of the FBI. So, without the 3,000 pages we would not have known that. And without the I.G. report, Michael Horowitz.

MALKIN: Yes. That's right. Which I think it points to the fact that there's so much more here and, you know, we've heard the cliche tip of -- tip of the iceberg. And -- but that is, you know, anybody who is a journalist who had to file public records requests know even at the local level that public records acts are really seen as subvert the public and so obviously, you know, you multiply that by thousands for the FBI. I mean, there are ongoing public records requests that have -- you know, date back to 20, 25 years. And thank god we have good watchdog groups like Judicial Watch out there fighting these battles for us, you know, outside of the Congressional Committees as well.

BARTIROMO: Michelle, thanks for weighing in on all that. Great to see you.

MALKIN: You too. Take care.

BARTIROMO: Michelle Malkin joining us there. Coming up, SoftBank and Saudi Arabia teaming up again, now to build the world's largest solar park. We break down the $200-billion deal, they signed a memorandum of understanding last night. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Futures erasing early losses. A complete turnaround here, Dow Industrials now expected to be up about 90 points on the session when the market opens in about an hour and 15 minutes. So we're looking at money moving into stocks after that tough selloff yesterday. Meanwhile, a fatal crash of a Tesla Model X in California prompting a Federal investigation. Cheryl Casone with the story now. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, Maria. The National Transportation Safety Board says it's conducting a field investigation to determine whether the vehicle's semi-automated driving system was actually engaged. The driver died when the Model X SUV struck a barrier and caught fire on a highway last week. Shares of Tesla plunged more than eight percent yesterday as you can see on your screen, 279.18. This morning the company's stock is lower in the premarket by more than two percent. Well, Saudi Arabia turning to solar power in a big way. They've teamed up with SoftBank to build the biggest solar park in the world. SoftBank's founder Masayoshi Son and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman sitting there with you, Maria, has signed a preliminary agreement for the $200-billion project. They did this yesterday here in New York. The venture is going to create as many as 100,000 jobs and generate enough electricity to power 150 million homes. It's part of the Prince's plan to reduce Saudi Arabia's dependence on oil. Shares of SoftBank have lost four percent so far this year.

Well, actor Corey Feldman says that he was stabbed last night. Feldman post a picture to Twitter about an hour or so ago saying that three men pulled up and one attack him while he was sitting in his car. Here's what he tweeted. I'm in the hospital. I was attacked tonight. A man opened my car door and stabbed me with something. Please say prayers for us. Well, security was distracted a guy in a car pulled up and attacked. I'm OK. According to Feldman, the LAPD is investigation the alleged as an attempted homicide. He believes the attack could be connected to a number of threats made to him on social media. Feldman has been outspoken for years actually against alleged sexual predators in Hollywood. Predators that go after young actors like himself at one point in his life.

Well, Wal-Mart has decided to ban cosmopolitan from the checkout line at its stores. The National Center on Sexual Exploitation is actually claiming credit for this, saying Wal-Mart made the decision following conversations that they had with the organization. The magazine is famous for its sexy covers and giving out love and sex advice to women but the NCSC calls it pornography and has been lobbying Wal-Mart to remove it from the sight of children. Cosmo has logged in the most profitable title for publisher Hearse, maybe there's a reason for that. Shares of Wal-Mart slightly higher in the premarket, Maria. Pornography. Come on.

BARTIROMO: This is crazy.

CASONE: Really.

BARTIROMO: Removing Cosmopolitan from the aisles, what do you think?

KISSEL: I don't know. They do run some kind of racy topics, don't they?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KISSEL: Because I'm a regular reader of Cosmo --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: -- for the 70s.

KISSEL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And then there's this. Mark Zuckerberg, guys, he will reportedly testify before Congress on the Facebook data scandal. How the social media company responds to the scrutiny from Washington, next. And then the iPad gets a reboot. The high-tech features from the new Apple device that's under $300 for students. Wait until you see it, next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We are watching Facebook this morning. The company announced this morning new privacy features allowing users to download and delete data, should they want to. This comes after CEO Mark Zuckerberg reportedly agreed yesterday to testify before Congress over the company's data practices. The Senate Judiciary Committee wants him questioned. The stock is now in bare market territory of notice, trading higher right now, it is down 20 percent from the most recent high which was on February 1st. The stock yesterday was down five percent. This morning it's bouncing about one percent. Joining us right now GBH Insights Chief Strategy Officer and head of technology research Daniel Ives. Dan, good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

DANIEL IVES, CHIEF STRATEGY OFFICER, GBH INSIGHTS: Great to be here.

IVES: You still like Facebook stock. You're bullish on the stock despite?

IVES: Yes. I mean, look, this has been the darkest chapter for Zuckerberg in Facebook's 14-year history. But we view it -- as what's really baked into the stock is a draconian type of regulatory environment. If you think it's anything less caught slight to modest in our opinion, this is a significant buying opportunity. If you can navigate through these dark clouds that are going to become over the coming weeks and months for Facebook and Zuckerberg.

(CROSSTALK)

KELLY: I have a hard time with that given the fact that there's so much uncertainty. And one of the things that we don't know, what's going to happen to management? Will they separate the chairman and CEO role? That's a real possibility. Because Mark Zuckerberg can't even apologize or be held accountable. He was a v victim. They were victims of this, considering the fact that consistently cozied up to advertisers that have done nefarious things on their platform post election. Then all of a sudden you're seeing the multiple compression, right? Right now they're still trading at 25 times earnings. I'm having a hard time buying into your thesis if they go from 25 to 20.

IVES: Look, I mean, there's no doubt. Right now the bear's going to come out of hibernation. I mean -- and you're seeing it. Ultimately we factored if they lose 10 percent advertising revenue up five billion a year. You fact that in, reduce the multiple, ultimately with $10.00 earnings power, 30 percent grower, I view it as a $180 to $190 stock. To your point has the upside been capped as you start to pick up from multiple expansion? No doubt. And this has definitely been -- for Zuckerberg, it's going to be a defining period. When he goes on his sort of (INAUDIBLE) sorry tour in front of Congress and others, that's going to be defining not just for Facebook but for Alphabet, for Twitter. You saw Twitter yesterday for social media peers. So this is really a game-changing fork in the road situation.

MCDOWELL: We should just point out. Twitter's stock fell 12 percent yesterday.

KISSEL: Yes. They're getting slammed.

MCDOWELL: That's a huge haircut for one day.

KISSEL: But there's longer term problems here for Facebook. I mean, Facebook's user growth has been slowing now for a while.

IVES: No doubt. I mean, if you look at user growth, engagement, you get to two billion users, 50 billion in advertising revenue, you're going to hit a point right now where it starts to slow. And that's also why Twitter was starting to get sea legs, Snap continues sort of the up-and-down story. But when you look at Facebook from a fundamental valuation, this is really one way of using heavy-handed regulation, this is a game-changing move and ultimately to --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: You're talking about 30 to 40 percent upside potential for this stock? Is that what you see?

IVES: Oh, yes. I mean, in our --

BARTIROMO: In what time frame?

IVES: In our opinion, over the next year we view this as a 30 percent upside stock. I'm not saying you're not going to (INAUDIBLE) roller coaster over the coming weeks and months.

BARTIROMO: What about the charges? I mean, how much -- how much money is this going to cost Facebook? Doesn't that cut into earnings?

IVES: Yes. And look, when we factored in like in terms of FTC and some of these other fines, if you factor in it's going to be in the hundreds of millions of dollars, that's probably where we see FTC funds some of the class action lawsuits. But there's no doubt, if you look at Facebook right now, this is one of those -- it's a fork in the road. If you think this is the start of just a game-changer to the model and fundamentals, to your point, you don't own the stock.

MCDOWELL: Real quick. Instagram is owned by Facebook, so if Facebook, the social media platform gets hurt, where does the traffic go? Its goes to Instagram and they also on WhatsApp, so that gives them balance.

IVES: And that's -- and that's why even though from advertisers, it sounds great when you say, I'm going to come off Facebook for a week? You put the P.R. out, you feel good. Realistically, where are you going when it comes down online, if it's Faceboook. And ultimately, Amazon is probably a beneficiary on the advertising model. Because remember on FANG stock, Netflix, Amazon are really insulated from regulatory headwinds.

BARTIROMO: you're All right. We will leave it there. Well, you're sticking your neck out, Dan. Thanks.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Daniel Ives there. Coming up, we've got the final reading of the fourth quarter GDP due out in a few minutes. Economists are expecting growth of 2.7 percent. Markets are up going into the numbers. Dow Industrials are expected to be up 90 points. We're watching for any change of that, ahead of the number.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. I'm Maria Bartiromo. It is Wednesday, March 28. Your top stories right now 8:30 a.m. on the East Coast. Stocks looking to rebound. We are waiting on the GDP number out momentarily. The expectations call for growth of 2.7 percent. The number -- 2.9 percent is the number that is better than expected, just hitting the tape. This comes after yesterday's route on Wall Street. Right now, we're looking at Futures up 100 points as the number hits the tape of 2.9 percent growth better than expected. Yesterday, the market was down nearly 400 points. Take a look at the Dow Industrials down 344 points yesterday. 1.5 percent lower, the S&P and the NASDAQ also lower. The NASDAQ hit hard yesterday. Three percent lower. But this morning, we're looking at money moving into stocks and this fourth quarter GDP number right now is actually boosting markets as it is up 2.9 percent. Versus an estimate of 2.7 percent. This market is up fractionally from where we we're going in to the numbers. Dow Industrials expected to be up 114 points at the opening of trading this morning. The S&P and the NASDAQ are mixed right now. NASDAQ is slipping back into negative territory by two points. urn:contentItem:60G8-J5B1-DXH2-60KV-00000-00Oregon Leaders Claim Feds Are Leaving Portland; Is Big Tech Endangering Lives?; Left Using Tragedy For Political Leverage; Trump Supporter Murdered In Broad Daylight; Terry Crews Exposes Hypocrisy Of BLM Movement; Report: Wisconsin School Social Worker Arrested For Assaulting State Senator; Trump: Radical Left Will Kill American Prosperity; Portland Under Siege From Violent Radicals; Acting DHS Chief Hits Back At Oregon Governor's Claim That Fed Agents Are Leaving Portland Tomorrow; Acting Homeland Security Secretary Chad Wolf Is Interviewed On Deploying Federal Law Enforcement Officers To Protect Federal Buildings; Joe Biden Holds Campaign Event In Wilmington, Delaware; Brad Pitt Nominated For Emmy For Playing Dr. Anthony Fauci; Social Media Companies Take Down Video Of Doctors Promoting Use Of Hydroxychloroquine To Treat COVID-192020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:39ZLexisNexisINGRAHAM ANGLE10:00 PM ESTHorace Cooper, Andrew Hitt, Chad Wolf, Raymond Arroyo, Harvey Risch, Stephen SmithNEWSDomestic072901cb.257Oregon Leaders Claim Feds Are Leaving Portland; Is Big Tech Endangering Lives?; Left Using Tragedy For Political Leverage; Trump Supporter Murdered In Broad Daylight; Terry Crews Exposes Hypocrisy Of BLM Movement; Report: Wisconsin School Social Worker Arrested For Assaulting State Senator; Trump: Radical Left Will Kill American Prosperity; Portland Under Siege From Violent Radicals; Acting DHS Chief Hits Back At Oregon Governor's Claim That Fed Agents Are Leaving Portland Tomorrow; Acting Homeland Security Secretary Chad Wolf Is Interviewed On Deploying Federal Law Enforcement Officers To Protect Federal Buildings; Joe Biden Holds Campaign Event In Wilmington, Delaware; Brad Pitt Nominated For Emmy For Playing Dr. Anthony Fauci; Social Media Companies Take Down Video Of Doctors Promoting Use Of Hydroxychloroquine To Treat COVID-19Laura Ingraham

SEAN HANNITY, FOX NEWS HOST: Live free or America dies. Pre-available Hannity.com, amazon.com. We got to take our country back. It lays out everything that is at stake, preserving liberty and freedom and we have a lot of announcement on all this tomorrow night on the show.

Let not your heart be troubled. Laura Ingraham, how are you?

LAURA INGRAHAM, FOX NEWS HOST: Hey. Good. We're talking to the Acting Homeland Security Secretary.

HANNITY: You're speaking to Chad Wolf.

INGRAHAM: Yes.

HANNITY: He's been great. Please - he's been phenomenal.

INGRAHAM: Yes well. The of course the mayor and the governor want to try to say this is a big victory because we're pushing out the Feds but as Trump said if it weren't for the federal presence, that whole courthouse would've been burnt to the ground.

HANNITY: Bye - bye.

INGRAHAM: And so thank goodness we have that. Sean, fantastic show as always.

HANNITY: All right, OK, I'm going to be watching. Thanks so much.

INGRAHAM: OK, thanks so much. I'm Laura Ingraham. This is THE INGRAHAM ANGLE from Washington tonight. Oregon officials as I just said, claim that federal agents are leaving Portland after a deal was struck with the Trump administration but are they lying about that.

Acting DHS Secretary Chad Wolf says yes, he's going to tell us why. Also tonight, the war over hydroxychloroquine found a new battlefield today. A congressional hearing room. Two doctors are going to tell us why Big Tech might be endangering lives and Biden emerges from the bunker but does he know where he actually is?

And an anchor and actor gets an Emmy nomination for three minutes of work, three. Raymond Arroyo explains it in Seen and Unseen but first, do you know his name. That's the focus of tonight's ANGLE.

That question was posed by activists and protesters for weeks after the killing of George Floyd. It was meant to jar the nation into focusing on police brutality and it worked. Floyd's name and visage became synonymous with the suffering that comes from racial injustice.

Of course there were others who simply used his name for their own twisted political agendas as if burning down our cities would bring Mr. Floyd back or solve underlying problems. Of course, it just merely made matters worse and in the intervening weeks since the upheaval in late May, many more African-American families have lost loved ones to violence.

At least 144 have been murdered since June 1 in Chicago alone including these children. Three-year old Mekhi James, one-year-old Sincere Gaston, seven-year-old Natalia Wallace. All shot dead. But unlike with George Floyd, the general public won't remember them because the activists don't find their stories useful and the media also pushing a political agenda, they basically just yawn.

Last week in Milwaukee, a well-known passionate figure in the community, someone who had supported every issue from police reform and other liberal causes but lately he had been holding a homemade protesters-Trump signs. That man was murdered. He also happened to be African-American. He was shot and killed outside his office just after noon while he was sitting in a lawn chair. This happened in broad daylight. Do you know his name? I bet you don't. It's Bernell Trammell.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Saw the cops pull up. The vans, ambulance, firefighters and we sat and watched. They gave CPR for about 15 to 20 minutes.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: Security cameras capture these images of the suspect and police are continuing to investigate but the Milwaukee Central Journal reported just a few days ago that Reggie Moore, director of Milwaukee's Office of Violence Prevention said he recently intervene in a dispute between Trammell and a young man.

Moore thought the incident was related to a Trump sign that Trammell was carrying. And Wisconsin Senator Ron Johnson, a Republican tweeted this on the news of Mr. Trammell's tragic death. " Bernell Trammell was known to many in Milwaukee. My condolences to his family and friends. I hope they get answers and justice soon."

Well, you probably won't be surprised to know that the major networks outside of Fox didn't even mention this horrific murder. Not of peek from CNN, MSNBC, The Washington Post, The New York Times, ABC news, CBS news or NBC. And this led YouTubers to pick up the slack and ask some pretty basic questions.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MONIQUE PETERS, YOUTUBER: I can't for the life of me fathom how it's justified that just because somebody is a Trump supporter, that they get shot down in cold blood when they've never ever done anything to anybody other than express their opinions. I even wonder if the mainstream media is going to give it the amount of coverage that it's given some criminals out there that have died in the streets because they certainly don't give it to children. They don't get the coverage.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: No, they don't. And no one knows their names as I said but those victims are people too like Mr. Trammell was.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The guy was just full of love.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: We had very deep conversations.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: He's just a community figure.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: Tonight THE INGRAHAM ANGLE has exclusive video of Trammell's interactions just days before his murder that may shed light on what was motivating the homicide.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BERNELL TRAMMELL, ACTIVIST: Obama has enough of work. Everybody say healthcare. We can't afford healthcare. We got no money. So Trump at least had whether the will of God or his own inspiration to do something that no President has ever done and that's why he got my vote. If I stood here with a sign saying Trump Trump Soldiers. I get my [BEEP] I get a rock thrown at me at best.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What do you have? No fear. Come love me.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: She just called you disgusting.

TRAMMELL: Well, it ain't right but at the same time we're America. Freedom of expression.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: You know he seemed to truly believe that, didn't he? Well, we have more of that video later in the show but at the very least, it reveals that Mr. Trammell was aware that he could be harmed for his pro-Trump views. Now if this is true, it's absolutely appalling as is the deafening silence from Democrats.

Where's Al Sharpton? Where's Black Lives Matter? A group that Mr. Trammell even supported by the way. But they're nowhere to be found. Apparently, certain black lives do not matter. Let's not forget the left's long history of ignoring vilifying or dehumanizing blacks who disagree. They're called Uncle Toms or race traitors. They're not authentic. Just like Biden said, you're not really black if you're not a Democrat. At least twice in the last few days, MSNBC hosts have proved my point.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Has Donald Trump ever promised you anything financially in exchange for your blind support of this administration or helping his campaign?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: No and I've known him since 2015.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Are you a paid campaign surrogate? Are you being compensated?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You only ask me that because I don't fit your narrative.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: I'd like to turn the question on the anchor and say are you a campaign surrogate paid by the Biden campaign but how insulting is this? How demeaning? You didn't think this way on your own. You couldn't have come to this conclusion on your own using your own intellect. Think about that.

The Democrats and the radical media collaborators have been pulling a con on African Americans for decades. The party of slavery and Jim Crow. The party of segregation and the KKK has worked overtime to cover up its own sins in order once again divide us along racial and ethnic lines.

Now doing so requires that they demonize, disenfranchise, deplatform and dehumanize Americans who disagree. But they know I think that we're on to them and their sick game that more minorities are seeing through their sloganeering about black lives matter when in fact they act like only certain black lives matter.

More decent people I believe are seeing the pathetic failure in leadership in Democrat run cities where black and immigrant owned businesses are destroyed with impunity. Elected official so possessed by anti-Trump hatred that they actually do more to protect the rights of violent protesters than they do the rights of their own law abiding residents.

Now on occasion, a few honest Democrats will speak out as happened in a call with Mayor Lori Lightfoot early last month.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ALD. RAYMOND LOPEZ (D-IL): We have to come up with a better plan because once - my fear is once they're done looting and rioting and whatever's going to happen tonight, what are we going to do and what do we tell our residents other than good faith people stand up. It's not going to be enough.

MAYOR LORI LIGHTFOOT, (D) CHICAGO: Thank you Alderman. Next question.

LOPEZ: No, I want an answer. You commented on everybody. I want an answer.

LIGHTFOOT: I think you're 100 percent. I think you're 100 percent full of s***. That's what I think.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: Did you get that? To a Democrat city Alderman, you're 100 percent full of you know what. It doesn't have to be this way. African-Americans, Latinos, other immigrants who just want what everyone else wants. They want a fair shot. They want decent schools. They want safe streets. They can walk away from the party that's taking them for granted and abuse their trust and support for an agenda that actually will respect their freedom to make their own choices and to believe whatever they want.

Safe streets. Bernell Trammell wasn't killed by a corrupt police officer. He was cut down in the middle of the day after holding a Trump 2020 sign. That was his crime and that's THE ANGLE.

Joining me now is Horace Cooper co-Chair of Project 21 and author of 'How Trump is Making Black America Great Again.' Horace, we don't yet know the motive but this is a well-known community figure in Milwaukee who was assassinated in broad daylight and the media and BLM Al Sharpton and the rest of the gang can't even pretend to care.

HORACE COOPER, CO-CHAIR, PROJECT 21: This is just another example of how they jump to conclusions first and investigate later. The conclusion is Mr. Trammell's life didn't matter. The conclusion is there isn't any instance of any violence being attacked upon or brought upon people because of their political views.

We, you and I, we don't know what the story is. We're open. But it is strange that were the circumstances different, were he an active supporter of Bernie or Biden, it would be shocking if this wasn't front page news. Someone was holding a sign supporting a progressive or left wing candidate and now they're dead, that would be the sign and news that we would hear continuously.

INGRAHAM: Yes Jussie Smollett. Jussie Smollett story was believed immediately that he was beaten up by a bunch -

COOPER: It was too good not to be true.

INGRAHAM: Yes, MAGA hat wearing thugs, white thugs jumped him, beat him up and he was barely able to crawl home with bleach all over himself. So that was just take that to the bank and run with it. This man who by the way, is adopted a lot of liberal causes as well.

COOPER: Absolutely.

INGRAHAM: Carries around a Trump sign and he's unabashed about it. Then he ends up dead and that's not a story?

COOPER: It's a story. I want to understand we've got wanted 1619 project where we're so interested and motivated by this idea that the race of America was its starting point, is its most quintessential important point. Why is there silence from The New York Times? Why is it that the party of segregation in the 19th century, the 20th century and even though, the 21st century has continually exploited people for political power and its own ambitions. Why aren't they being called out? Why haven't the media just raised some basic questions?

INGRAHAM: Now earlier this month on CNN, Actor Terry Crews actually hit the nail right on the head about why BLM just doesn't care about cases like Mr. Trammell's.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TERRY CREWS, ACTOR AND HOST: When you have the leaders of the Black Lives movement who are now talking about you know, if we don't get our demands, we're going to burn it down. Other black people who are talking about working with other whites and other - other races, being viewed as sell outs or called Uncle Toms, it starts - you start to understand that you are now, you're being controlled.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: Horace, they set upon Terry for having the temerity to raise that point. He became persona non grata. That's where we are in the country tonight.

COOPER: Silence those who dissent. This is a pattern that we've seen from the 1800s, 1900s and now in the 2000s heading into deep into the 21st century. Where is the understanding that free people regardless of color have the right to express themselves, to think what they want to think? And where is the outrage that someone could be killed over this only if they don't support the leftist candidate?

Where is the outrage?

INGRAHAM: Well, Horace, thanks so much. Great to see you tonight and as we noted, Trammell was ruthlessly gunned down in broad daylight in Milwaukee, last Thursday. This was amid growing outrage over the signs he was holding, supporting President Trump's re-election.

The police are currently asking the public to help identify the suspected shooter so we still don't know why Trammell was killed but tonight, I want to show you more of that video that INGRAHAM ANGLE exclusively obtained. It's footage from just days before Trammell's heinous murder.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRAMMELL: So today, if you noticed I moved a little closer.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Well and more people can interact with you on the sidewalk unlike the corner over there.

TRAMMELL: Right, right you know what I'm saying, when they're cussing and hollering, they can't jump out of the car and knock me out at the same time. He snatched the sign.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This one?

TRAMMELL: Yes, this one. I had to chase him across the street, grab him, swing him around, get the sign back. Well, that why I'm over here today. Over there, they're just about ready to kill me.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: Joining me now is Andrew Hitt, former prosecutor, Chairman of the Republican Party of Wisconsin. His office is also the one that got its hands on that video. Andrew, he says they're just about ready to kill me. What were your thoughts when you saw that, heard that for the first time?

ANDREW HITT, CHAIRMAN, REPUBLICAN PARTY OF WISCONSIN: Well Laura, I mean it is just so chilling to sit there and hear it and watch all of those videos. It's scary, it's terrifying when you think about it. We're a little under 100 days out from the presidential election and there's a real possibility that Trammell was killed as a result of this political beliefs for supporting President Trump.

INGRAHAM: Now we're seeing on the screen now a picture of a suspect that the Milwaukee police has put out. Some local media have described him as about 6 feet tall, apparently African-American, about 30 years of age or so. That's the estimate. Weighs over 200 pounds. Anyone who has any information, he apparently rides a black bike. Anyone has information, please contact the Milwaukee police department.

Right now, we have federal court houses being threatened. We have another case where a Democrat in Wisconsin was assaulted by two women who today were arrested. We'll put their photos up on the screen when we have them. Again, that's a Democrat was assaulted at one of these protests. These are the two women who were arrested in that assault of Tim Carpenter, I believe I'm getting that name right.

This is gotten beyond dangerous. Now lives perhaps are being lost in jeopardize. We had an individual shot in Austin, Texas over the last several days. Where does it end up?

HITT: Well, you know it's hard to see where we go from here. I mean this is a low point. I don't recall anything like this ever happening certainly in Milwaukee or Wisconsin before and you know where we go from here is we have to as people who support the President, we've got to stand up, we've got to honor Trammell and his passion for the President and we need to get this President re-elected and that's what we're going to do in the fall of 2020.

Well, he was pretty well known in the community Mr. Trammell. I think, I called - I said Trammel before but surprise that there's not more coverage of this by the national media when he's on camera saying, I think they're going to kill me, holding a political sign.

What happened to people believing in political speech not being punished in the United States?

HITT: Well, not only do we not see coverage in national news but we're not seeing anything or hearing any reaction from Democrat leaders and Milwaukee, we haven't heard anything from Mayor Barrett. We haven't heard anything from Congresswoman Gwen Moore. Nothing from Governor Evers. Nothing from Attorney General Josh Kaul.

I mean we have somebody who stood up every day, got out on the street corner, supporting the President talking about his political views and he is dead now and you know we're less than 100 days out from an election. This is worth talking about. This is worth thinking about, being concerned about and we've got to bring attention to this.

That's why I called for an investigation by the United States Attorney.

INGRAHAM: You just rattled off all the Democratic officials in the state. None of them have addressed this. None of them have talked about it. That speaks volumes and we're going to stay on this story. Andrew, thank you for helping us understand this better tonight.

And still to come Raymond Arroyo on Biden's latest string of well, memory lapses plus did Oregon leaders just lie about the drawdown of federal troops in Portland. DHS Secretary Chad wolf is here and he'll set that record straight. Don't miss it.

INGRAHAM: President Trump travel to Midland, Texas, today the heart of America's fracking boom to laud our amazing oil and gas workers and warned about the newest threat to our energy independence.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD J. TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Pennsylvania, Ohio, so many other places, you don't realize how big it is. They want to have no fracking, no nothing. This extreme agenda would mean the death of American prosperity at the end of the American middle class.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: He's right. Absolutely. The consequences would be dire especially for Ohio, Pennsylvania, Texas and elsewhere. That's why we're kicking off a new series tonight. It's called States of Discontent where we're going to examine how America, especially the swing states would fare under a Biden presidency because we know Joe is largely being controlled by a hard Left Obama alliance, it's imperative that the voters understand how his policies will in most cases radically alter the lives of most of you.

Let's start with the energy sector.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. BERNIE SANDERS (D-VT): I'm talking about stopping fracking as soon as we possibly can. I'm talking about telling the fossil fuel industries that they all going to stop destroying this planet. I'm talking about -

JOE BIDEN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: But why?

SANDERS: To try - well, I'm not sure your proposal does that.

Biden: No more, no more fracking.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: Of course Biden's handlers tried to walk back his remarks, claiming he'd only ban fracking on federal lands but he bent to Bernie there, right? And that would still do a huge amount of damage and moreover, do you really think that the squad would stand for only on federal lands banning it.

Now remember Biden appointed AOC to his Climate Policy panel after all with her stunning scientific acumen, who can blame him? She'll definitely be one of the loudest voices in the room so Pennsylvania, Ohio and Texas as we said are fracking powerhouses.

Voters in those states must realize that Joe's green new jobs fantasy will reward Democrat friends and destroy an industry, that's provided really good paying jobs to American families for over a decade now.

Let's look at numbers. A 2019 Chamber of Commerce study found that a fracking ban would lose more than 19 million jobs nationwide including 700,000 jobs in Ohio; 609,000 in Pennsylvania; 468,000 in Colorado and another 816,000 in Wisconsin and Michigan. States and localities of course would see their revenue shrink by $600 billion and children will suffer in states like New Mexico where a huge chunk of public education is funded through taxes on oil and gas.

Coloradan, well, you'd be on average $6500 poorer if fracking were banned. It'd be a climate stick up with Joe wearing the mask but wait, you can have faith in a green new deal, right? If higher taxes and endless funding for climate cronies, remember Solyndra, if that's your idea of fair, sure, it'll be swell.

Speaking of lives shattered under Democrat rule, we turn now to Portland. The site of months of violent Antifa chaos, their local leaders have refused to address. But could it be coming to a close. Today Oregon governor Kate Brown gleefully announcing that, "the federal government has agreed to withdraw federal officers from Portland. They've acted as an occupying force and brought violence. Starting tomorrow all Customs and Border Protection and ICE officers will leave downtown Portland."

Sounds like she's declaring victory. Well, that would be a shocking development, right? But is that true? Joining me now is Acting DHS Secretary Chad Wolf. Mr. Secretary, she says agents are an occupying force and basically good riddance, she won. What do you say?

CHAD WOLF, ACTING SECRETARY, DHS: Well, I think that language is very irresponsible. Again, she's describing law enforcement officers, civil law enforcement officers who wake up every day, put the badge on, put the uniform on and protect the community and federal properties as an occupying force and responsible for the violence that we've seen in Portland.

And it exactly opposite. It's the violent rioters and criminals that we've seen there for over 60 days that are the occupying force in downtown Portland and have caused this violence that we have seen. So I took exception to that, to that language and I would say all of our men and women, law enforcement officers at DHS and those inside that courthouse that are risking their lives every day also take exception to that language.

INGRAHAM: So how many people are going to be left, federal officers left, in that courthouse, given I guess, the agreement you two came to?

WOLF: Absolutely. Well, DHS law enforcement presence will remain in Portland until we can be assured that the plan put in place by the governor and the Oregon state police is working, is effective and they can continue to do it night after night and keep the criminal and violent activity away from the courthouse.

INGRAHAM: Mr. Secretary, hold on, hold on. Do you have faith? She just called your people an occupying force. Do you have faith that given their language, their attitude, and playing politics with this, that that's going to happen and this is going to be secure, Mr. Secretary?

WOLF: Well, we're going to have to wait and see on that. But I think the key there is that none of the DHS law enforcement that are there today, that have been there for the past month or over a month at this point are leaving Portland. We will remain there. We will protect that courthouse. That is our responsibility, and that is our duty.

With the Oregon state police, we have a robust presence coming in to downtown Portland across the streets from that courthouse, and we're going to see if they can execute the plan that they put in place. And that's not going to happen overnight. We're going to have to stay there. We're going to have to understand if their plan is effective. And if it's not, then we'll continue to secure that courthouse.

INGRAHAM: You know what's incredible is a good friend of mine in New Orleans has an office basically right across the street from the courthouse there, a business. And he said to me over the weekend, he said this is a sought after location, because we always assumed that area is going to be safe. Isn't it ironic that now areas near federal buildings are going to give businesses pause when they decide where to locate if this kind of nonsense continues? It never struck me before as when he said that to me over the weekend. And apparently, they are not going anywhere near that New Orleans federal courthouse because they're concerned.

WOLF: Right. What I will say in cities like New Orleans and other cities across the country, we have a good relationship with the state and local law enforcement. And if there are threats and there are targets against those federal facilities in those locations, we work as a team together to address those. And unfortunately, that has not occurred in Portland over the last 60 days. I'm glad the governor stepped up at this time and is deploying the Oregon state police, that should have been done earlier to address this situation so that they can police city streets and city parks in the area that these violent criminals are organizing each and every night. So I'm glad they did it, and I'm glad they're join other responsible cities around the country.

INGRAHAM: Well, they clearly decided this is just not working out for them politically. I know you're not going to say that, but I'll say it. They are looking at the public opinion on this, and it's starting to turn against the Democrats. That's why they decided to start working with you.

The governor of Michigan said this about having federal officers in her state, Mr. Secretary. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GOV. GRETCHEN WHITMER, (D) MICHIGAN: "What we are worried about, of course, is the federal government is going to come in and do what they did in Portland." That is not acceptable. That is not necessary.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: So is she saying she does not want you to protect courthouses from being burned down? As the A.G. said yesterday, is this now acceptable behavior as a political tactic?

WOLF: Right. It's very confusing. I've received a number of letters from mayors and governors, and it doesn't make any sense to me, because what they don't understand, they don't understand the facts on the ground in their state or in their cities. Again, Michigan and elsewhere, we have a good relationship with local and state law enforcement, and they come to our assistance when we need them too. We don't see that in Portland, which has caused what we've had over the last 60 days. But in other states and other cities, local and state law enforcement understand that that partnership is critical to securing federal facilities and working together as a team.

INGRAHAM: All right, Secretary, thank you.

Biden finally emerges from the basement, so surely he had a good event today, right? Raymond Arroyo will show you the latest, "Seen and Unseen" next.

INGRAHAM: It's time for our "Seen and Unseen" segment where we expose the stories behind the headlines. Biden escapes the basement for at least one event. For details we are joined by Raymond Arroyo, FOX News contributor. Raymond, Biden held a big presser yesterday, and he got rave reviews.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Joe Biden in his hometown of Wilmington, Delaware, today, not shying away from attacking Donald Trump.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Joe Biden is very comfortable in who he is and in his own skin.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: He was fine in that press conference and answered questions coherently and intelligently.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: Coherently, is that the standard now? How coherent and intelligent was it, Raymond?

RAYMOND ARROYO, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: You know what, Laura, I'm not going to characterize it. I'm going to let the audience be the judge. This is how Joe Biden started the presser.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE BIDEN, (D) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to the Kingswood Community Center. Actually, that's the one down I used to work. That was a joke. I didn't know where we were. Anyway.

(LAUGHTER)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARROYO: It's a joke, OK. It's unclear whether Biden knew where he actually was, Laura. And he was in his hometown where he does everything.

Then came the challenging questions from the press corps. Now note, all of the reporters were preapproved, Biden consults his list, and some reporters acted like they were campaign aides.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE BIDEN, (D) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I would be happy to take your questions. Let me get my list here are.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm curious, why Delaware?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Are you running against President Trump or for president?

BIDEN: Do you think the president all of a sudden decided not to go to Tallahassee because he no longer thought it was an interest of the public?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Jacksonville.

BIDEN: I mean Jacksonville.

I'm not prepared to say much more than that right now.

(LAUGHTER)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARROYO: Laura, are you trying to win your timeslot, or are you trying to get higher ratings than the competition? What kind of questions are these? And these performances of Biden, they don't exactly give voters confidence, that he's ready to lead or can lead any longer. Politics aside, you know what I always say, the more vigorous, vibrant candidate usually wins. That was Obama over tired old McCain and staid Romney. Trump was more vigorous than Hillary. And my sense is this race is tending in the same direction, which is why you see those tightening polls. The more people see this, the more his lead is eroding.

INGRAHAM: Raymond, I have a question for you tonight. Why New Orleans? Why? What kind of question is that?

(LAUGHTER)

ARROYO: That's all I'm going to say, Laura. I'm going to say no more.

INGRAHAM: The best is Biden answered, and he said, well, I find I can just campaign from here and nobody knows the difference. He explained why he doesn't have to campaign, because the press doesn't really hold him accountable for not campaigning. He's just going to stay in Delaware for the most part. What else?

ARROYO: This is why that Zogby poll, you see swing voters going with Trump by three to one, 65 percent for Trump, 21 for Biden. And a Marist poll has Biden at 59 percent support among Hispanic voters. That's worrisome for him. So he held an event with a Latino group today, but it was less than coherent and intelligent, Laura, and of course there were some technical pyrotechnics.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE BIDEN, (D) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I have to ensure the people of Puerto Rico have support to rebuild their country.

Think of the psychic -- the damage done to the psyche of so many young Latinos.

The 2020 census, which is now two censuses ago, soon to be.

I used to think you could defeat hate. I used to. But it just hides under a rock. It hides under rocks.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARROYO: Laura, this is like grandpa trying to operate the Zoom call. If things are coming in and out. But this comes at an urgent moment for Biden. The new Rasmussen poll has Trump with 41 percent over the Hispanic vote and Biden at 46. He can't win with those numbers. And poor man, maybe that psychic, psyche -- maybe that Spanish. I don't know, I don't recognize that particular accent.

INGRAHAM: First of all, all these immigrant families in just the D.C. area, northern Virginia, Maryland, they are unable to send their kids to school because the teachers unions are blocking a return to in-person education despite to science, despite the real medicine. This is now an easy call for minority owned businesses. Your businesses are going to be threatened, burned to the ground, and now this.

What else? You have one more thing about.

ARROYO: Before we go, some entertainment news with political implications. The Emmy nominations came out today, and as my cameraman here said, he didn't know, no one else did either. Brad Pitt was nominated for playing Dr. Anthony Fauci, Laura, for exactly three minutes. And if lousy imitations are the path to victory, surely Kate McKinnon will win an Emmy for her lousy imitation for you, my dear. And yes, she is nominated as well, believe it or not.

(LAUGHTER)

INGRAHAM: Is she nominated?

ARROYO: Yes, for that intoxicated kind of high, I'm Laura Ingraham.

INGRAHAM: OK, we're running over, but this is how she did my impression. She talked like this, hi, I'm Laura Ingraham from the "The Ingraham Angle." That's how she talks. I don't think I talk like that. It's just really bad.

ARROYO: And Brad Pitt did the worst Dr. Anthony Fauci I've ever heard. Terrible.

INGRAHAM: No, no, no.

ARROYO: Three minutes, and poor Eddie Murphy does an hour, he gets nominated in the same category. I hope Eddie and baby Yoda sweep everything.

INGRAHAM: If you thought "Meet Joe Black" was a flatliner performance, Fauci was. Raymond, thanks.

ARROYO: He'll be Joe Biden next season.

(LAUGHTER)

INGRAHAM: In moments, the war on hydroxy hits Silicon Valley, and Dr. Fauci cheers at all. Or was that Brad Pitt. Can't miss Medicine Cabinet next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DR. ANTHONY FAUCI, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES: Right now today, the cumulative scientific data that has been put together and done over a number of different studies has shown no efficacy. So when there is a video out there from a bunch of people spouting something that isn't true, the only recourse you have is to be very, very clear in presenting the scientific data that essentially contradicts that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: A bunch of doctors who actually treat COVID patients, Dr. Fauci. That was his latest attack on hydroxychloroquine. The video he is referencing is one that went viral before being censored by the social media giants. What are they afraid of? It featured medical doctors touting the benefits that they personally witnessed from treating patients with hydroxychloroquine.

And they are not alone. Joining me now is Dr. Harvey Risch, professor of Epidemiology at the Yale School of Public Health, and Dr. Stephen Smith, founder for Smith Center for Infectious Diseases and Urban Health. Dr. Risch, in your illustrious career, have you ever seen a commonly used drug this set upon?

DR. HARVEY RISCH, YALE SCHOOL OF PUBLIC HEALTH: No. Good evening, Laura. No. This is totally unusual, and just never seen before that I know of.

INGRAHAM: Big tech CEOs appeared before a congressional committee today, and the topic quickly turned to their ban on that hydroxy video the other day.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK ZUCKERBERG, FACEBOOK CEO: If someone is going to go out and say the hydroxychloroquine is proven to cure COVID when in fact it has not been proven to cure COVID, and that that statement could lead people to take a drug that in some cases, some of the data suggests that it might be harmful to people, we think that we should take that down. That could cause imminent risk.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: He should stick to comparing the pictures of hot girls at Harvard. Dr. Smith, how dangerous is it to have big tech now judging what the correct opinions are on medical science?

DR. STEPHEN SMITH, SMITH CENTER OF INFECTIOUS DISEASES: This is an enormous. It's an enormously bad development for U.S. medicine. It's horrible to have tech companies weighing on what's good and what's bad for you from a medical point of view, regardless of what the issue is.

INGRAHAM: Ohio is taking its cues from the leftist media on hydroxy. "The Columbus Dispatch" reporting pharmacies, clinics, and other medical institutions in Ohio will be prohibited from dispensing or selling hydroxychloroquine to treat COVID-19 according to new regs issued by the State Ohio Board of Pharmacy. Dr. Risch, I've heard from several doctors in Ohio tonight about this. They said they have never witnessed anything like this, the drug that has been around six decades. And at the end of this new regulation, they admit that doctors do say it can be efficacious.

RISCH: That's right. But Ohio is no different except that they made this public. Forty-four states in total have restrictions and limitations on both prescribing hydroxychloroquine and selling it. And doctors are intimidated all over the country from doing this. So Ohio is more out in public about it.

INGRAHAM: Dr. Smith, lives, in my view, are in danger, in jeopardy because of this. But I'm not a doctor. You're the one treating COVID patients. Do you agree with that?

SMITH: A hundred percent. I've seen this. A large percent of our patients that end up dying or being intubated with COVID come to the E.R. and get sent home with nothing. And we know from the French data that that group that is mildly ill do very, very well with hydroxychloroquine, azithromycin. And the combination is extremely safe. And that is really disturbing what is going on in Ohio and what is going on, period, with this drug. I don't understand it at all.

And yet, people have died because they did not get hydroxychloroquine and azithromycin coming to the E.R. They come back three or four days later, get put on a ventilator, and a month later die. That's an awful, awful thing to happen. It's happened several times to patients I'm taken care of. And we know --

INGRAHAM: I'm sorry to interrupt, but I hope people are understanding this, Dr. Risch, what they are hearing. Dr. Smith is one of the preeminent doctors in New Jersey treating patients, OK? He is a real doctor. He's a practicing physician right now in infectious diseases. Why is this happening, Dr. Risch? Is this political because Trump said it can work, and so if it works, then Trump is responsible for saving lives? What is going on here?

RISCH: I think the main reason is that the FDA has said that this drug has potential harms. And they said this, and it's on their website as of the posting July 1st, that it says in the title of the website that hydroxychloroquine should not be used in patients managed in outpatient circumstances with this drug because of risks of cardiac arrhythmias. But underneath that box, underneath the title, there's a box that says it was only from data --

INGRAHAM: Hold that, Dr. Risch. We'll have you back to continue this. We have to take a quick break. Stay there.

INGRAHAM: Dr. Fauci is changing his mind on masks again? Now they don't cover enough of your face.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: You think where we are going to go to where eye protection is recommended.

DR. ANTHONY FAUCI, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES: You know it might, if you have goggles or an eye shield, you should use it. It's not universally recommended, but if you really want to be complete, you should probably use it if you can.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: What's next, scuba gear, spacesuits, ski goggles on the subway? Wait, I shouldn't give me any ideas. That's all the time we have tonight.

Shannon Bream, "FOX NEWS @ NIGHT" team, take it all from here. Shannon.

MARTHA MACCALLUM, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: So that is THE STORY of Tuesday, October the first already 2019. But as you know THE STORY goes on. So we will see you back here tomorrow night. Thanks for being with us tonight, everybody. Have a great night. Stick around for Tucker Carlson, coming up next.

TUCKER CARLSON, FOX NEWS HOST: Good evening, and welcome to TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT. There is often disagreement in Washington. But if there's one thing that everyone who lives in the city knows for certain, it is that investigations of government officials are always a good thing. Yes, they can be expensive. They can run to tens of millions of dollars per. Of course they do paralyze the government making it impossible to fix our most pressing problems.

And then if we're being honest about it, we will also concede that investigations tend to destroy the lives of completely innocent people.

But in the end, as anyone in Washington can and will tell you, all of that is well worth it. Investigations are a search for facts. Anyone who stands in their way, obstructs the truth itself.

That, ladies and gentlemen, is why we spent more than two full years looking into the question of whether or not Donald Trump worked secretly as an agent of Vladimir Putin.

There was never any evidence that he did that, but Hillary Clinton's campaign donors demanded a thorough investigation of it anyway. And so as you well know, we got that investigation.

In the end, the investigation in effect cleared Donald Trump of claims he colluded with Russia. But it also did something else. It inadvertently implicated quite a few other people for unrelated crimes.

We learned, for example, that quite a few senior law enforcement and Intelligence officials think nothing of lying to the public -- really lying to the public -- or of abusing their tremendous powers for partisan political ends. They did that, we now know that.

We also learned that the Obama administration was perfectly willing to spy on his political opponents in the middle of a presidential campaign. It did that, too.

Now, these are not small revelations, nothing like them has happened in recent American history. So it would seem wise to get the bottom of exactly what happened, who did it and why.

And as it turns out, for the past seven months, the Attorney General William Barr has been trying to do just that. He has opened an investigation.

Now, you would think, given everything you know about Washington, and its love of investigations that everyone in official D.C. would be thrilled by this, but you would be wrong. Because here's the thing. They are not happy in the slightest, they are outraged, in fact.

Former acting F.B.I. Director Andy McCabe went on CNN today to complain about Barr's investigation. As it turns out, McCabe is one of the people the Attorney General will be investigating.

Andy McCabe thinks that's completely outrageous.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ANDY MCCABE, FORMER F.B.I. DEPUTY DIRECTOR: There are two primary questions that I think you have to ask here. The first is why is he doing this at all? The circumstances behind the opening of the Russia case are not a mystery.

I have testified under oath about them as early as December of 2017. Jim Comey has made comments about them publicly. I have -- we've both written books that touched on the issues. So it's -- the circumstances behind the case are widely known. They were entirely validated by the Special Counsel investigation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Got that? Jim Comey and I already wrote bestselling books explaining our side of things. So what is there to investigate? McCabe seemed completely serious as he said this. How dare the Justice Department not accept my word at face value, despite the fact I was fired for lying?

You'd have to be lacking a certain -- what's the term here -- self- awareness to make a case like that on television, but McCabe was happy to.

And by the way, the CNN anchor seemed to agree with him wholeheartedly. It's certainly a common view in Washington.

A story in this morning's "Washington Post" for example, quotes unnamed Federal bureaucrats grousing that they might be subject to the same oversight the rest of us could expect if we ever stepped out of line.

Here's a direct quote, "Current and former Intelligence and law enforcement officials expressed frustration and alarm Monday that the head of the Justice Department was taking such a direct role in reexamining what they view is conspiracy theories and baseless allegations of misconduct."

Got that? The allegations against me are baseless. I'm claiming from behind the cloak of anonymity. How dare you investigate us? Didn't you hear what I said? It's baseless. Call off your investigation. I already wrote the book. I already denied it.

Now, this is the part in the story when honest journalists might step forward -- by the way of all political backgrounds -- and remind us that that's a pretty ludicrous response, actually, and that nobody is above the reach of a Federal investigation.

But no, the kind of journalist who would make that point seems to have retired or at least no longer works at NBC News. Instead, we get hacks like this siding with the nameless unaccountable bureaucrats against the rest of us.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEN DILANIAN, NBC NEWSINTEL AND NATIONAL SECURITY CORRESPONDENT: The top law enforcement official in the United States, Stephanie is spending his time amid all the great concerns that must be on his plate pursuing what many people believe is essentially a conspiracy theory about the origins of the Russia investigation.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It appears that it is just the Attorney General operating outside the normal D.O.J. channels to kind of, you know, roam around the world, roam around the Intelligence Community looking for ways to smear the people the President sees as his political opponents, the Intelligence Community and the F.B.I.

LAWRENCE O'DONNELL, MSNBC HOST: William Barr could be as deeply implicated in what Nancy Pelosi has called the Trump cover-up as Richard Nixon's Attorney General was in the Nixon cover-up.

Tonight, the Attorney General of the United States once again, needs his own personally paid for criminal defense lawyer who might soon become the only person William Barr can safely talk to in Washington.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Yes, whatever that means. Let's translate for you just to make it totally clear. Powerful people are telling you that they should not be subjected to oversight. We should not be investigated say powerful people. The people whose job it is to watch over the powerful people and hold them to account, they agree.

No oversight required. Ever feel like nobody's on your side? Maybe it's because nobody is.

Chief Intelligence Correspondent, Catherine Herridge joins us with more on the latest on the Attorney General William Barr's investigation into what just happened. Catherine, great to see you.

CATHERINE HERRIDGE, FOX NEWS CHIEF INTELLIGENCE CORRESPONDENT: Tucker, good evening. The investigation into the genesis of the 2016 F.B.I. Russia collusion probe is global with confirmation tonight from a senior Justice Department official that Attorney General William Barr and U.S. Attorney John Durham were in Italy last week as part of the case.

A source close to the process tells Fox News that earlier this year, Barr got the runaround from senior Intelligence officials about the Maltese Professor Joseph Mifsud and whether he had connections to U.S., Italian or other foreign intelligence service.

The Special Counsel report describes Mifsud as quote, "A London based Professor with connections to Russia, who told campaign a George Papadopoulos that Moscow had dirt on Hillary Clinton in the form of thousands of e-mails." Those claims let the collusion flame with the F.B.I. later opening the counterintelligence case.

In May after this Special Counsel report and before the July 25th phone call with the Ukrainian leader, President Trump told reporters he wanted Barr to cast a wide net.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The Attorney General is one of the most respected people in this country. I hope he looks at Australia. And I hope he looks at Ukraine. I hope he looks at everything, because there was a hoax that was perpetrated on our country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HERRIDGE: There is a second investigation by Justice Department Inspector General Michael E. Horowitz into the surveillance warrant and renewals targeting the Trump campaign, but the scope of that investigation is narrow and Horowitz cannot compel some testimony.

A source close to the process tonight suggested to Fox News, the report could finally come later this month -- Tucker.

CARLSON: That'll be interesting.

HERRIDGE: It will be.

CARLSON: Catherine Herridge, thank you so much for that. Well, Hunter Biden somehow got a corporate Board seat in a Ukrainian energy company. Why? Well, it seems obvious, the purpose would be influencing his father, who was Vice President at the time and whose portfolio included Ukraine.

Now Joe Biden, to the extent he has been asked about it -- not very often, presses deeply and curious -- but he certainly has been, and he says, well, it wasn't a corrupt arrangement, because he never spoke to Hunter Biden about the arrangement.

And yet, as we reported last night on this show, there is photographic evidence of Biden on a golf outing with both his son Hunter and a man called Devon Archer, who was another member of the Burisma Board.

What does this add up to? Doug Macgregor has deep knowledge of Ukraine. He is a former U.S. Army Colonel and author of the book, Margin of Victory." He joins us tonight. So, Doug, thanks so much for coming on. So you're familiar with the region and you're familiar with Washington.

COL. DOUGLAS MACGREGOR (RET), U.S. ARMY: Yes.

CARLSON: What do you think was going on here?

MACGREGOR: Well, I think we know now and in fact, for your information, "Novaya Gazeta" in Moscow has now just recently published an article backed up by documents that go into far greater detail than we can hear, but the bottom line is that the oligarch who is responsible for appointing Mr. Biden to the Board and his friend, Archer, Devon --

It seems that he was banned from traveling to the United States. And then magically after the appointment to the Board occurred, suddenly the ban on this man's travel to the United States was lifted, and his suspected criminal activities and shady business practices were suddenly ignored.

So if you're looking for quid pro quo, it's pretty hard to argue that there wasn't a quid pro quo, at least on that level.

CARLSON: That is -- that is absolutely remarkable and checkable by the way.

MACGREGOR: Yes, absolutely. Absolutely. And to this, you've got to add a whole range of other things, billions of dollars over many years in Ukraine disappearing into private banks. One owned by this particular oligarch, and $5 billion, $4 billion -- we're not really sure that may have been lost of that, at $3 billion or $4 billion came out of the I.M.F. that was supposed to jumpstart the Ukrainian economy.

So the whole problem with corruption in Ukraine is pervasive.

CARLSON: The left's campaign against science in general and Biology in particular, has already claimed quite a few victims, the Boy Scouts and the Girl Scouts among them, but here's a new one -- urinals.

Portland, Oregon is abolishing urinals in all of its municipal buildings. The purpose is to quote, "remove arbitrary barriers" -- arbitrary -- between the sexes for the sake of gender neutrality.

How to assess this? Tammy Bruce hosts "Get Tammy Bruce" on Fox nation or reason to subscribe. She joins us tonight. Hey, Tammy, was there groundswell of support for this? Did people ask for this?

I mean, from the beginning -- this is a great question, Tucker, because whether it was the transgender bathroom issue or this, nobody wanted this to change. Nobody was having a problem. And then that's the other issue, separate from the inevitable bathroom humor, that fact is that this is actually very serious. And look, there are many different people in the world. I'm one of them, right? I'm a sexual minority. And the fact is, you know, we're part of a -- we're a minority in a part of a larger framework, and that's okay.
